explanations: The French states that husbands 'abandonnent aux Etrangers un superflu' (abandon a surplus to strangers), where 'un superflu' refers to the excess of 'faveurs' (favors) from their wives. The English translation 'do freely abandon their fair Wives to Strangers' makes two key explicitations: it adds 'freely,' clarifying the nature of the abandonment, and more significantly, it changes the object of abandonment from the abstract 'superflu' (surplus of favors) to the concrete 'their fair Wives.' This re-writing makes the practical outcome more direct and explicit.

The French 'un superflu' (a surplus), which the husbands find in their wives' 'faveurs' (favors), is significantly expanded in the English phrase 'so many Charms in their Embraces, as more than satisfie them.' This target segment explicitly details both *what* constitutes the surplus (an abundance of 'Charms,' with 'Embraces' specifying 'faveurs') and *why* it is a surplus ('as more than satisfie them'), thereby adding layers of explanation that were only implied in the concise French original.

The French 'd'une soye' (of silk), describing the material of the silkworm's cocoon, is translated and expanded to 'wrought together with Silk.' This addition makes explicit the idea of construction and material composition, clarifying that the cocoons are not merely 'of silk' but are actively 'wrought' or fabricated from it, an aspect of their formation implied but not detailed in the source.

The French 'une espece de duvet' (a kind of down) is rendered as 'a Covering of soft Down.' The translator enhances explicitness by adding 'soft' (a quality often implied by 'duvet' but here stated) and specifies its function in relation to the Earth as 'a Covering,' thereby clarifying its role as the atmospheric layer that is 'couverte' (covered) over the planet.

The French phrase 'jusqu'à vinght lieües de hauteur' (up to twenty leagues in height) is translated as 'of twenty Leagues thickness.' The translator changes 'hauteur' (which can mean height or altitude) to 'thickness,' explicitly clarifying that this dimension refers to the depth or layered extent of the air surrounding the Earth, rather than its altitude from a specific reference point.

The French 'la matiere celeste' (the celestial matter) is translated as 'that Celestial Matter I spoke of.' The addition of the clause 'I spoke of' makes an implicit anaphoric reference explicit. It directly links this mention of celestial matter to a previous statement by the narrator within the dialogue, a connection that the French leaves for the reader to infer from the context of the ongoing conversation.

chunks.source_manual: <P016>Vous me présentez la Terre sous des idées bien méprisables, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>. C'est pourtant sur cette Coque de Ver à Soye qu'il se fait de si grands Travaux, de si grandes Guerres, & qu'il regne de tous costez une si grande agitation. Oüy, répondis-je, & pendant ce temps-là la Nature qui n'entre point en connoissance de tous ces petits mouvemens particuliers, nous emporte tous ensemble d'un mouvement général, & se joüe de la petite boule.</P016> <P017>Il me semble, reprit-elle, qu'il est ridicule d'estre sur quelque chose qui tourne, & de se tourmenter tant; mais le malheur est qu'on n'est pas assez assuré qu'on tourne; car enfin, à ne vous rien celer, toutes les précautions que vous prenez pour empêcher qu'on ne s'apperçoive du mouvement de la Terre, me sont un peu suspectes. Est-il possible qu'il ne laissera pas quelque petite marque sensible à laquelle on le reconnoisse?</P017> <P018>Les mouvemens les plus naturels, répondis-je, & les plus ordinaires sont ceux qui se font le moins sentir, & cela est vray jusque dans la Morale. Le mouvement de l'Amour propre nous est si naturel, que le plus souvent nous ne le sentons pas, & que nous croyons agir par d'autres principes. Ah! vous <IIM>moralisez</IIM>, dit- elle, quand il est question de <RW>Phisique</RW>, cela s'appelle baailler. Retirons-nous, aussi bien en Voila assez pour la premiere fois. Demain nous reviendrons icy, vous avec vos Systêmes, & moy avec mon Ignorance.</P018> <P019>En retournant au Château je luy dis pour épuiser la matiere des Systêmes, qu'il y en avoit un troisiéme inventé par Ticho- Brahé qui, voulant absolument que la Terre fust immobile, la plaçoit au centre du Monde, & faisoit tourner autour d'elle le Soleil, autour duquel tournoient toutes les autres Planetes, parce que depuis les nouvelles Découvertes, il n'y avoit pas moyen de faire tourner les Planetes autour de la Terre. Mais la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, qui a le discernement vif & prompt, jugea qu'il y avoit trop d'affectation à exempter la Terre de tourner autour du Soleil, puis qu'on n'en pouvait pas exempter tant d'autres grands Corps; que le Soleil n'estoit plus si propre à tourner autour de la Terre, depuis que toutes les Planetes tournoient autour de luy; que ce Systême ne pouvoit estre propre tout au plus qu'à soûtenir l'Immobilité de la Terre, quand on avoit bien envie de la soûtenir, & nullement à la persuader; & enfin il fut résolu que nous nous en tiendrions à celuy de Copernic, qui est plus uniforme & plus riant, & n'a aucun mélange de préjugé. En effet la simplicité dont il est, vous persuade, & sa hardiesse vous fait plaisir.</P019>
chunks.target_manual: <P016>You represent the Earth to me, said the Marquiese, as a very contemptible thing, by the despicable Idea's you give me of it: 'Tis, nevertheless, upon this Silk-Worm-Ball, there are perform'd such mighty Works; and where there are such terrible Wars, and such strange Commotions as reign every where. 'Tis certainly true, said I, Madam; while at the same time, Nature, who is not at the pains to consider these Troubles and Commotions, carries us all along together, by a general Motion, and does, as it were, play with this little Globe. It seems to me, said she, that 'tis very ridiculous to inhabit any thing that turns so often, and is so much agitated; and the worst of all is, that we are not assur'd whether we turn round, or not; for, to be plain with you, and that I may keep none of my Doubts from you, I do extreamly suspect, that all the Pre-cautions you can take, will not convince me of the Motion of the Earth: For is it possible, but Nature wou'd have taken care to have given us some sensible Sign, by which we might discover the turning round of so vast a Body? The Motions (answer'd I) which are most natural to remove, are the least perceptible; and which holds true, even in Morality; for the Motion of Self-love is so natural to us, that for the most part we do not feel it, while we believe we act by other Principles. Ah, said she, do you begin to speak of <IIM>Moral</IIM> Philosophy, when the Question is of that which is altogether natural? But I perceive you are sleepy, and begin to yawn; let us therefore retire, for there's enough said for the first Night, to morrow we shall return hither again; you with your Systems, and I with my Ignorance. In returning to the Castle, to make an end of what might be said to Systems, I told her, there was a third Opinion invented by Ticho-brahe, who wou'd have the Earth absolutely immoveable, and plac'd in the Centre of the Universe, and made the Sun to turn round it, as he did the other Planets to turn round the Sun; because, since the new Discoveries, it cou'd not be imagin'd that the other Planets turn'd round the Earth. But my Lady Marquiese, whose Judgment and Understanding is solid and penetrating, found, there was too much Affectation in endeavouring to free the Earth from turning round the Sun, since several other great Bodies cou'd not be exempt from that Labour; and that the Sun was not so proper and fit to turn round the Earth, since the other Planets turn round the Sun; and that this new System was only good to maintain the standing still of the Earth, if one had a mind to undertake that Argument; but 'tis not proper to perswade another to believe it. At last, we resolv'd to hold our selves to the Opinion of Copernicus, which is more uniform, and more agreeable, without the least mixture of Prejudice; and, indeed, its Simplicity and Easiness perswades as much as its Boldness pleases.</P016>

explanations: The French 'répondis-je' (replied I) is translated as 'said I, Madam;'. The addition of 'Madam' explicitly includes a formal term of address for the Marquise, making an element of social decorum explicit that was implied by the characters' status and the conversational context.

The French 'la Nature qui n'entre point en connoissance de tous ces petits mouvemens particuliers' (Nature, who does not take cognizance of all these small particular movements) is translated as 'Nature, who is not at the pains to consider these Troubles and Commotions,'. The phrase 'Troubles and Commotions' explicitly interprets the 'petits mouvemens particuliers' (referring to human endeavors like wars and works) with a specific, human-centric negative connotation, making the implied nature of these 'movements' explicit.

The French 'd'estre sur quelque chose qui tourne' (to be on something that turns) is translated as 'to inhabit any thing that turns'. The verb 'to inhabit' makes explicit the specific mode of 'being on' the Earth, clarifying that it refers to dwelling or residing, a nuance implied but not directly stated by the more general 'estre sur'.

The French 'à ne vous rien celer' (to hide nothing from you) is translated as 'to be plain with you, and that I may keep none of my Doubts from you,'. The addition 'and that I may keep none of my Doubts from you' explicitly specifies that the 'nothing' (rien) being concealed refers to her 'Doubts', information that was only generally implied.

The French phrase regarding the precautions, 'me sont un peu suspectes.' (are a bit suspect to me.), describes a quality of the precautions. The translation shifts to 'that all the Pre-cautions you can take, will not convince me of the Motion of the Earth:' making explicit the *content* of her suspicion or the specific *consequence* she infers – namely, her belief that the precautions will be ineffective in convincing her.

The French 'Est-il possible qu'il ne laissera pas quelque petite marque sensible' (Is it possible that it/there won't be some small sensible mark) is impersonal. The translation 'For is it possible, but Nature wou'd have taken care to have given us some sensible Sign,' explicitly introduces 'Nature' as the agent responsible for providing such a sign, making an underlying philosophical assumption about Nature's role explicit.

The French 'à laquelle on le reconnoisse?' (by which one recognizes it [the movement]) is translated as 'by which we might discover the turning round of so vast a Body?'. The phrase 'the turning round of so vast a Body' explicitly restates and expands on what the pronoun 'le' (it) refers to (the Earth's movement), and adds the descriptive 'of so vast a Body,' making the referent and its characteristics explicit.

The French 'vous moralisez' (you are moralizing) is translated as 'do you begin to speak of Moral Philosophy,'. The translation explicitly specifies the subject matter ('Moral Philosophy') that 'moralisez' refers to in this context, clarifying the domain of the philosopher's discourse which was only implied by the verb.

The French 'Phisique' (Physics) is translated as 'that which is altogether natural?'. In the 17th-century context, 'Phisique' often referred to Natural Philosophy. The translation 'that which is altogether natural' makes this broader, historical meaning of 'Phisique' explicit, clarifying its scope beyond modern physics.

The French 'cela s'appelle baailler.' (literally 'that is called yawning,' idiomatically suggesting the situation is boring or induces yawning) is impersonal. The translation 'But I perceive you are sleepy, and begin to yawn;' makes the cause ('sleepy') and the subject (the philosopher, 'you') of the yawning explicit, personalizing the observation and clarifying the implied connection between the discourse and the act of yawning.

The French 'aussi bien' (as well/besides/it's just as well), introducing a reason for retiring, is translated as 'therefore'. The word 'therefore' makes the logical, causal connection between the preceding statement (about yawning/enough talk) and the decision to retire more explicit than the looser connection implied by 'aussi bien'.

The French 'en Voila assez pour la premiere fois.' (that's enough for the first time) is translated as 'for there's enough said for the first Night,'. The additions 'said' and 'Night' make explicit *what* there is enough of (conversation/words said) and specify that 'la premiere fois' (the first time) refers to the context of the 'first Night' of their discussions.

The French 'pour épuiser la matiere des Systêmes,' (to exhaust the matter of Systems) is translated as 'to make an end of what might be said to Systems,'. The translation clarifies *how* the matter is to be exhausted by explicitly stating it involves 'what might be said,' thus spelling out the verbal nature of 'exhausting the topic' which was implied.

The French 'la Marquise, qui a le discernement vif & prompt,' (the Marquise, who has sharp and quick discernment) is translated as 'my Lady Marquiese, whose Judgment and Understanding is solid and penetrating,'. The singular 'discernement' is expanded into the dyad 'Judgment and Understanding,' and 'vif & prompt' (sharp & quick) is rephrased with 'solid and penetrating,' which elaborates and makes more explicit the qualities of her intellect.

The French 'puis qu'on n'en pouvait pas exempter tant d'autres grands Corps;' (since one could not exempt so many other large bodies from it;) uses the pronoun 'en' (from it) to refer implicitly to the act of turning. The translation 'since several other great Bodies cou'd not be exempt from that Labour;' makes this referent explicit by naming it 'that Labour' (i.e., the labor of turning).

The French 'quand on avoit bien envie de la soûtenir,' (when one really wanted to support it [the immobility of the Earth]) is translated as 'if one had a mind to undertake that Argument;'. The phrase 'to undertake that Argument' explicitly clarifies the *manner* in which one might support the idea, specifying it as engaging in an 'Argument,' which was implied by the context of discussing philosophical systems.

The French 'nullement à la persuader;' (not at all to persuade it [the immobility or the system supporting it]) is translated as 'but 'tis not proper to perswade another to believe it.'. The translation makes explicit the indirect object of persuasion ('another') and what they are persuaded of ('to believe it'), details that are only implied in the more abstract French phrasing.

The French 'la simplicité dont il est,' (its simplicity) is translated as 'its Simplicity and Easiness'. The addition of 'Easiness' alongside 'Simplicity' expands on the single French term, explicitly stating a related quality (ease of understanding or acceptance) that might be implied by 'simplicité' but is not directly expressed.

explanations: The French "Soir" (Evening) in the chapter title "SECOND SOIR." is translated as "Night" in "The Second Night." This choice makes explicit the implication that the conversations, which revolve around astronomy and celestial observation, occur during a time of sufficient darkness for these activities. While "soir" can refer to the period from late afternoon into early night, "Night" more specifically denotes the darker hours optimal for stargazing. The translation thus emphasizes the scientific observational context of the dialogues, which was implicit in the original's combination of "Soir" and the subject matter, potentially altering the original's gentler, more social connotation of an "evening" rendezvous.

chunks.source_manual: <P021>Le lendemain au matin dés que l'on pût entrer dans l'Appartement de la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, j'envoyay sçavoir de ses nouvelles, & luy demander si elle avoit pû dormir en tournant. Elle me fit répondre qu'elle estoit déjà toute accoûtumée à cette allûre de la Terre, & qu'elle avoit passé la nuit aussi tranquillement qu'auroit pû faire Copernic luy-mesme. Quelque temps après il vint chez elle du monde qui y demeura jusqu'au soir, selon l'ennuyeuse coutume de la Campagne. Encore leur fut-on bien obligé, car la Campagne leur donnoit aussi le droit de pousser leur visite jusqu'au lendemain, s'ils eussent voulu, & ils eurent l'honnesteté de ne le pas faire. Ainsi la <IIM>Marquise</IIM> & moy nous nous retrouvâmes libres le Soir. Nous allâmes encore dans le Parc, & la Conversation ne manqua pas de tourneraussi-tost sur nos Sistêmes. Elle les avoit si bien conceus, qu'elle dédaigna d'en parler une seconde fois, & elle voulut que je la menasse a quelque chose de nouveau. Et bien donc, luy dis-je, puis que le Soleil, qui est presentement immobile, a cessé d'estre Planete, & que la Terre qui se meut autour de luy, a commencé d'en estre une, vous ne serez pas si surprise d'entendre dire que la Lune est une Terre comme celle-cy, & qu'apparemment elle est habitée. Je n'ay pourtant jamais oüy parler de la Lune habitée, dit-elle, que comme d'une <IIM>folie & d'une vision</IIM>. C'en est peut-estre une aussi, répondis-je. Je ne prens party dans ces choses-là que comme on en prend dans les Guerres Civiles, où l'incertitude de ce qui peut arriver, fait qu'on entretient toûjours des <IIM>intelligences</IIM> dans le party opposé, & <IIM>qu'on a des ménagemens avec ses Ennemis mesmes</IIM>. Pour moy, quoyque je voye la Lune habitée, je ne laisse pas de vivre civilement avec ceux qui ne le croyent pas, <SC></SC> & je me tiens toûjours en estat de me pouvoir ranger à leur opinion avec honneur, si elle avoit le dessus; mais en attendant qu'ils ayent sur nous quelque avantage considérable, voyci ce qui m'a mis du côté des Habitans de la Lune.</P021> <P022>Suposons qu'il n'y ait jamais eu nul commerce entre <NCE>Paris & Saint-Denis</NCE>, & qu'un Bourgeois de Paris qui ne sera jamais sorty de sa Ville, soit sur les Tours de <NCE>Nostre Dame</NCE>, & voye <NCE>Saint Denis</NCE> de loin, on luy demandera s'il croit que <NCE>Saint Denis</NCE> soit habité <SC>comme Paris</SC>. Il répondra hardiment que non; car, dira- t-il, je voy bien les Habitans de Paris, mais ceux de Saint Denis, je ne les voy point, & on n'en a jamais entendu parler. Il y aura quelqu'un qui luy representera qu'à la verité quand on est sur les <NCE>Tours de Nostre Dame</NCE>, on ne voit pas les Habitans de Saint Denis, mais que l'éloignement en est cause; que tout ce qu'on peut voir de Saint Denis ressemble fort à Paris: que Saint Denis a des Clochers, des Maisons, des Murailles, & qu'il pourroit bien encore ressembler à Paris pour ce qui est d'estre habité. Tout cela ne gagnera rien sur mon Bourgeois, il s'obstinera toûjours à soûtenir que Saint Denis n'est point habité, puis qu'il n'y voit personne. Nostre Saint Denis c'est la Lune, & chacun de nous est ce Bourgeois de Paris, qui n'est jamais sorty de sa Ville.</P022> <P023>Ah! interrompit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, vous nous faites tort, nous ne sommes point si sots que vostre Bourgeois. Puis qu'il voit que Saint Denis est tout fait comme Paris, il faut qu'il ait perdu la raison pour ne le pas croire habité; mais la Lune n'est point du tout faite comme la Terre. Prenez garde, Madame, repris-je, car s'il faut que la Lune ressemble en tout à la Terre, vous Voila dans l'obligation de croire la Lune habitée. J'avoüe, répondit-elle, qu'il n'y aura pas moyen de s'en dispenser, & je vous vois un air de confiance qui me fait déjà peur. Les deux mouvemens de la Terre dont je ne me fusse jamais doutée, me <IIM>rendent timide sur tout le reste</IIM>, mais pourtant seroit-il bien possible que la Terre fût lumineuse comme la Lune? Car il faut cela pour leur ressemblance. Helas! Madame, repliquay-je, estre lumineux n'est pas si grand-chose que vous pensez. Il n'y a que le Soleil en qui cela soit une qualité considérable. Il est lumineux par luy-mesme, & en vertu d'une nature particuliere qu'il a, mais les Planetes n'éclairent que parce qu'elles sont éclairées de luy. Il envoye sa lumiere à la Lune, elle nous la renvoye, & il faut que la Terre renvoye aussi à la Lune la lumiere du Soleil; il n'y a pas plus loin de la Terre à la Lune, que de la Lune à la Terre.</P023>
chunks.target_manual: <P018>AS soon as one could get into my Lady Marquiese's Apartment, I sent to know how she did, and how she had slept that Night in turning round. She sent me word, that now she was pretty well accustom'd to the Motion of the Earth, and that Copernicus himself cou'd not have rested better that Night than she did. A little after this, there came Company to visit my Lady, which, according to the nauseous Country-fashion, stay'd till the Evening, and yet we thought our selves happy that we were so easily rid of 'em then, since, according to the custom of the Country, they might have prolong'd their Visit till the next Day; but they were so civil, as not to do it; so that Madam the Marquiese and I found our selves at liberty. In the Evening we went again to the Park, and the Conversation began as it ended before, of our System: My Lady Marquiese had comprehended 'em so well, that she wou'd not be at the pains to re-assume any thing of what had pass'd, but press'd me to lead her to something that was new. Well, said I, since the Sun, which is now immoveable, and no longer a Planet; and that the Earth, that moves round the Sun, is now one, be not surpriz'd if I tell you, the Moon is another Earth, and is, by all appearance, inhabited. Said she, I never heard of the Moon's being inhabited, but as a Fable. So it may be still, said I; I concern my self no further in these Matters, than Men use to do in Civil Wars; where the Uncertainty of what may be, makes People still entertain a Correspondence with the adverse Party: As for me, tho' I see the Moon inhabited, I live very civilly with those that do not believe it; and I carry my self so trimmingly, that I may, <UP>upon occasion,</UP> with Honour go over to their side who have the better; but still they gain some considerable Advantage over us. I'll tell you my Reasons that make me take part with the Inhabitants of the Moon: Suppose then, there had never been any Commerce between Paris and St. Denis, and that a Citizen of Paris, who had never been out of that City, shou'd go up to the top of the Steeple of our Lady, and shou'd view St. Denis at a distance, and one shou'd ask him if he believ'd St. Denis to be inhabited; he wou'd answer boldly, Not at all; for (he wou'd say) I see the Inhabitants of Paris, but I do not see those of St. Denis, nor ever heard of 'em. It may be, some body standing by, wou'd represent to him, That it was true, one cou'd not see the Inhabitants of St. Denis from our Lady's Church, but that the distance was the cause of it; yet that all we cou'd see of St. Denis, was very like to Paris; for St. Denis had Steeples, Houses and Walls; and that it might resemble Paris in every thing else, and be inhabited as well as it. All these Arguments wou'd not prevail upon my Citizen; who wou'd continue still obstinate in maintaining, that St. Denis was not inhabited, because he saw none of the People. The Moon is our St. Denis, and we the Citizens of Paris, that never went out of our own Town. Ah, interrupted the Marquiese, you do us wrong; we are not so foolish as your Citizens of Paris: Since he sees that St. Denis is so like to Paris in every thing, he must have lost his Reason, if he did not think it was inhabited: But for the Moon, that's nothing like the Earth. Have a care, Madam, said I, what you say; for if I make it appear, that the Moon is in every thing like the Earth, you are oblig'd to believe that the Moon is inhabited. I acknowledge, said she, if you do that, I must yield; and your Looks are so assur'd, that you frighten me already: The two different Motions of the Earth, which wou'd never have enter'd into my Thoughts, make me very apprehensive of all you say. But is it possible that the Earth can be an enlighten'd Body, as the Moon is? For, to resemble it, it must be so. Alas, Madam, said I, to be enlightned, is not so great a matter as you imagine, and the Sun only is remarkable for that Quality: 'tis he alone that is enlightned of himself, by virtue of his particular Essence; but the other Planets shine only, as being enlightned by the Sun: The Sun communicates his Light to the Moon, which reflects it upon the Earth; as the Earth, without doubt, reflects it back again to the Moon, since the distance from the Moon to the Earth is the same as from the Earth to the Moon.</P018>

explanations: The French 'il vint chez elle du monde' (some people/company came to her place) implies a visit. The English 'there came Company to visit my Lady' makes the purpose of their coming explicit by adding 'to visit my Lady'.

The French 'Encore leur fut-on bien obligé' (Still, one was much obliged to them) subtly implies relief that the visit wasn't prolonged. The English 'we thought our selves happy that we were so easily rid of 'em then' makes this implied relief and a somewhat negative sentiment towards the visitors ('rid of 'em') much more explicit, altering the tone.

The French 'la Conversation ne manqua pas de tourner aussi-tost sur nos Sistêmes' (the conversation did not fail to turn immediately to our Systems) indicates a return to the topic. The English 'the Conversation began as it ended before' explicitly spells out the continuity and connection to the previous conversation, which was only implied in the source.

The French 'elle dédaigna d'en parler une seconde fois' (she disdained to speak of it a second time) uses the pronoun 'en' (of it/them). The English 'she wou'd not be at the pains to re-assume any thing of what had pass'd' explicitly clarifies that 'en' refers to the previous topics of conversation ('any thing of what had pass'd'), expanding the condensed French expression.

The French 'je me tiens toûjours en estat de me pouvoir ranger à leur opinion avec honneur, si elle avoit le dessus' (I always keep myself in a position to be able to rally to their opinion with honor, if it prevailed) describes a cautious, adaptable stance. The English 'I carry my self so trimmingly...' makes this stance explicit by using the contemporary political term 'trimmingly.' This term, loaded in the English socio-political context (referring to 'Trimmers'), re-writes the French by adding a specific cultural and political interpretation that was only generally implied by Fontenelle's phrasing.

The French specifies resemblance 'pour ce qui est d'estre habité' (for what concerns being inhabited). The English 'that it might resemble Paris in every thing else, and be inhabited as well as it' expands this by adding 'in every thing else,' making explicit a broader scope of resemblance before restating the main point of being inhabited.

The French 'Tout cela' (All that) is a general demonstrative pronoun referring to the preceding discourse. The English 'All these Arguments' makes explicit that 'cela' refers to the specific lines of reasoning or arguments previously presented.

The French 'Prenez garde, Madame' (Take care/Be careful, Madam) is a general warning. The English 'Have a care, Madam, ... what you say' makes explicit the specific object of the Marquise's caution, namely her words or assertions.

The French 'qu'il n'y aura pas moyen de s'en dispenser' (that there will be no way to avoid it/get out of it) states an impersonal necessity. The English 'if you do that, I must yield' makes the condition ('if you do that' – referring to the philosopher's potential proof) explicit and personalizes the consequence for the Marquise ('I must yield').

The French 'Les deux mouvemens de la Terre' (The two movements of the Earth) implies that these two movements are distinct. The English 'The two different Motions of the Earth' makes this quality of being 'different' explicit by adding the adjective.

The French 'me rendent timide sur tout le reste' (make me timid about all the rest) expresses a general timidity. The English 'make me very apprehensive of all you say' specifies that her apprehension is directed towards 'all you [the philosopher] say,' making the focus of her timidity more explicit in relation to the ongoing dialogue.

The French 'en vertu d'une nature particuliere qu'il a' (by virtue of a particular nature that it has) is translated as 'by virtue of his particular Essence.' The term 'Essence' is more specific and philosophically loaded than 'nature,' making explicit a potentially deeper or more technical meaning that was only one possible interpretation of Fontenelle's more general term, reflecting an elevation of scientific/philosophical register.

The French 'elle nous la renvoye' (it sends it back to us) uses the general verb 'renvoyer' (to send back) and the pronoun 'nous' (us). The English 'which reflects it upon the Earth' uses the more scientific term 'reflects' and explicitly identifies 'nous' as 'the Earth' within the astronomical context, clarifying both the action and the recipient.

The French 'il faut que la Terre renvoye aussi à la Lune la lumiere du Soleil' (the Earth must also send back the Sun's light to the Moon) uses 'il faut que' (it is necessary that/it must be that), implying strong certainty. The English 'as the Earth, without doubt, reflects it back again to the Moon' makes this certainty explicit with 'without doubt' and translates 'renvoye' (sends back) with the more scientific term 'reflects'.

chunks.source_manual: <P024>Mais, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, la Terre est-elle aussi propre que la Lune à renvoyer la lumiere au Soleil? Je vous vois toûjours pour la Lune, repris-je, un reste d'estime dont vous ne sçauriez vous défaire. La lumiere est composée de petites balles qui bondissent sur ce qui est solide <UP></UP>, & retournent d'un autre costé, au lieu qu'elles passent au travers de ce qui leur presente des ouvertures en ligne droite, comme l'air ou le verre. Ainsi ce qui fait que la Lune nous éclaire, c'est qu'elle est un Corps dur & solide, qui nous renvoye ces petites balles. Or je croy que vous ne contesterez pas à la Terre cette mesme dureté & cette mesme solidité. Admirez donc ce que c'est que d'estre posté avantageusement. Parce que la Lune est éloignée de nous, nous ne la voyons que comme un Corps lumineux, & nous ignorons que ce soit une grosse masse, toute semblable à la Terre. <IIM>Au contraire,</IIM> parce que la Terre a le malheur que nous la voyons de trop prés, elle ne nous paroist qu'une grosse masse, propre seulement à fournir de la pasture aux Animaux, & nous ne nous apercevons pas qu'elle est lumineuse, faute de nous pouvoir mettre à quelque distance d'elle. Cela va de la mesme maniere, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, que quand nous sommes frapez de l'éclat des Conditions élevées au-dessus des nostres, & que nous ne voyons pas qu'au fond elles se ressemblent toutes extremement.</P024> <P025>C'est la mesme chose, répondis-je. Nous voulons juger de tout, & nous sommes toûjours dans un mauvais point de veüe. Nous voulons juger de nous, nous en sommes trop près; nous voulons juger des autres, nous en sommes trop loin. Qui serait entre la Lune & la Terre, ce seroit la vraye place pour les bien voir. Il faudroit estre simplement Spectateur du Monde, & non pas Habitant. Je ne me consoleray jamais, dit-elle, de l'injustice que nous faisons à la Terre, & de la préoccupation trop favorable où nous sommes pour la Lune, si vous ne m'assurez que les Gens de la Lune ne connaissent pas mieux leurs avantages que nous connoissons les nostres, & qu'ils prennent nostre Terre pour un Astre, sans sçavoir que leur habitation en est un aussi. Pour cela, repris-je, je vous le garantis. Nous leur paroissons faire assez regulierement nos fonctions d'Astres. Il est vray qu'ils ne nous voyent pas décrire un Cercle autour d'eux, mais il n'importe, voicy ce que c'est. La moitié de la Lune qui se trouva tournée vers nous au commencement du Monde, y a toûjours esté tournée depuis; elle ne nous presente jamais que ces yeux, cette bouche, & le reste de ce visage que nostre imagination luy compose sur le fondement des tâches qu'elle nous montre. Si l'autre moitié opposée se presentoit à nous, d'autres tâches differemment arrangées, nous feroient sans doute imaginer quelque autre figure. Ce n'est pas que la Lune ne tourne sur elle-mesme, elle y tourne en autant de temps qu'autour de la Terre, c'est à dire, en un mois; mais lors qu'elle fait une partie de ce tremblement <RW></RW>, & de s'imaginer que nous avons dans le Ciel comme un mouvement de Pendule qui va & vient.</P025> <P026>Toutes ces Planetes, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, sont faites comme nous, qui rejettons toûjours sur les autres ce qui est en nous-mesmes. La Terre dit, Ce n'est pas moy qui tourne, c'est le Soleil. La Lune dit, Ce n'est pas moy qui tremble, c'est la Terre. Il y a bien de l'erreur par tout. Je ne vous conseille pas d'entreprendre d'y rien réformer, répondis-je; il vaut mieux que vous acheviez de vous convaincre de l'entiere ressemblance de la Terre & de la Lune. Representez-vous ces deux grandes Boules suspendües dans les Cieux. Vous sçavez que le Soleil éclaire toûjours une moitié des Corps qui sont ronds, & que l'autre moitié est dans l'ombre. Il y a donc toûjours une moitié, tant de la Terre que de la Lune, qui est éclairée du Soleil, c'est à dire, qui a le jour, & une autre moitié qui est dans la nuit. Remarquez d'ailleurs que comme une Balle a moins de force & de vistesse aprés qu'elle a esté donner contre une muraille qui l'a renvoyée d'un autre costé, de mesme la lumiere s'affoiblit lors qu'elle a esté réfléchie par quelque Corps. Cette lumiere blanchâtre qui nous vient de la Lune, est la lumiere mesme du Soleil, mais elle ne peut venir de la Lune à nous que par une réflexion. Elle a donc beaucoup perdu de la force & de la vivacité qu'elle avoit lors qu'elle estoit receüe directement sur la Lune, & cette lumiere éclatante que nous recevons directement du Soleil & que la Terre reflechit sur la Lune, ne doit plus estre qu'une lumiere blanchâtre quand elle y est arrivée. Ainsi ce qui nous paroit lumineux dans la Lune, & qui nous éclaire pendant nos nuits, ce sont des parties de la Lune qui ont le jour, & les parties de la Terre qui ont le jour, lors qu'elles sont tournées vers les parties de la Lune qui ont la nuit, les éclairent aussi. Tout dépend de la maniere dont la Lune & la Terre se regardent. Dans les premiers jours du mois que l'on ne voit pas la Lune, c'est qu'elle est entre le Soleil & nous, & qu'elle marche de jour avec le Soleil. Il faut necessairement que toute sa moitié qui a le jour, soit tournée vers le Soleil, & que toute sa moitié qui a la nuit, soit tournée vers nous. Nous n'avons garde de voir cette moitié qui n'a aucune lumiere pour se faire voir. Mais cette moitié de la Lune qui a la nuit, estant tournée vers la moitié de la Terre qui a le jour, nous voit sans estre veüe, & nous voit sous la même figure que nous voyons la Pleine Lune. C'est alors pour les Gens de la Lune Pleine Terre, s'il est permis de parler ainsi. Ensuite la Lune qui avance sur son Cercle d'un mois, se dégage de dessous le Soleil, & commence à tourner vers nous un petit coin de sa moitié éclairée, & voila le Croissant. Alors aussi les parties de la Lune qui ont la nuit, commencent à ne plus voir toute la moitié de la Terre qui a le jour, & nous sommes en Decours pour elles.</P026>
chunks.target_manual: <P019>But, said the Marquiese, is the Earth as proper for reflecting the Light of the Sun, as the Moon? You are always for the Moon, said I, and you cannot rid your self of those Remains of Kindness you have for her. Light is compos'd for little Balls, which rebound upon any solid Body, <UP>which is opaque, or obscure,</UP> and are sent back another way; whereas they pass through any thing that offers them an Opening, or Passage, in a streight Line; which is Diaphanus, or clear; such as Air and Glass: So that the Moon enlightens us, because she is an Opaque, solid Body, which retorts these little Balls upon us; and I believe you will not dispute the same Solidity to the Earth. Admire then, Madam, how advantageous it is, to be well posted; so that the Moon being at a great distance from us, we see it as an enlightned Body only, but are ignorant that 'tis a gross, solid Mass, very much like the Earth: On the other hand, the Earth having the ill luck to be seen by us too near, we consider it only as a great massy Body, fit only for the producing of Food for living Creatures. 'Tis just, said the Marquiese, as when we are struck and surpriz'd with the Splendour of Quality above our own; we do not perceive, that in the main, there's no difference between them and us. 'Tis just so, said I; and we will needs be judging of every thing; but we have the mis-fortune, still to be plac'd in a false Light: Wou'd we judge of our selves, we are too near; if of others, we are too far off: Cou'd one be plac'd between the Moon and the Earth, that wou'd be a true Station to consider both well: To this End, we ought only to be Spectators of the World, and not Inhabitants. I shall never be satisfy'd, said the Marquiese, with the Injury we do the Earth, in being too favourably engag'd for the Inhabitants of the Moon, unless you can assure me, that they are as ignorant of their Advantages, as we are of ours; and that they take our Earth for a Star, without knowing that the Globe they inhabit is one also. Be assur'd of that, Madam, said I, that the Earth appears to them to perform all the Functions of a Star: 'Tis true, they do not see the Earth describe a Circle round 'em, but that's all one; I'll explain to you what it is: That side of the Moon which was turn'd towards the Earth at the beginning of the World, has continu'd towards the Earth ever since; which still represents to us these same Eyes, Nose and Mouth, which our Imaginations fansie we see compos'd of these Spots, Lights and Shadows, which are the Surface of the Moon: Cou'd we see the other half of the Moon, 'tis possible our Fancy wou'd represent to us some other Figure. This does not argue, but the Moon turns however upon her own Axis, and takes as much time to perform that Revolution, as she does to go round the Earth in a Month. But then, when the Moon performs a part of her Revolutions on her own Axis, and that she ought to hide from us (for Example) one Cheek of this imaginary Face, and appear to us in another Position, she does at the same time perform as much of the Circle she describes in turning round the Earth; and tho' she is in a new Point of Sight or Opposition as to us, yet she represents to us still the same Cheek: So that the Moon, in regard to the Sun, and the other Planets, turns upon her own Axis; but does not so as to the Earth.</P019> <P020>The Inhabitants of the Moon see all the other Planets rise and set in the space of fifteen Days, but they see our Earth always hanging in the same Point of the Heavens. This seeming Immovability does not very well agree with a Body that ought to pass for a Planet; but the truth is, the Earth is not in such perfection: Besides, the Moon has a certain trembling Quality, which does sometimes hide a little of her imaginary Face, and at other times shews a little of her opposite Side; and no doubt but the Inhabitants of the Moon attribute this shaking to the Earth, and believe we make a certain swinging in the Heavens, like the Pendulum of a Clock. All these Planets, said the Marquiese, are like us Mortals, who always cast our own Faults upon others: Says the Earth, It is not I that turn round, 'tis the Sun: Says the Moon, It is not I that tremble, 'tis the Earth: There are Errors and Mistakes every where. I wou'd not advise you, said I, to undertake to reform any of 'em; 'tis better that I make an end in convincing you, that the Moon is in all things like the Earth. Represent to your self these two great Globes, hanging in the Heavens; you know that the Sun does always enlighten one half of any Globe, and the other half is in the Shadow; there is therefore always one half of both Moon and Earth that is enlightned, or half Day, and the other half is still in the Darkness of Night. Be pleas'd, besides, to consider that a Ball has less force and swiftness after it re- bounds from a Wall, against which it was thrown, than it had before it touch'd the Wall, which sends it another way; so Light is not so strong, after 'tis reflected by <IIM>any solid Body</IIM>: This pale Light which comes to us from the Moon, is the Light of the Sun it self, but we have it only by Reflection from the Moon, and has lost a great deal of that Strength and Vivacity which it had when 'twas receiv'd by the Moon, directly from the Sun; and that bright and dazling Light which we receive from the Sun, must in the same manner appear to the Inhabitants of the Moon, after 'tis reflected by the Earth, on the Moon: So that the Surface of the Moon, which we see enlightned, and which shines upon us in the Night, is that half of the Moon that enjoys the Day, as that half of the Globe of the Earth which is enlightned by the Sun, when 'tis turn'd towards the darkened half of the Globe of the Moon, does give Light to the Inhabitants there, during their Nights. All depends upon the different Opposition and Aspects between the Moon and the Earth: The first and second Day of the Moon, we do not see her, because she is betwixt the Sun and us, and moves with the Sun by our Day; it necessarily follows, that the half of the Moon which is enlightned, is turn'd towards the Sun, and the obscure part towards the Earth; 'tis no wonder then, that we cannot see that half which is dark; but that same half of the Moon which is in Darkness, being turn'd towards the enlightned half of the Earth, the Inhabitants see us, without being seen, and the Earth appears to them, as their Full-Moon does to us; and so, if one may use the Expression, 'tis with them Full-Earth. After this, the Moon going on in her Monthly Circle, dis-engages her self from the Sun, and begins to turn towards us a part of her enlightned half, which is the Crescent; at the very same time, the darkned half of the Moon loses some share of the enlightned part of the Earth, and then <NCE>the Earth is in the Wain,</NCE> as to its Inhabitants.</P020>

The source describes light passing through 'ce qui leur presente des ouvertures en ligne droite' (that which presents them openings in a straight line). The target translates this and adds 'which is Diaphanus, or clear,' explicitly stating the physical property (transparency) of such materials using both a scientific term ('Diaphanus') and a common one ('clear').

The source's 'un Corps dur & solide' (a hard and solid Body) is translated as 'an Opaque, solid Body.' The addition of 'Opaque' makes explicit a key property of the Moon for it to reflect light, which was implied by the context but not stated in this specific phrase.

When referring to the Moon, the source's 'une grosse masse' (a big mass) is rendered as 'a gross, solid Mass.' The addition of 'solid' explicitly reiterates a physical property of the Moon crucial to the discussion of light reflection, making the description more scientifically precise.

The source states 'qu'au fond elles se ressemblent toutes extremement' (that at the bottom they all resemble each other extremely). The target, 'that in the main, there's no difference between them and us,' makes explicit the *implication* of this extreme resemblance, rephrasing it as a statement of fundamental equality or lack of difference.

The source states a conditional necessity: 'Il faudroit estre simplement Spectateur du Monde, & non pas Habitant.' (One would need to be simply Spectator of the World, and not an Inhabitant.). The target prefaces this with 'To this End,' explicitly stating the purpose (achieving a true perspective, as discussed prior) for which one should adopt this detached viewpoint.

The source's 'la préoccupation trop favorable où nous sommes pour la Lune' (the too favorable preoccupation we have for the Moon) is rendered as 'being too favourably engag'd for the Inhabitants of the Moon.' This explicitly clarifies that the favorable bias is directed towards the Moon's (hypothetical) inhabitants, not just the celestial body itself.

The source refers to the Moon-dwellers' home as 'leur habitation' (their dwelling/habitation). The target translates this as 'the Globe they inhabit,' making the astronomical nature of their dwelling explicit and specific, aligning with the scientific popularization intent of the work.

The target expands this significantly to 'compos'd of these Spots, Lights and Shadows, which are the Surface of the Moon:', adding detail ('Lights and Shadows') to what 'tâches' might entail and explicitly identifying these features as constituting 'the Surface of the Moon'.

The source states the Moon's synchronous rotation: 'elle y tourne en autant de temps qu'autour de la Terre, c'est à dire, en un mois' (it turns on itself in as much time as around the Earth, that is to say, in a month). The target translates this and then adds a lengthy, detailed explanation ('But then, when the Moon performs... but does not so as to the Earth.') of the mechanics by which this synchronous rotation results in the same lunar face always being presented to Earth. This extensive addition makes the causal link and process explicit.

The source refers to the Moon's libration as 'ce tremblement' (this trembling). The target expands this to 'a certain trembling Quality, which does sometimes hide a little of her imaginary Face, and at other times shews a little of her opposite Side,' explicitly describing the visual effects of this phenomenon.

chunks.source_manual: <P027>Il n'en faut pas davantage, dit brusquement la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, je sçauray tout le reste quand il me plaira, je n'ai qu'à y penser un moment, & qu'à promener la Lune sur son Cercle d'un mois. Je vois en gennral que dans la Lune ils ont un mois à rebours du nostre, & je gage que quand nous avons pleine Lune, c'est que toute la moitié lumineuse de la Lune est tournée vers toute la moitié obscure de la Terre; qu'alors ils ne nous voyent point du tout, & qu'ils content Nouvelle Terre. Je ne voudrois pas qu'il me fust reproché de m'estre fait expliquer tout au long une chose si aisée. Mais les Eclipses comment vont-elles? Il ne tient qu'à vous de le deviner, répondis-je. Quand la Lune est Nouvelle, qu'elle est entre le Soleil & nous, & que toute sa moitié obscure est tournée vers nous qui avons le jour, vous voyez bien que l'ombre de cette moitié obscure se jette vers nous. Si la Lune est justement sous le Soleil, cette ombre nous le cache, & en mesme temps noircit une partie de cette moitié lumineuse de la Terre qui estoit vûë par la moitié obscure de la Lune. Voila donc une Eclipse de Soleil pour nous pendant nostre jour, & une Eclipse de Terre pour la Lune pendant sa nuit. Lors que la Lune est pleine, la Terre est entre elle & le Soleil, & toute la moitié obscure de la Terre est tournée vers toute la moitié lumineuse de la Lune. L'ombre de la Terre se jette donc vers la Lune; si elle tombe sur le Corps de la Lune, elle noircit cette moitié lumineuse que nous voyons, & à cette moitié lumineuse qui avoit le jour, elle luy dérobe le Soleil. Voila donc une Eclipse de Lune pour nous pendant nostre nuit, & une Eclipse de Soleil pour la Lune pendant le jour dont elle joüissoit. Ce qui fait qu'il n'arrive pas des Eclipses toutes les fois que la Lune est entre le Soleil & la Terre, ou la Terre entre le Soleil & la Lune, c'est que souvent ces trois Corps ne sont pas tres exactement rangez en ligne droite, & que par consequent celuy qui devroit faire l'Eclipse, jette son ombre un peu à costé de celuy qui en devroit estre couvert.</P027>
chunks.target_manual: <P021>Say no more, said the Marquiese, briskly, I shall know all the rest when I please; I need only think a little, and follow the Moon in her Monthly Circle: I see in general, that the Inhabitants of the Moon have their Month, the exact Reverse of ours; and I am perswaded, when 'tis Full-Moon, the enlightned half of it is turn'd towards the obscure part of the Earth, and then they do not see us, but a certain new Earth. I wou'd not have any Body reproach me with the want of so much Sence, as that you need explain so easie a thing to me. But as to the Eclipses, What is the Cause of them? If you do not understand that, said I, 'tis your own fault. When 'tis New Moon, and that she is between the Sun and the Earth, and that all her obscure half is turn'd towards us, who then enjoy the Day, you may see easily, that the Shadow of this darkned half is cast upon the Earth; if the Moon be directly under the Sun, this Shadow hides the Sun from us, and at the same time darkens a part of the enlightened half of the Earth, which was seen by the Inhabitants of the obscure half of the Moon: And this is an Eclipse of the Sun to us, in our Day; and an Eclipse of the Earth to those in the Moon, in their Night. When the Moon is at the Full, the Earth is betwixt her and the Sun, and all the obscure part of the Earth is turn'd towards the enlightned half of the Moon, the Shadow of the Earth is then cast upon the Moon; and if it falls directly on her Surface, it obscures the enlightned half which we see, and hides the Sun from that enlightned part of the Moon that enjoy'd the Day: This is an Eclipse of the Moon to us, during our Night; and an Eclipse of the Sun to them, during their Day. By this Reason, it falls out, that there are not always Eclipses when the Moon interposes between the Sun and the Earth, or the Earth is interjected between the Sun and the Moon; because these three Bodies are not opposite one to another, in a streight Line; and by consequence, that of the three, which ought to make the Eclipse, casts its shadow a little to one side of that which shou'd be eclips'd.</P021>

explanations: The French pronoun 'ils' (they), while contextually referring to hypothetical beings on the Moon, is made explicit in the translation as 'the Inhabitants of the Moon'. This removes any potential ambiguity and directly names the subjects experiencing the described phenomena.

The source text expresses the Marquise's desire not to be reproached for having a simple thing explained. The translation expands this by adding 'with the want of so much Sence,' explicitly stating the implied reason for the potential reproach – a perceived lack of intelligence – which is only hinted at in the original.

The French 'comment vont-elles?' (literally 'how do they go?') is a general question about the nature or workings of eclipses. The translation 'What is the Cause of them?' explicitates the inquiry by narrowing its focus to the specific causal mechanism of eclipses, which is implied as the core of the Marquise's curiosity but not stated so directly.

The French 'Il ne tient qu'à vous de le deviner' (It's up to you to guess it/You only have to guess it) implies the Marquise is capable of deducing the answer. The translation 'If you do not understand that, said I, 'tis your own fault' makes this implication explicit and intensifies it by adding a conditional ('If you do not understand that') and attributing blame ('tis your own fault') if she fails, thus re-writing the philosopher’s encouraging remark into a more direct and somewhat judgmental statement.

The French 'vers nous' (towards us) refers to the philosopher and the Marquise. The translation 'upon the Earth' explicitates their physical location, clarifying that the Moon's shadow is cast upon the planet they inhabit, making the reference more concrete.

The French 'par la moitié obscure de la Lune' (by the obscure half of the Moon) implies observation or perception from that part of the Moon. The translation 'by the Inhabitants of the obscure half of the Moon' explicitly identifies the agents of this perception as hypothetical inhabitants, clarifying who is seeing the Earth.

The French 'pour la Lune' (for the Moon) indicates that the subsequent description of an eclipse of the Earth is from the Moon's perspective. The translation 'to those in the Moon' explicitly clarifies that this experience pertains to hypothetical observers or inhabitants situated on the Moon.

The French 'à cette moitié lumineuse qui avoit le jour' (to this luminous half which had the day) refers contextually to the Moon's illuminated side. The translation 'from that enlightned part of the Moon that enjoy'd the Day' explicitly adds 'of the Moon,' specifying which celestial body's enlightened part is being discussed, a detail understood from context in the source but not overtly stated in the phrase itself.

Similar to a previous instance, the French 'pour la Lune' (for the Moon) indicates the perspective from which an eclipse of the Sun (caused by the Earth) is experienced. The translation 'to them' explicitly refers to the previously established 'Inhabitants of the Moon', making the experiencing subjects (hypothetical beings) explicit where the source uses the location as a proxy for its inhabitants.

The French 'ces trois Corps ne sont pas tres exactement rangez en ligne droite' (these three bodies are not very exactly arranged in a straight line) describes the general geometric condition for an eclipse not occurring. The translation 'these three Bodies are not opposite one to another, in a streight Line' explicitates the specific nature of the alignment required for an eclipse (syzygy, where one body is directly between the other two, making them appear 'opposite' from certain perspectives) by adding 'opposite one to another,' thereby clarifying the particular type of linear arrangement that is relevant.

chunks.source_manual: <P028>Je suis fort étonnée, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, qu'il y ait si peu de mystere aux Eclipses, & que tout le monde n'en devine pas la cause. Ah! vraiment, répondis-je, il y a bien des Peuples qui de la maniere dont ils s'y prennent, ne la devineroient encore de long-temps. Dans toutes les Indes Orientales on croit que quand le Soleil & la Lune s'éclipsent, c'est qu'un certain Démon qui a les Griffes fort noires, les étend sur ces Astres dont il veut se saisir; & vous voyez pendant ces temps-là les Rivieres couvertes de Testes d'Indiens qui se sont mis dans l'eau jusqu'au cou, parce que c'est une situation tres-devote, selon eux, & tres-propre à obtenir du Soleil & de la Lune qu'ils se défendent bien contre le Démon. En Amerique, on estoit persuadé que le Soleil & la Lune estoient fâchéz quand ils s'éclipsoient, & Dieu sçait ce qu'on ne faisoit pas pour se raccommoder avec eux. Mais les Grecs qui estoient si raffinez, n'ont-ils pas creu long-temps que la Lune étoit ensorcelée, & que des Magiciennes la faisoient descendre du Ciel pour jeter sur les Herbes une certaine écume malfaisante? Mais nous, n'eûmes-nous pas belle peur il n'y guere plus de trente ans, à une certaine Eclipse de Soleil, qui arriva? Une infinité de Gens ne se tinrent-ils pas enfermez dans des caves, & <IIM>les Philosophes</IIM> <NCE></NCE> qui écrivirent pour nous rassurer,n'écrivirent-ils pas en vain?</P028> <P029>En verité, reprit-elle, tout cela est trop honteux pour les hommes, il devroit y avoir un Arrest du Genre humain qui défendît qu'on parlast jamais d'Eclipse, de peur que l'on ne conserve la memoyre des sotises qui ont esté faites ou dites sur ce Chapitre-là. Il faudrait donc, repliquay-je, que le mesme Arrest abolist la memoire de toutes choses, & défendist qu'on parlast jamais de rien, car je ne sçache rien au monde qui ne soit le monument de quelque sotise des hommes.</P029> <P030>Dites-moy, je vous prie, une chose, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>. Ont-ils autant de peur des Eclipses dans la Lune, que nous en avons ici? Il me paroistroit tout-à-fait burlesque, que les Indiens de ce Pays-là se missent à l'eau comme les nostres; que les Ameriquains creussent nostre Terre fâchée contre eux; que les Grecs s'imaginassent que nous fussions ensorcelez; que nous allassions gâter leurs Herbes, & qu'enfin nous leur rendissions la consternation qu'ils causent icy-bas. Je n'en doute nullement, répondis-je. Je voudrois bien sçavoir pourquoy Messieurs de la Lune auroient l'esprit plus fort que nous. De quel droit nous feront-ils peur sans que nous leur en fassions? Je croirois mesme, ajoûtai-je en riant, que comme un nombre prodigieux d'hommes ont esté assez fous, & le sont encore assez pour adorer la Lune, il y a des Gens dans la Lune qui adorent aussi la Terre, & que nous sommes à genoux les uns devant les autres. Aprés cela, dit-elle, <IIM>nous pouvons bien prétendre</IIM> à envoyer des influences à la Lune, & à donner des crises à ses Malades, mais comme il ne faut qu'un peu d'esprit & d'habileté dans les Gens de ce Pays-là, pour détruire tous ces honneurs dont nous nous flattons, j'avoüe que je crains toûjours que nous n'ayons quelque desavantage.</P030> <P031>Ne craignez rien, répondis-je, il n'y a pas d'apparence que nous soyons la seule sotte espece de l'Univers. L'ignorance est quelque chose de bien propre à estre generalement répanduë, & quoy que je ne fasse que deviner celle des Gens de la Lune, je n'en doute non plus que des Nouvelles les plus seures qui nous viennent de là.</P031>
chunks.target_manual: <P022>I am extreamly surpriz'd, said the Marquiese, that (since there is so little of Mystery or Difficulty in Eclipses) every body does not find out the Cause of 'em. Do not wonder at that, said I, Madam; there are many Nations in the World, that, as they go to work, will not find it out for Ages to come; for all over the East-India's, the Inhabitants believe, that when the Sun or Moon is eclips'd, certain Demons, or Spirits, who have very black Claws, do stretch them forth upon these two Luminaries, which he endeavours to sieze: and during the time of the Eclipse, you may see all the Rivers cover'd with Heads of Indians; for they go into the Water, up to the Neck, thinking that most devout posture for obtaining from the Sun and Moon, a defence against that Demon. In America, the People were perswaded, that the Sun and Moon were angry with 'em when they were eclips'd; and God knows what pains they are at, to make their Peace with 'em. But the Grecians, who were so polite a People, Did not they believe for a long time, that the Moon was bewitch'd, and that the Magician made her come down, to throw a certain poisonous Scum or Dew upon the Herbs and Grass? And even we our selves, Were we not frightned out of our Wits at an Eclipse of the Sun, that happen'd about thirty Years since? Did not a great many People shut themselves up in Vaults and Cellars? And did not the <IIM>learned Men</IIM> write in vain, to assure us, there was no danger? Certainly, said the Marquiese, that's very disgraceful to Mankind; and I think there ought to be a Law made by universal Consent, never to speak of Eclipse hereafter, lest the memory of such Folly shou'd be preserv'd to Posterity. Pray, Madam, said I, let there be another Law made, for abolishing the Memory of all things past; for I know of nothing, that is not a Monument of the Folly of Mankind. Pray, tell me, said the Marquiese; Are the Inhabitants of the Moon as much afraid of Eclipses as we are? It seems to me very ridiculous, that some of 'em shou'd run into the Water up to the Neck; that others shou'd think our Earth angry with 'em; some, that our Earth shou'd be bewitch'd, and that we are coming to spoil their Grass. Without all doubt, said I, Madam: Why shou'd the Inhabitants of the Moon have more Sense than we? And what Right have they to frighten us, more than we have to frighten them? Nay, more; I am apt to believe, that as there has been, and still are, many Inhabitants in our Globe, who are such Fools to adore the Moon; there are also Inhabitants in the Moon, foolish enough to adore our Earth. At that rate, said the Marquiese, <IIM>we may very well pretend</IIM> to send Influences to the Moon, and to give a Judgment on their Distempers. But since there is only requisite, a little more Wit and Ingenuity in the Inhabitants of that Country, to blast the Honour we flatter our selves with, I confess, I am still apprehensive, they may have some Advantage over us. Do not fear, said I; there is no likelihood that we are the only Fools of the Universe. Ignorance is naturally a very general Talent; and though I do but guess at that of the Inhabitants of the Moon, yet I no more doubt of it, than I do of the most certain News we have from thence.</P022>

certain Demons, or Spirits

explanations: The French 'mystere' implies something hidden or hard to understand. The translator makes this explicit by adding 'or Difficulty,' directly stating the challenging aspect of understanding eclipses, which was only implied by 'mystere.'

The French 'un certain Démon' (a certain Demon) is singular. The translation 'certain Demons, or Spirits' not only pluralizes 'Demon' but also adds 'or Spirits.' This addition explicates the nature of the 'Démon' by offering an alternative or clarifying term ('Spirits') that might be more familiar to the English reader of the time, thereby broadening the implied category of the malevolent entity.

The French 'situation' (situation, circumstance) in 'c'est une situation tres-devote' is general. The translator renders this as 'posture' in 'thinking that most devout posture,' making explicit the physical disposition of the Indians (in water up to the neck) implied by the context, thus adding a concrete visual detail not explicitly stated in 'situation.'

The French 'une certaine écume malfaisante' translates to 'a certain harmful scum/foam.' The translator specifies 'malfaisante' (harmful) as 'poisonous,' making the type of harm explicit. More significantly, 'or Dew' is added, explicating a possible alternative form or appearance of the 'écume,' thereby expanding the original description beyond what was literally stated.

The French 'belle peur' (literally 'beautiful fear') signifies a strong or intense fear. The English idiom 'frightned out of our Wits' makes the *degree* of this fear explicit by spelling out the intensity implied by 'belle.'

In Fontenelle's era, 'Philosophes' often referred broadly to scholars or 'natural philosophers.' The translation to 'the learned Men' explicates this broader, less specialized meaning, clarifying for the contemporary English reader that it refers to knowledgeable individuals in general, not strictly philosophers in the modern academic sense.

The French 'pour nous rassurer' (to reassure us) implies the content of the reassurance. The translation 'to assure us, there was no danger' makes this implicit content explicit by stating precisely what the reassurance was about (i.e., the absence of danger from the eclipse).

The French 'un Arrest du Genre humain' translates to 'a Decree of Mankind.' The translator explicates the nature or basis of such a decree by adding 'made by universal Consent,' spelling out the implied mechanism or legitimizing source of this 'Arrest' that would bind all of humankind.

The French 'sur ce Chapitre-là' means 'on that topic/subject' (referring to the follies about eclipses). The translation 'lest the memory of such Folly shou'd be preserv'd to Posterity' shifts the focus. Instead of directly explicating 'on that topic,' it explicates an implied consequence by specifying *to whom* ('to Posterity') the memory would be preserved, an aspect not explicit in the source.

The French 'la memoire de toutes choses' (the memory of all things) is general. The addition of 'past' in 'the Memory of all things past' makes explicit the temporal aspect that memory inherently refers to historical or concluded events, a nuance implied but not overtly stated in the original.

The French 'Messieurs de la Lune' (Gentlemen of the Moon) uses a specific, somewhat formal and personifying term. 'The Inhabitants of the Moon' is more general and neutral. This translation explicates that the reference is to the general populace of the Moon, removing the potential social restriction or figurative nuance of 'Messieurs' for a more direct demographic term.

The French 'un nombre prodigieux d'hommes' (a prodigious number of men/people) is general as to location. The translation 'many Inhabitants in our Globe' makes explicit their location ('in our Globe'), which, while contextually understood in the source (as they adore the Moon from Earth), is spelled out in the target text.

The French 'donner des crises à ses Malades' (to give crises to its sick people) is ambiguous; 'crises' could imply causing critical turns. The translation 'to give a Judgment on their Distempers' explicates this by interpreting 'crises' in the context of astrological influence as making prognoses or judgments about illnesses ('Distempers'), rather than directly causing medical crises. This clarifies the intended meaning of influencing from afar.

The French 'quelque chose de bien propre à estre generalement répanduë' (something quite apt/suited to be generally widespread) implies an inherent tendency. The English 'naturally a very general Talent' uses 'naturally' to make this inherent quality explicit. While 'Talent' is a re-interpretation of 'quelque chose,' 'naturally' directly explicates the sense of inherent suitability or propensity conveyed by 'bien propre à.'

chunks.source_manual: <P032>Et quelles sont ces Nouvelles seures? interrompit-elle. Ce sont celles, répondis- je, qui nous en sont apportées par ces Sçavans qui y voyagent tous les jours avec des Lunettes de longue veuë. Ils vous diront qu'ils y ont découvert des Terres, des Mers, des Lacs, de tres-hautes Montagnes, des Abismes tres-profonds.</P032>
chunks.target_manual: <P023>And what, pray, are these certain News you have from thence, interrupted she? They are, said I, Madam, such as are brought us every Day by the Learned, who travel daily thither by the help of long Telescopes: They tell us, they have discover'd vast Countries, Seas, Lakes, high Mountains, and deep Valleys.</P023>
target_segments: these certain News you have from thence
said I, Madam
long Telescopes
vast Countries
explanations: The French "ces Nouvelles seures?" (these certain News?) in the Marquise's question refers to news about the Moon, implied by the conversational context. The English translation "these certain News you have from thence" makes explicit the Marquise's assumption that the philosopher possesses this news ("you have") and its specific origin ("from thence," i.e., the Moon), details that were only implicitly understood in the French.

The French "répondis- je" (replied I) is a concise dialogue tag. The English translation "said I, Madam" incorporates the formal address "Madam." This addition explicitly highlights the social decorum and the respectful relationship between the philosopher and the Marquise, a nuance implied by their societal roles and the overall polite tenor of the original dialogue but not specifically verbalized in this French phrase.

The French "Lunettes de longue veuë" (literally "glasses of long sight") is a descriptive term for early telescopes. The English translation "long Telescopes" employs the more specific, established technical term "Telescopes." This acts as an explicitation by directly naming the instrument, moving from a functional description to a precise identification, thereby making the object's identity as a telescope more explicit to the English reader of the era.

The French "des Terres" (lands) is a general term. The English translation "vast Countries" introduces two explicitations: "vast" adds a qualitative descriptor of size, implying large expanses which might be assumed for newly discovered celestial 'lands' but is unstated in the French. Secondly, "Countries" offers a more specific interpretation of "Terres" than the general "lands," suggesting distinct or delineated regions, thus providing a more concrete and perhaps culturally relatable image.

chunks.source_manual: <P033>Vous me surprenez, reprit-elle. Je conçois bien qu'on peut découvrir sur la Lune des Montagnes & des Abismes, cela se reconnoist apparemment à des inégalitez remarquables; mais comment distinguer des Terres & des Mers? On les distingue, répondis- je, parce que les Eaux, qui laissent passer au travers d'elles-mesmes une partie de la lumiere, & qui en renvoyent moins, paroissent de loin comme des taches obscures, & que les Terres qui par leur solidité la renvoyent toute, sont des endroits plus brillants. On reconnoist si bien toutes ces diferentes parties, qu'on leur a donné des noms, & ce sont presque tous noms de <RW>Sçavans</RW>. Un endroit s'appelle Copernic, un autre Archimede; un autre Galilée; il y a une Mer Caspienne, le Monts Porphirites, le Lac Noir; enfin la Description de la Lune est si exacte, qu'un Sçavant qui s'y trouveroit presentement, ne s'y égareroit non plus que je ferois dans <NCE>Paris</NCE>.</P033>
chunks.target_manual: <P024>You surprize me, said the Marquiese: I know very well, that Mountains and Valleys may be discover'd in the Moon, by the remarkable Inequality we see in its Surface; But how do they distinguish Countries and Seas? Very easily, said I; because the Water permits a part of the Light to pass through it, and reflects less, and appears, at a great distance, to be obscure Spots; and that the Earth, which is solid, reflects the whole Light, and therefore must appear the brightest part of the Globe of the Moon. These different parts are all so well known, that they have given them all Names of learned Men: One place is call'd Copernicus; another, Archimedes; and a third, Galileus: There are too a Caspian-Sea, Porphory-Hills, and the Black Lake. In short, they have fram'd so exact a Description of the Moon, that a learned Man, if he were there, wou'd be in no more danger of losing his Way, than I wou'd be, if I were at Paris.</P024>
