explanations: The translator adds 'occasion'd by a mighty Tempest,' making explicit an implied cause (a storm) for the 'grand naufrage' (great shipwreck), thus adding clarifying detail.
The French 'icy' (here) is translated as 'upon our World.' This explicitly specifies the location as Earth, clarifying information that was contextually implied, especially in contrast to the Moon.

The French 'les figures' (forms/appearances) is expanded to 'Shape and Figure.' This doublet clarifies that 'figures' refers to physical form, making the meaning more explicit and less ambiguous than the singular 'figures' might be in English.
The addition of 'Madam' makes the implied formality and social hierarchy of addressing the Marquise (inherent in 'vous') more explicit according to English social conventions of the period.

The French 'bien malade' (very ill) is translated as 'very weak and feeble.' This expansion specifies the likely symptoms or nature of the illness implied by being at high altitude, adding clarifying detail.

The French 'ceux-la mesme' (even those ones) is expanded to 'even those who are skilful in that Art.' The phrase 'who are skilful in that Art' explicitly spells out the implied characteristic (skill in diving) of the individuals being referred to, which was alluded to by 'sçachent plonger' (know how to dive).

The French focuses on the outcome ('des plongeons de tres-peu de durée' - very short dives). The English translation explicitates the implied cause by detailing the 'great difficulty to penetrate the grossness of the Air which we breath,' thereby explaining why the dives would be short.

The French 'barrieres naturelles' (natural barriers) is rendered as 'Nature has set many Bars and Fences.' This makes an implied agent ('Nature') explicit ('Nature has set') and uses the more concrete 'Bars and Fences' to clarify the abstract 'natural barriers.'

The impersonal French 'on y voye' (one sees there) is made specific by 'the Inhabitants of the Moon must see.' The translator explicitly identifies the viewers (lunar inhabitants), who were only implied by the context of discussing the Moon.

The French 'Lunette naturelle' (natural lens/telescope) is translated as 'natural Perspective-Glass.' 'Perspective-Glass' was a more specific contemporary term for an optical instrument like a telescope, thus making the scientific analogy of the air as a viewing device more explicit.

The French 'Quelques Modernes' (Some Moderns/modern thinkers) is translated as 'Some of late.' The addition 'of late' explicitly clarifies the temporal relationship of these 'Moderns' as being recent to Fontenelle's time, information implied by 'Modernes'.

Instead of simply repeating 'blue' (from the French 'il paroist bleu' - it appears blue), the translation 'the Heavens appear of that Colour' makes the anaphoric reference to the previously stated color ('blew') more explicit.

The French 'prendre autant de celle qui leur est naturelle' (take/receive as much of their natural color) is translated as 'lose as much of their own natural Colour.' This translation makes explicit the implied consequence: if light is tinged by the air's color, it inherently loses some of its original color. The English version spells out this resulting loss.

The addition of 'all' before 'our Air' in the English translation of 'nostre Air n'est non plus qu'un gros broüillard' explicitly extends the characteristic of being a 'thick Fog' to the entirety of Earth's atmosphere being discussed, clarifying an implied scope.

The translator adds 'to us' at the end of the clause translating 'qui nous doit alterer la vraye couleur...'. While the French 'nous doit alterer' (must alter for/to us) implies the observer, the explicit 'to us' clarifies for whom the colors are perceived as altered.

The translator adds 'and Perfection' to 'Purity' in translating 'dans toute leur pureté, & telles qu'elles sont'. While the French 'pureté' (purity) in this context implies an ideal, unaltered state of light and colors, 'Perfection' is an explicit addition that expands on and clarifies this implied quality.

The French 'ou il est teint en luy-mesme d'une autre couleur' (or it is itself tinged with another color) is translated as 'or is, of it self, of an indifferent Colour.' In 17th-century English, 'indifferent colour' often meant a neutral or unremarkable color, thereby specifying a type of 'other colour' and making the potential nature of the Moon's air more explicit.

The translator adds 'in appearance' to the translation of 'qui cause une autre alteration aux couleurs des Corps celestes'. This explicitly clarifies that the 'alteration' to the colors of celestial bodies is a perceptual effect due to the intervening lunar atmosphere, rather than an intrinsic change in the objects themselves, a distinction implied but not stated in the original.

The French 'Enfin, à l'égard des Gens de la Lune, cette Lunette au travers de laquelle on voit tout, est changée.' (Finally, regarding the people of the Moon, this lens...is changed) is rephrased as 'In short, if there be Inhabitants in the Moon, they see all things chang'd, through their Perspective-glasses, which is their Air.' This makes explicit the condition of their existence ('if there be Inhabitants'), the direct perceptual consequence for them ('they see all things chang'd'), and explicitly identifies their 'Perspective-glasses' as 'their Air,' spelling out connections and consequences that were more implicit in the French.

chunks.source_manual: <P045>Cela me fait préférer nostre sejour à celuy de la Lune, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, je ne saurois croire que l'assortiment des couleurs celestes y soit aussi beau qu'il l'est icy. Mettons, si vous voulez, un Ciel rouge, & des Etoiles vertes, l'effet n'est pas si agreable que des Etoiles couleur d'or sur du bleu. On diroit à vous entendre, <UP></UP>, repris-je, que vous assortiriez un habit, ou un meuble; mais, croyez-moy, la Nature a bien de l'esprit; laissez-luy le soin d'inventer un assortiment de couleurs pour la Lune, & je vous garantis qu'il sera bien entendu. Elle n'aura pas manqué de varier le Spectacle de l'Univers à chaque point de veüe diferent <UP></UP>, & de le varier d'une maniere toûjours agreable.</P045> <P046>Je reconnois son adresse, interrompit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, elle s'est épargné la peine de changer les objets pour chaque point de veüe, elle n'a changé que les Lunettes, & elle a l'honneur de cette grande diversité, sans en avoir fait la dépense. Avec un air bleu, elle nous donne un Ciel bleu, & peut-estre avec un Air rouge, elle donne un Ciel rouge aux Habitans de la Lune, c'est pourtant toûjours le mesme Ciel. Il me paroist qu'elle nous a mis aussi dans l'imagination certaines Lunettes, au travers desquelles on voit tout, & qui changent fort les objets à l'égard de chaque homme. Alexandre voyoit la Terre comme une belle place bien propre à y établir un grand Empire. Celadon ne la voyoit que comme <RW>le sejour d'Astrée</RW>. Un Philosophe la voit comme une grosse Planete qui va par les Cieux, toute couverte de fous. Je ne croy pas que le Spectacle change plus de la Terre à la Lune, qu'il fait icy d'imagination à imagination.</P046>
chunks.target_manual: <P034>That makes me prefer our place of Habitation, said the Marquiese, to that of the Moon; for I cannot believe, that the mixture of the Heavenly Colours is so fine there, as it is here. Let us suppose, if you will, the Heavens of a reddish Colour, and the Stars of a greenish, the Effect wou'd not be half so agreeable as Stars of Gold, upon a deep Blue. To hear you speak, said I, one wou'd think you were fitting of Furniture for a Room, or chusing a Garniture for a Suit of Cloths: Believe me, Nature is very ingenious, therefore let us leave to her Care the finding out a Mixture of Colours agreeable to the Inhabitants of the Moon; and I assure you, 'twill be perfectly well understood; she certainly has not fail'd of changing the Scene of the Universe, according to the different <UP>Situation and Position of the Beholders</UP>, and still in a new and agreeable way. I know the Skill of Nature perfectly well, said Madam the Marquiese; and she has spar'd her self the pains of changing her Objects, as to the several Points from whence they may be seen, and has only chang'd the Perspective-glasses, through which they are seen; and has the Honour of this great Variety, without the Expence: She has bestow'd on us a blue Heaven, with a blue Air; and it may be, she has bestow'd upon the Inhabitants of the Moon, a Heaven of Scarlet, with an Air of the same Colour, and yet their Heaven and ours is one and the same: And it seems to me, that Nature has given every one of us a Perspective-glass, or Tube, through which we behold Objects in a very different manner, one from the other. Alexander the Great saw the Earth as a fine place, fit for him to form a great Empire upon: Celadon only look'd upon it, as <RW>the Dwelling-place of Astraea</RW>: A Philosopher considers it as a great Planet, all cover'd over with Fools, moving through the Heavens: And I do not see that the Object changes more from the Earth to the Moon, than it does here from one Man to another.</P034>

The translator makes the implied meaning of a fixed dwelling explicit by using "place of Habitation," clarifying the nature of their preference for Earth over the Moon as a home.

This specifies the shade of blue, which was unstated in the source, likely to enhance the visual description for the reader in the context of discussing beautiful celestial color combinations.

The translation specifies the item as "a Suit of Cloths" and the action as selecting "a Garniture" (trimmings/adornments) for it, thus expanding and making the implied details of the comparison more explicit and elaborate.

This makes explicit the implied context of furnishing a larger space (a room) and dealing with a collection of items ("Furniture") rather than potentially just a single item ("un meuble").

The French "un assortiment de couleurs pour la Lune" (an assortment of colours for the Moon) is translated as "a Mixture of Colours agreeable to the Inhabitants of the Moon." The translator adds "agreeable to the Inhabitants of the Moon," making explicit the implied beneficiary and purpose of these colors, which is hinted at in the conversational context about aesthetic preference.

The French "à chaque point de veüe diferent" (at each different point of view) is translated as "according to the different Situation and Position of the Beholders." The abstract "point de veüe" is made concrete by specifying it as relating to the "Situation and Position" and by explicitly identifying "the Beholders" whose perspectives are being considered.

The French "son adresse" (her/its skill), where "son" anaphorically refers to "la Nature" mentioned earlier, is translated as "the Skill of Nature perfectly well." The translator makes the agent "Nature," which was only implied by the possessive pronoun "son," explicit by name. The addition "perfectly well" amplifies the degree of skill, but the core explicitation is identifying Nature.

The French "pour chaque point de veüe" (for each point of view) is translated as "as to the several Points from whence they may be seen." The phrase "from whence they may be seen" is added, explicitly clarifying that these "points of view" are locations or perspectives from which objects are observed, making the concept more concrete.

The French "les Lunettes" (the eyeglasses/lenses/telescopes) is translated as "the Perspective-glasses, through which they are seen." "Perspective-glasses" is a more specific term for optical instruments of the period than the general "Lunettes." Furthermore, the clause "through which they are seen" is added, making the function of these instruments explicit.

The French "un Ciel rouge" (a red Sky/Heaven) is translated as "a Heaven of Scarlet." "Rouge" (red) is a general color term. "Scarlet" is a specific, vivid shade of red. The translator specifies the color, adding a descriptive detail not explicitly present in the source, likely to enhance the imagery and convey a particular intensity implied by the context of discussing striking celestial aesthetics.

The French "avec un Air rouge" (with a red Air) is translated as "with an Air of the same Colour." Following the mention of "a Heaven of Scarlet" for the Moon, this phrase explicitly links the color of the Moon's air to the specific color (Scarlet) just attributed to its heaven, spelling out a connection that was merely implied by the repetition of "rouge."

The French "elle nous a mis aussi dans l'imagination certaines Lunettes" (she has put [...] certain glasses/lenses in our imagination), where "elle" (she) implicitly refers to Nature, is translated as "Nature has given every one of us a Perspective-glass, or Tube." The referent "Nature" is made explicit. "Lunettes" is rendered as the more specific "Perspective-glass," and this is further expanded by "or Tube," providing an alternative and more descriptive term for the implied optical instrument.

The French "Alexandre" is simply a name. The translation "Alexander the Great" adds the common epithet "the Great." This makes the specific historical identity of Alexander, who is strongly implied by the context of "établir un grand Empire" (to establish a great Empire), fully explicit for the reader.

The French "le sejour d'Astrée" (the stay/sojourn of Astraea) is translated as "the Dwelling-place of Astraea." "Sejour" can have a general meaning of "stay." The translator makes the implicit meaning of a more permanent or specific location explicit by using "Dwelling-place," clarifying the nature of Astrée's connection to Earth in this literary allusion.

The French "qui va par les Cieux" (which goes through the Heavens) is translated as "moving through the Heavens." The general verb "va" (goes) is rendered as the more specific "moving," which explicitly describes the manner of the planet's travel through the skies, aligning with a more dynamic depiction of celestial motion.

chunks.source_manual: <P047>Le changement de Spectacle est plus surprenant dans nos imaginations, repliquay-je, car ce ne sont que les mesmes objets qu'on voit si diferemment; du moins dans la Lune on peut voir d'autres objets, ou ne pas voir quelques-uns de ceux qu'on voit icy. Peut-estre ne connoissent-ils point en ce Pays-là l'Aurore, ny les Crepuscules, avant que le Soleil se leve, ou aprés qu'il est couché. L 'Air qui nous environne, & qui est élevé au dessus de nous, reçoit des rayons qui ne pourroient pas tomber sur la Terre, & parce qu'il est fort grossier, il en arreste une partie, & nous les renvoye, quoy qu'ils ne nous fussent pas naturellement destinez. Ainsi l'Aurore & les Crepuscules sont une grace que la Nature nous fait; c'est une lumiere que régulierement nous ne devrions point avoir, & qu'elle nous donne par dessus ce qui nous est dû. Mais dans la Lune, où apparemment l'Air est plus pur, il pourroit bien n'estre pas si propre à renvoyer en bas les rayons qu'il reçoit du Soleil avant qu'il se leve, ou aprés qu'il est couché. Vous n'avez donc cette lumiere de faveur <NCP></NCP>, qui en se fortifiant peu à peu, vous prepare agreablement à l'arrivée du Soleil, ou qui en s'affoiblissant comme de nuance en nuance, vous accoûtume à sa perte. Vous estes dans des tenebres profondes <NCP></NCP>, & tout d'un coup il semble qu'on tire un rideau, voila vos yeux frapez de tout l'éclat qui est dans le Soleil; vous estes dans une lumiere vive & éclatante, & tout d'un coup vous voila tombés dans des tenebres profondes. Le jour & la nuit ne sont point liez par un milieu qui tienne de l'un & de l'autre. L'Arc-en-ciel est encore une chose qui manque aux Gens de la Lune, car si l'Aurore est un effet de la grossiereté de l'air & des vapeurs, l'Arc-en-ciel se forme dans les nuages d'où tombent les pluyes, & nous devons les plus belles choses du monde à celles qui le sont le moins. Puis <UP></UP> qu'il n'y a autour de la Lune ny vapeurs assez grossieres, ny nuages pluvieux, adieu l'Arc-en-ciel avec l'Aurore, & à quoy ressembleront les Belles de ce Pays-là? Quelle source de comparaisons perduë!</P047>
chunks.target_manual: <P035>The Change of Sights is more surprizing to our Imagination, said I; for they are still the same Objects we see at different Views; and it may be, in the Moon they see other Objects than we see; at least, they do not see a part of those we see: Perhaps in that Country they know nothing of the <RW>Dawning of the Day, of the Twi-light before Sun-rising</RW>, and after Sun-setting; for the Beams of the Sun, at these two times, being oblique and faint, have not strength to penetrate the grosness and thickness of the Air, with which we are environ'd; but are receiv'd and intercepted by the Air, before they can fall upon the Earth, and are reflected upon us by the Air; so that Day-break and Twi-light are Favours of Nature which we enjoy by the by, or, as it were, by chance, they not having been destin'd for us; but 'tis likely that the Air of the Moon, being purer than ours, is not so proper and fit for reflecting the faint Beams of the Sun before its Rising, and after its Setting; therefore I suppose, the Inhabitants of the Moon do not enjoy the favourable light of the Aurora, or Dawning; which growing stronger and stronger, does prepare us for the glorious Appearance of the Sun at Noon; nor the Twi-light, which becoming more faint by degrees, we are insensibly accustom'd to the Absence of the Sun: So that the Inhabitants of the Moon are in profound Darkness, when on a suddain a Curtain is drawn, as it were, and their Eyes are dazl'd with the Rays of the Sun, and they enjoy a bright resplendent Light; when by a suddain motion, as quick as the former, down falls the Curtain, and instantly they are reduc'd to their former Darkness: They want those Mediums, or Interstices, which join Day and Night together (and which participates of both) which we enjoy. Besides, these People have no Rain-bow; for as the Dawning is an Effect of the thickness of our Air, so the Rain-bow is form'd upon Exhalations and Vapours, condens'd into black Clouds, which pour down Rain upon us, <UP>by divers Reflections and Refections of the Sun-beams upon these Clouds</UP>: So that we owe the Obligation of the most agreeable and pleasant Effects, to the ugliest and most dis- agreeable Causes in Nature: And since the Purity of the Air of the Moon deprives it of Clouds, Vapours and Rain, adieu to Rain-bow and Aurora: To what then can the Lovers in the Moon compare their Mistresses, without these two things?</P035>

The target translation makes this explicit by identifying these as "the Beams of the Sun," specifying that this occurs "at these two times" (dawn/dusk), and describing them as "oblique and faint." This adds clarifying scientific attributes to the rays that were only implied or unstated in the source.

The French "par dessus ce qui nous est dû" (over and above what is owed to us) implies something extra or unmerited. The English translation "by the by, or, as it were, by chance" explicitly interprets this "extra" nature as being coincidental or fortuitous, adding a layer of meaning about the manner of this "grace" not directly stated in the source.

The translator makes the referent of "Vous" (You) explicit as "the Inhabitants of the Moon." The addition of "I suppose" also makes the philosopher's speculative stance more explicit. Furthermore, "cette lumiere de faveur" (this light of favor) is specified as "the favourable light of the Aurora, or Dawning," explicitly linking it to the previously discussed phenomenon by name.

The source refers to "l'arrivée du Soleil" (the arrival of the Sun). The target translation expands this to "the glorious Appearance of the Sun at Noon." The addition of "at Noon" makes explicit the implied time of the sun's full presence or peak, clarifying information that was less specific in the source.

The French "sa perte" (its loss, referring to the Sun) is translated as "the Absence of the Sun." This makes the nature of the "loss" more explicit and less metaphorical, clarifying it as the sun's physical absence rather than just "loss."

The source simply states a sudden fall into deep darkness. The target translation elaborates on this by adding the descriptive mechanism "by a suddain motion, as quick as the former, down falls the Curtain." This makes the process of transition to darkness more explicit, mirroring and completing the "curtain" metaphor used earlier for sunrise, which the source did not explicitly extend to sunset.

The French "un milieu" (a medium/middle state) is expanded in the target to "those Mediums, or Interstices," where "or Interstices" adds a clarifying synonym. Furthermore, the clause "which we enjoy" is added, explicitly framing this transitional state as a benefit experienced on Earth, a nuance implied but not directly stated in the source phrase.

The source provides a basic explanation for rainbow formation: "in the clouds from which rain falls." The target text significantly expands this by adding detailed scientific information concerning the material composition ("Exhalations and Vapours, condens'd into black Clouds") and the optical mechanism ("by divers Reflections and Refections of the Sun-beams upon these Clouds"). This makes the implicit scientific process of rainbow formation explicit.

The source states the absence of "vapeurs assez grossieres, ny nuages pluvieux" (coarse enough vapors, nor rainy clouds) around the Moon. The target translation explicitly attributes this absence to "the Purity of the Air of the Moon," thus spelling out a causal relationship (purity of air leads to lack of clouds/vapors) that was previously implied or stated separately.

The source's general "les Belles de ce Pays-là" (the Beauties of that country) and "Quelle source de comparaisons perduë!" (What a lost source of comparisons!) are made more specific. The target translation explicitly identifies "the Lovers in the Moon" as the agents performing the comparison and "their Mistresses" as the objects of comparison ("les Belles"), thus making the implied social and literary context of such comparisons explicit.

chunks.source_manual: <P048>Je n'aurois pas grand regret à ces comparaisons là, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, & je trouve qu'on est assez bien recompensé dans la Lune <UP></UP>, de n'avoir ny Aurore ny Arc-en- ciel, car on ne doit avoir par la mesme raison ny Foudres ny Tonnerres, puisque ce sont aussi des choses qui se forment dans les nüages. On a de beaux jours toûjours serains pendant lesquels on ne perd point le Soleil de veuë <NCE></NCE>. On n'a point de nuits où toutes les Etoiles ne se montrent <UP></UP>; on ne connoist ny les orages ny les tempestes, ny tout ce qui paroist estre un effet de la colere du Ciel, trouvez-vous qu'on soit tant à plaindre? Vous me faites voir la Lune comme un séjour enchanté, répondis-je; cependant je ne sçay s'il est si délicieux d'avoir toûjours sur la teste, un Soleil ardent dont aucun nüage ne modere la chaleur. Peut-estre aussi est-ce à cause de cela que la Nature a creusé dans la Lune des especes de Puits, qui sont assez grands pour estre apperceus par nos Lunettes; car ce ne sont point des Vallées qui soient entre des Montagnes, ce sont des creux que l'on voit au milieu de certains lieux plats. Que sçait-on si les Habitans de la Lune, incommodez par l'ardeur perpetuelle du Soleil, ne se refugient point dans ces grands Puits? Ils n'habitent peut-estre point ailleurs, c'est-là qu'ils bâtissent leurs Villes. Nous voyons icy que la Rome soûterraine estoit presque aussi grande que la Rome qui estoit sur Terre. Il ne faudroit qu'oster celle-cy, le reste seroit une Ville à la maniere de la Lune. Tout un Peuple est dans un Puits, & d'un Puits à l'autre il y a des chemins soûterrains pour la communication des Peuples. Vous vous mocquez de cette vision, j'y consens de tout mon cœr; cependant, à vous parler tres serieusement, vous pourriez vous tromper plûtost que moy. Vous croyez que les Gens de la Lune doivent habiter sur la surface de leur Planete, parce que nous habitons sur la surface de la nostre: c'est tout le contraire, puisque nous habitons sur la surface de nostre Planete, ils pourroient bien n'habiter pas sur la surface de la leur. D'icy là il faut que toutes choses soient bien differentes. <UP></UP></P048> <P049>Il n'importe, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, je ne puis me resoudre à laisser vivre les Habitans de la Lune dans une obscurité perpetuelle. Vous y auriez encore plus de peine, répris-je, si vous sçaviez qu'un grand Philosophe de l'Antiquité a fait de la Lune le séjour des Ames qui ont merité icy d'estre bien-heureuses. Toute leur felicité consiste en ce qu'elles y entendent l'Harmonie que les Corps Celestes font par leurs mouvemens; mais comme il pretend que quand la Lune tombe dans l'ombre de la Terre, elles ne peuvent plus entendre cette Harmonie <UP></UP>; alors, dit-il, ces Ames crient comme des desesperées, & la Lune se haste le plus qu'elle peut de les tirer d'un endroit si facheux. Nous devrions donc, repliqua-t-elle, voir arriver icy les Bienheureux de la Lune, car apparemment on nous les envoye aussi, & dans ces deux Planetes on croit avoir assez pourveu à la felicité des Ames, de les avoir transportées dans un autre Monde. Serieusement, répris-je, ce ne seroit pas un plaisir mediocre de voir plusieurs Mondes differens. Ce Voyage me réjoüit quelquefois beaucoup à ne le faire qu'en imagination, & que seroit-ce, si on le faisoit en effet? Cela vaudroit bien mieux que d'aller d'icy au Japon, c'est à dire de ramper avec beaucoup de peine d'un point de la Terre sur un autre, pour ne voir que des hommes. Eh bien, dit-elle, faisons le Voyage des Planetes, comme nous pourrons; qui nous en empesche? Allons nous placer dans tous ces differens points de veuê, & de là considerons l'Univers. N'avons-nous plus rien à voir dans la Lune? Je croy que non, répondis-je, du moins je vous y ay fait voir tout ce qui estoit de ma connoissance. Au sortir de la Lune en tirant vers le Soleil, on trouve Venus. Sur Vénus je reprens le <NCE>Saint Denis</NCE>. Venus tourne sur elle-mesme, & autour du Soleil <UP>comme la Lune</UP>, on découvre avec les <NCP><IIM>Lunettes d'approche</IIM></NCP>, que Venus aussi-bien que la Lune, est tantost en Croissant, tantost en Décours, tantost pleine selon les diverses situations où elle est à l'égard de la Terre. La Lune selon toutes les apparences est habitée, pourquoy Vénus ne le sera-t-elle pas aussi? Mais, interrompit-elle, en disant toûjours Pourquoy non, vous m'allez mettre des Habitans dans toutes les Planetes? N'en doutez pas, répliquay-je, ce Pourquoy a une vertu qui suffira pour peupler tout. Nous voyons que toutes les Planetes sont de la mesme nature, toutes des Corps <IIM>opaques</IIM> qui ne reçoivent de la lumiere que du Soleil, qui se la renvoyent les uns aux autres, & qui n'ont que les mesmes mouvemens, jusque là tout est égal. Cependant il faudroit concevoir que ces grands Corps auroient esté faits pour n'estre point habitez, que ce seroit là leur condition naturelle, & qu'il y auroit une exception justement en faveur de la Terre toute seule. Qui voudra le croire, le croye; pour moy, je ne m'y puis pas resoudre? Je vous trouve, dit-elle, bien affermy dans vôtre opinion depuis quelques instans. <UP></UP> Je viens de voir le moment que la Lune seroit deserte, & que vous ne vous en souciïez pas beaucoup, & presentement si on osoit vous dire que toutes les Planetes ne sont pas aussi habitées que la Terre, je voy bien que vous vous mettriez en colere. Il est vray, répondis-je, que dans le moment où vous venez de me surprendre, si vous m'eussiez contredit sur les Habitans des Planetes, non seulement je vous les aurois soutenus, mais je crois que je vous aurois dit comment ils estoient tous faits. Il y a des momens pour croire, & je ne les ay jamais si bien crûs que dans celuy là; mais presentement que je suis un peu plus de sens froid, je ne laisse pas de trouver qu'il seroit bien étrange que la Terre fust aussi habitée qu'elle l'est, & que les autres Planetes ne le fussent point du tout; car ne croyez pas que nous voyions tout ce qui habite la Terre; il y a autant d'especes d'Animaux invisibles que de visibles. Nous voyons depuis l'Elephant jusqu'au <UP></UP> Ciron; là finit nostre veuë; mais au Ciron commence une multitude infinie d'Animaux, dont il est l'Elephant, & que la simple veuë ne sçauroit appercevoir. On a vu avec des <RW>Lunettes</RW> beaucoup de Liqueurs toutes remplis de petits Animaux que l'on n'auroit jamais soupçonnez d'y estre, & il y a quelque apparence que le goût qu'elles font sentir, sont les piqueures que ces petits Animaux font à la langue & au palais. Meslez de certaines choses dans quelques-unes de ces Liqueurs, ou exposez-les au Soleil, ou laissez-les se corrompre, voilà aussi-tost de nouvelles especes de petits Animaux.</P049> <P050>Beaucoup de Corps qui paroissent solides <UP></UP>, ne sont que des amas de ces Animaux imperceptibles, qui y trouvent pour leurs mouvemens autant de liberté qu'il leur en faut. Une feüille d'Arbre est un petit Monde habité par des Vermisseaux invisibles, à qui elle paroist d'une étenduë immense, qui y connoissent des Montagnes & des Abismes, & qui d'un costé de la feüille à l'autre n'ont pas plus de communication avec les autres Vermisseaux qui y vivent, que nous avec nos Antipodes. A plus forte raison, ce me semble, une <RW>grosse</RW> Planete sera-t-elle un Monde habité. On a trouvé jusque dans des especes de pierres tres-dures de petits Vers sans nombre, qui y étoient logez de toutes parts dans des vuides insensibles, & qui ne se nourrissoient que de la substance de ces pierres qu'ils rongeoient. Figurez-vous combien il y avoit de ces petits Vers, & pendant combien d'années ils subsistoient de la grosseur d'un grain de sable; & sur cet exemple, quand la Lune ne seroit qu'un amas de rochers, je la ferois plûtost ronger par ses Habitans que de n'y en pas mettre. Enfin tout est vivant, tout est animé <UP></UP>: mettez toutes ces especes d'Animaux nouvellement découvertes, & mesme toutes celles que l'on conçoit aisément qui sont encore à découvrir, avec celles que l'on a toûjours veuës, vous trouverez assurément que la Terre est bien peuplée, & que la Nature y a si liberalement répandu les Animaux, qu'elle ne s'est pas mise en peine que l'on en vist seulement la moitié. Croirez-vous qu'aprés qu'elle a poussé icy sa fecondité jusqu'à l'excés, elle a esté pour toutes les autres Planetes d'une sterilité à n'y rien produire de vivant?</P050>
chunks.target_manual: <P036>I do much regret that loss, said the Marquiese, for in my Opinion, the Inhabitants of the Moon are fully recompens'd for the want of the Rain-bow, day- break and twi-light, since for the same Reason, they have neither Thunder nor Lightning, both which are produc'd by Clouds and Exhalations; they enjoy bright serene Days, and never lose the Sun by Day, <UP>nor the Stars by Night</UP>. They know nothing of Storms and Tempest; which seem to us the effects of the wrath of Heaven. And can you think their condition is so much to be lamented? You, said I, Madam, represent the Moon as a most charming abode. Now methinks it should not be so desirous and agreeable to have a burning Sun always over ones Head, without the interposition of any Clouds to moderate its heat: And it may be for this Reason, Nature has sunk these Caverns in the Moon, which are big enough to be seen by our Telescopes: Who knows but the Inhabitants of the Moon, retire into these Cavities, when they are incommoded with the Excessive heat of the Sun, and it may be they live no where else, but build their Towns and Villages in these hollow places? And do not we know that Rome, which is built under ground, is almost as great as the City above ground? So that if we shou'd suppose, that the City of Rome above ground shou'd be ras'd, and quite remov'd, Rome under ground wou'd then be just such a Town, as those I have imagin'd to be in the Moon. Whole Nations live in these vast Caverns; and I doubt not but there may be Passages under ground, for the communication and commerce of one People and Nation with another. You are pleas'd to laugh, Madam, at my Fancy, do so with all my Heart, I agree you shou'd; and yet you may be more mistaken than I: For you believe, that the Inhabitants of the Moon dwell upon the Surface of their Globe, as we do on that of the Earth; it is very likely that 'tis just the contrary; for there is most certain, a vast difference between their way of living and ours. No matter, said the Marquiese, I cannot resolve to suffer the Inhabitants of the Moon to live in perpetual Darkness. You wou'd be harder put to it, Madam, said I, if you knew that a great Philosopher of old, believ'd the Moon to be the abode and dwelling of the Souls who had merited Happiness by their good Life in this World; and that theit Felicity consisted in hearing the Harmony of the Spheres as they turn'd round, and that they were depriv'd of this heavenly Musick, as often as the Moon was obscur'd by the Shadow of the Earth; and that then these Souls roar'd and cry'd out as in despair, and that the Moon made haste to recover her Light again, to bring the Souls out of that Affliction. At that rate, said she, we shou'd see the bless'd Souls come from the Moon to us; for why shou'd not the Earth be to the Moon, as the Moon is to the Earth, since according to the opinion of your Philosopher, there was no other Felicity for the Souls of the blessed, than to be transported from one World to the other? Seriously, said I, Madam, 'twould be a great Pleasure and Satisfaction to see several different Worlds; and I am often glad, to make these Journeys in Imagination; what joy then it wou'd be to do it in reality; that wou'd be far better than to travel from hence to Iapan, crawling as it were with difficulty from one point of this Globe to another, and still to see nothing but Men and Women over and over again. Well, said she, what hinders, but we shou'd make a Journey through the Planets as well as we can? Let us by imagination place our selves in several Positions, and situations, fit for considering the Universe. Have we no more to see in the Moon? No, said I, at least, I have shown you all I know. Going out of the Moon towards the Sun, the first Planet you meet with is Venus; and here I must again make use of my former Simile of Paris and St. Denis. Venus turns round the Sun on her own Axis, <UP>as the Moon does round the Earth</UP>; and by the means of Telescopes, we discover that Venus waxes and wanes, being sometimes altogether enlightned, and sometimes darkened according to her different Positions in respect to the Earth.</P036> <P037>By all appearance the Moon is inhabited, why shou'd not Venus be so, as well as she? Ay, but interrupted the Marquiese by your why nots, you will people all the Planets. Do not doubt of it, Madam, answer'd I; why has not Nature sufficient to give Inhabitants to 'em all? We see that all the Planets are of the same Nature, that they are all Opaque solid Bodies, having no Light but what they receive from the Sun; which they send one to another by Reflection, and that they have all the same kind of motion; thus far equal, and after all this must we conceive that all these vast Bodies were made not to be inhabited? And that Nature has made only an exception in Favor of the Earth, he that will believe this, may, but for my part I cannot. I find you, said the Marquiese, very resolute and settled in your opinion of a sudden: A little while ago, you wou'd scarce allow the Moon to be inhabited; and seem'd to be very indifferent, whether it were so or not; whereas now, I am confident, you wou'd be very angry with any body that shou'd tell you that all the Planets were not inhabited. It is true, Madam, in the minute wherein you have surpriz'd me, had you contradicted me, as to the Inhabitants of all the Planets, I wou'd not only have defended my opinion, but have proceeded, to have given you an exact description of all the several Inhabitants of the Planets. There are certain Moments of believing things; and I never so firmly believ'd the Planets to be inhabited, as in that Moment I spoke of 'em; but now, after cooler Thoughts, I shou'd think it very strange, that the Earth shou'd be inhabited as it is; and the other Planets shou'd be so entirely desolate and desarted: For you must not think, that we see all the living Creatures that inhabit the Earth. For there are as many several species and kinds of Animals invisible, as there are visible. We see distinctly from the Elephant to the Mite; there our sight is bounded, and there are infinite numbers of living Creatures lesser than a Mite, to whom, a Mite is as big in proportion, as an Elephant is to it. <RW>The late invention of Glasses</RW> call'd Microscopes, have discover'd thousands of small living Creatures, in certain Liquors, which we cou'd never have imagin'd to have been there. And it may be the different tastes of these Liquors, proceed from these little Animals, who bite, and sting our Tongues and Palates. If you mix certain ingredients in these Liquors, <RW>(as Pepper in Water,)</RW> and expose 'em to the heat of the Sun, or let 'em putrefie, you shall see other new species or living Creatures. Several Bodies, which appear to be solid, are nothing else but Collections or little heaps of these imperceptible Animals; who find there as much room, as is requisite for them to move in. The leaf of a Tree, is a little World inhabited, by such invisible little Worms: To them this leaf seems of a vast Extent, they find Hills and Valleys upon it: And there is no more Communication between the living Creatures on the one side, and those on the other, than between us and the Antipodes. And I think there is more reason, to believe a Planet <RW>(which is so vast a Body)</RW> to be inhabited. There has been found in several sorts of very hard Stones, <UP>infinite multitudes</UP> of little Worms, lodg'd all over them in insensible varieties; and who are nourish'd upon the Substance of these Stones which they eat. Consider the vast Numbers of these little Animals, and how long a tract of Years they have liv'd upon a grain of Sand. And by this Argument, tho my Moon were nothing but a confus'd heap of Marble Rocks, I wou'd rather make it be devour'd and consum'd by its Inhabitants, than to place none at all in it.</P037>

explanations: The translator adds 'and Exhalations' to 'Clouds', making explicit the contemporary scientific theory that attributed weather phenomena like thunder and lightning not just to clouds but also to vapors or exhalations from the Earth, a detail implied by the French 'se forment dans les nüages' (are formed in the clouds) but specified in the English.

The phrases 'by Day' and 'by Night' are added to explicitly link the Sun to daytime visibility and Stars to nighttime visibility. This spells out temporal connections that are obvious from the context but are not explicitly demarcated in the source text's phrasing.

The French 'leurs Villes' (their cities/towns) is expanded to 'their Towns and Villages.' This explicitly broadens the scope of potential settlements on the Moon to include smaller ones like villages, a nuance not explicitly present in the single word 'Villes'.

The French adjectival phrase 'la Rome soûterraine' (subterranean Rome) is expanded into the descriptive clause 'Rome, which is built under ground.' This explicitly clarifies the meaning of 'soûterraine' for the reader by explaining its nature.

The French 'oster celle-cy' (remove this one) is translated as 'shou'd be ras'd, and quite remov'd.' The addition of 'ras'd' (razed) and the intensifier 'quite' makes explicit a more destructive and complete manner of removal than implied by the simpler 'oster'.

The French 'la communication des Peuples' (the communication of Peoples) is expanded to 'the communication and commerce of one People and Nation with another.' The addition of 'commerce' explicitly includes the economic aspect of interaction, and 'one People and Nation with another' elaborates on 'des Peuples,' emphasizing distinct groups.

The general French statement 'D'icy là il faut que toutes choses soient bien differentes' (From here to there, all things must be very different) is interpreted and narrowed in the translation to 'for there is most certain, a vast difference between their way of living and ours.' This makes explicit that the 'difference in all things' specifically pertains to the 'way of living.'

The French 'le séjour des Ames qui ont merité icy d'estre bien-heureuses' (the sojourn/abode of Souls who merited here to be happy) is translated to 'the abode and dwelling of the Souls who had merited Happiness by their good Life in this World'. 'Le séjour' is expanded to the doublet 'abode and dwelling', and 'icy' (here) is significantly expanded to 'by their good Life in this World,' explicitly stating the cause and location of meriting happiness.

The French 'l'Harmonie que les Corps Celestes font par leurs mouvemens' (the Harmony that the Celestial Bodies make by their movements) is rendered as 'the Harmony of the Spheres as they turn'd round'. This translation makes the implicit ancient cosmological concept explicit by using the specific term 'Harmony of the Spheres' and clarifies 'mouvemens' with 'as they turn'd round'.

The French 'crient comme des desesperées' (cry out/shout like desperate ones) is translated as 'roar'd and cry'd out as in despair.' The addition of 'roar'd' intensifies the action, making the expression of despair more vivid and explicit.

The French 'la Lune se haste le plus qu'elle peut de les tirer d'un endroit si facheux' (the Moon hastens as much as it can to pull them from such a vexing place) is rendered as 'the Moon made haste to recover her Light again, to bring the Souls out of that Affliction.' The translation explicitly states the *mechanism* (recovering her light) by which the Moon helps the souls, which is an interpretation and elaboration of the ST's more direct action of 'pulling them'.

The Marquise's reasoning in French, 'car apparemment on nous les envoye aussi, & dans ces deux Planetes on croit avoir assez pourveu à la felicité des Ames, de les avoir transportées dans un autre Monde,' is significantly rephrased and expanded. The translation introduces an explicit logical structure with a rhetorical question ('for why shou'd not...') and a direct causal link ('since according to...') to the philosopher's idea, thereby spelling out the implied reciprocal relationship and the basis of felicity more fully.

The French 'pour ne voir que des hommes' (to see only men/people) is translated as 'and still to see nothing but Men and Women over and over again.' 'Men and Women' makes explicit the inclusivity of 'hommes' in this context, and 'over and over again' elaborates on the monotony implied by 'ne voir que'.

The elliptical French 'Sur Vénus je reprens le Saint Denis' (On Venus I take up the Saint Denis again) is made explicit as 'and here I must again make use of my former Simile of Paris and St. Denis.' The translation identifies 'le Saint Denis' as a specific, previously mentioned simile, clarifying the reference for the reader.

The French 'Venus tourne sur elle-mesme, & autour du Soleil comme la Lune' (Venus turns on herself, & around the Sun like the Moon) is translated to 'Venus turns round the Sun on her own Axis, as the Moon does round the Earth'. This makes astronomically precise clarifications: 'sur elle-mesme' becomes 'on her own Axis', and the comparison 'comme la Lune' is expanded to 'as the Moon does round the Earth,' explicitly distinguishing Venus's solar orbit and self-rotation from the Moon's terrestrial orbit.

The French terms for lunar/planetary phases, 'est tantost en Croissant, tantost en Décours, tantost pleine' (is sometimes crescent, sometimes waning, sometimes full), are translated ('waxes and wanes') and further explained by describing their appearance in terms of illumination: 'being sometimes altogether enlightned, and sometimes darkened.' This makes the visual implication of the phases explicit.

The French 'toutes des Corps opaques' (all opaque Bodies) is translated as 'that they are all Opaque solid Bodies.' The word 'solid' is added, making explicit a physical property (solidity) that is strongly implied for planets in this context but not stated in the French.

The French 'qui se la renvoyent les uns aux autres' (which send it [light] back to each other) is translated as 'which they send one to another by Reflection.' The addition of 'by Reflection' explicitly states the scientific mechanism of light transfer between planets.

The French 'qu'il y auroit une exception justement en faveur de la Terre toute seule' (that there would be an exception precisely in favor of the Earth alone) is rendered as 'And that Nature has made only an exception in Favor of the Earth'. The translator personifies and makes explicit the agent 'Nature' as the one making the exception, whereas the French is more passive.

The concise French 'comment ils estoient tous faits' (how they were all made/constituted) is expanded into the more elaborate 'an exact description of all the several Inhabitants of the Planets.' This specifies the nature of the information (a description) and details the subjects (several inhabitants), making the philosopher's potential claim more explicit.

The French metaphorical phrase 'dont il [le Ciron] est l'Elephant' (of which it [the mite] is the Elephant) is translated and expanded into an explicit proportional analogy: 'to whom, a Mite is as big in proportion, as an Elephant is to it.' This spells out the relationship of scale that was implicit in the metaphor.

The French 'des Lunettes' (glasses/lenses), used in the context of observing microscopic creatures, is translated and specified as 'The late invention of Glasses call'd Microscopes.' This not only names the instrument explicitly but also adds 'The late invention of,' highlighting its novelty and contextualizing it within the Scientific Revolution.

The vague French 'Meslez de certaines choses dans quelques-unes de ces Liqueurs' (Mix certain things in some of these Liquors) is made more concrete by the addition of a specific example: 'If you mix certain ingredients in these Liquors, (as Pepper in Water,)'. This clarifies what 'certaines choses' might refer to.

The French 'un amas de rochers' (a heap/mass of rocks) is translated as 'a confus'd heap of Marble Rocks.' The adjectives 'confus'd' (describing the arrangement) and 'Marble' (specifying the type of rock) are added, providing details not explicit in the source.

The French 'je la ferois plûtost ronger par ses Habitans' (I would rather have it gnawed by its Inhabitants) is intensified to 'I wou'd rather make it be devour'd and consum'd by its Inhabitants.' The doublet 'devour'd and consum'd' makes the destructive action more total and explicit than the more specific 'ronger' (to gnaw).

chunks.source_manual: <P051>Ma raison est assez bien convaincuë, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, mais mon imagination est accablée de la multitude infinie des Habitans de toutes ces Planetes, & embarrassée de la diversité qu'il faut établir entre eux; car je voy bien que la Nature, selon qu'elle est ennemie des repetitions, les aura tous faits différens, mais comment se representer cela? Ce n'est pas à l'imagination à prétendre le représenter, répondis-je, elle n'est pas propre à aller plus loin que les yeux. On peut seulement apercevoir d'une certaine veuë universelle, la diversité que la Nature doit avoir mise entre tous ces Mondes. Tous les visages sont en general sur un mesme modele; mais ceux de deux grandes Nations, comme des Européens, si vous voulez, & des Africains, paroissent estre faits sur deux modeles particuliers, & il faudroit encore trouver le modele des visages de chaque Famille. Quel secret doit avoir eu la Nature pour varier en tant de manieres une chose aussi simple qu'un visage? Nous ne sommes dans l'Univers que comme une petite Famille, dont tous les visages se ressemblent; dans une autre Planete, c'est une autre Famille dont les visages ont un autre air. <UP></UP>.</P051> <P052>Apparemment les differences augmentent à mesure que l'on s'éloigne, & qui verroit un Habitant de la Lune, & un Habitant de la Terre, remarqueroit bien qu'ils seroient de deux Mondes plus voisions qu'un Habitant de la Terre & un Habitant de Saturne. Icy, <NCP>par exemple</NCP>, on a l'usage de la voix, ailleurs on ne parle que par signes, plus loin on ne parle point du tout. Icy le raisonnemét se forme entierement par l'experience; ailleurs l'experience y ajoûte fort peu de chose, plus loin les Vieillards n'en sçavent pas plus que les Enfants. Icy on se tourmente de l'avenir plus que du passé; plus loin on ne se tourmente ny de l'un ny de l'autre, & ceux-là ne sont peut-estre pas les plus malheureux. On dit qu'il pourroit bien nous manquer un sixiéme Sens naturel, qui nous aprendroit beaucoup de choses que nous ignorons. Ce sixiéme Sens est apparemment dans quelque autre Monde, où il manque quelqu'un des cinq que nous possedons. Peut-estre mesme y a-t-il effectivement un grand nombre de Sens naturels; mais dans le partage que nous avons fait avec les Habitans des autres Planetes, il ne nous en est écheu que cinq, dont nous nous contentons faute d'en connoistre d'autres. Nos Sciences ont de certaines bornes que l'Esprit humain n'a jamais pû passer; il y a un point où elles nous manquent tout à coup, le reste est pour d'autres Mondes, où quelque chose de ce que nous sçavons est inconnu. <RW>Cette Planete-cy</RW> joüit des douceurs de l'Amour, mais elle est toûjours desolée en plusieurs de ses parties par les fureurs de la Guerre. Dans une autre Planete on joüit d'une Paix éternelle, mais au milieu de cette Paix on ne connoist point l'Amour, & on s'ennuye. Enfin ce que la Nature pratique en petit entre les hommes pour la distribution du bonheur où des talens, elle l'aura sans doute pratiqué en grand entre les Mondes, & elle se sera bien souvenuë de mettre en usage ce secret merveilleux qu'elle a de diversifier toutes choses, & de les égaler en mesme temps que les compensations.</P052>
chunks.target_manual: <P038>To conclude, every thing lives, and every thing is animated; that is to say, if you comprehend the Animals, that are generally known; the living Creatures lately discover'd, and those that will be discover'd herafter, you will find that the Earth is very well Peopl'd; and that Nature has been so liberal in bestowing them, that she has not been at the pains to discover half of 'em. After this, can you believe, that Nature, who has been fruitful to Excess as to the Earth, is barren to all the rest of the Planets? My Reason is convinc'd, said the Marquiese, but my Fancy in confounded with the infinite Number of living Creatures, that are in the Planets; and my thoughts are strangely embarass'd with the variety that one must of Necessity imagine to be amongst 'em; because I know Nature does not love Repetitions; and therefore they must all be different. But how is it possible for one to represent all these to our Fancy? Our Imaginations can never comprehend this variety, said I, let us be satisfied with our Eyes, or we may easily conceive by an universal view, Nature has form'd variety in the several Worlds. All the Faces of Mankind are in general near the same Form. Yet the two great Nations of our Globe, the Europaeans and Africans, seem to have been made after different Models. Nay, there is a certain resemblance and Air of the Countenance peculiar to every Family or Race of Men. Yet it is wonderful to observe how many Millions of Times, Nature has varied so simple a thing as the Face of a Man. We, the Inhabitants of the Earth, are but one little Family of the Universe, we resemble one another. The Inhabitants of another Planet, are another Family, whose Faces have another Air peculiar to themselves; by all appearance, the difference increases with the distance, for cou'd one see an Inhabitant of the Earth, and one of the Moon together, he wou'd perceive less difference between them, than between an Inhabitant of the Earth, and an Inhabitant of Saturn. Here <NCP>(for Example)</NCP> we have the use of the Tongue and Voice, and in another Planet, it may be, they only speak by Signs. In another the Inhabitants speaks not at all. Here our Reason is form'd and made perfect by Experience. In another Place, Experience adds little or nothing to Reason. Further off, the old know no more than the young. Here we trouble our selves more to know what's to come, than to know what's past. In another Planet, they neither afflict themselves with the one nor the other; and 'tis likely they are not the less happy for that. Some say we want a sixth Sense by which we shou'd know a great many things we are now ignorant of. It may be the Inhabitants of some other Planet have this advantage; but want some of those other five we enjoy; it may be also that there are a great many more natural Senses in other Worlds; but we are satisfi'd with the five that are fal'n to our Share, because we know no better. Our Knowledge is bounded to certain limits, which the Wit of Man cou'd never yet exceed. There is a certain point where our Ingenuity is at a stand; that which is beyond it is for some other World, where it may be some things, that are familiar to us, are altogether unknown. Our <RW>Globe</RW> enjoys the Pleasure of Love; but is destroyed in several places by the fury of War. Another Planet enjoys constant Peace, without the delights of Love, which must render their Lives very irksom. In fine, Nature has done to the several Worlds in great, as she has done to us Mortals in little by making some happy, others miserable. <UP>Yet she has never forgot her admirable Art</UP> in varying all things, tho she has made some equal in some respects, by compensating the want of any one thing, with another of equal value.</P038>

explanations: The French "qu'il faut établir" (that one must establish/posit) is rendered as "that one must of Necessity imagine to be". The translator makes explicit the cognitive action ("imagine") and the compelling nature ("of Necessity") of this positing of diversity, which is more understated in the French.

The French "comment se representer cela?" (how to represent that to oneself?/how to imagine that?) is expanded to "But how is it possible for one to represent all these to our Fancy?". The translator adds "is it possible for one" making the difficulty explicit, specifies "cela" (that) as "all these" (referring to the diverse inhabitants), and adds "to our Fancy", making explicit the mental faculty involved, which was only implied in "se representer".

The French "Ce n'est pas à l'imagination à prétendre le représenter" (It is not for the imagination to claim/attempt to represent it) is translated as "Our Imaginations can never comprehend this variety". The translator makes "le" (it) explicit as "this variety" and rephrases the negation into a stronger assertion of inability "can never comprehend".

The French states "elle [l'imagination] n'est pas propre à aller plus loin que les yeux" (it [imagination] is not suited/able to go further than the eyes). The translation "let us be satisfied with our Eyes" makes explicit a suggested course of action or conclusion derived from this limitation, a connection that was unstated.

The French "On peut seulement apercevoir" (One can only perceive/glimpse) is translated as "we may easily conceive". The addition of "easily" makes explicit an assumed facility in this act of conception which is not stated in the French "seulement" (only/merely), which rather emphasizes limitation.

The French "Tous les visages" (All faces) is translated as "All the Faces of Mankind". The translator adds "of Mankind" to explicitly specify that human faces are being discussed, a detail implied by subsequent examples but not literally present in the initial phrase.

The French "deux grandes Nations" (two great nations) is translated as "the two great Nations of our Globe". The translator adds "of our Globe" to make explicit that these nations are terrestrial, a fact understood from context but not literally stated.

The French "le modele des visages de chaque Famille." (the model/pattern of faces of each family) is expanded to "a certain resemblance and Air of the Countenance peculiar to every Family or Race of Men.". The translator makes explicit the nature of this "modele" by describing it in detail and broadens "Famille" (family) with "or Race of Men," clarifying the intended scope.

The French "en tant de manieres" (in so many ways/manners) is made more emphatic and specific in the translation "how many Millions of Times". This adds a concrete, albeit figurative, quantification to the variety, making the sheer scale of Nature's variation more explicit.
The French "un visage" (a face) is translated as "the Face of a Man." The addition "of a Man" explicitly specifies that a human face is the example, which is contextually implied.
The French "Nous" (We) is translated as "We, the Inhabitants of the Earth". The translator explicitly identifies the referent of "Nous", clarifying the scope of the statement to terrestrial beings.

The French "dans une autre Planete, c'est une autre Famille" (in another Planet, it is another Family) uses an impersonal "c'est" (it is). The translation "The Inhabitants of another Planet, are another Family" makes the subject explicit by naming "The Inhabitants of another Planet" directly.

The French "un autre air.." (another air/look/appearance) is expanded to "another Air peculiar to themselves". The addition of "peculiar to themselves" explicitly emphasizes the distinctiveness and uniqueness of this appearance.

The French "qu'ils seroient de deux Mondes plus voisions qu'un Habitant de la Terre & un Habitant de Saturne." (that they would be from two worlds closer to each other than an inhabitant of Earth and an inhabitant of Saturn) implies lesser difference. The translation "he wou'd perceive less difference between them..." makes this implied consequence explicit.

The French "l'usage de la voix" (the use of the voice) is translated as "the use of the Tongue and Voice". The translator adds "Tongue" to specify one of the primary organs involved in speech production, making the mechanism more explicit.

The French "ailleurs" (elsewhere) is translated as "in another Planet". The translator makes the referent of "elsewhere" explicit by specifying "Planet", aligning it with the book's theme, which is implied in the French but stated outright in the English.

The French "plus loin on ne parle point du tout." (further away one/they do not speak at all) uses the impersonal pronoun "on". The translation "In another the Inhabitants speaks not at all." makes the subject explicit by specifying "the Inhabitants" and clarifies "plus loin" (further) as "In another [planet]".

The French "le raisonnemét se forme entierement" (reason is entirely formed) is translated as "our Reason is form'd and made perfect". The translator adds "our" to specify whose reason is being discussed and "and made perfect" to elaborate on the result of being "entirely formed," implying a state of completion or refinement.

The French "l'experience y ajoûte fort peu de chose" (experience adds very little to it), where "y" (to it) anaphorically refers to "raisonnement" (reason). The translation "Experience adds little or nothing to Reason" makes this referent explicit by restating "Reason".

The French "de l'avenir" (about the future) is expanded in the translation to "to know what's to come". This makes explicit that the concern or "trouble" is specifically related to the desire or act of knowing future events.
Similarly, the French "du passé" (about the past) is expanded to "to know what's past", clarifying that the concern is with knowing past events.
The French "plus loin" (further away) is rendered as "In another Planet". The translator specifies "Planet" as the location, making the reference more concrete within the context of the dialogue.

The French states "Ce sixiéme Sens est apparemment dans quelque autre Monde" (This sixth sense is apparently in some other World). The translation "It may be the Inhabitants of some other Planet have this advantage" makes "the Inhabitants" the explicit possessors of the sixth sense, and labels this possession as "this advantage," making explicit the implied benefit.

The French mentions "un grand nombre de Sens naturels" (a great number of natural senses). The translation "a great many more natural Senses in other Worlds" adds "in other Worlds", explicitly locating these additional senses, an idea implied by the overall context but not stated in this specific phrase.

The French "elles [nos Sciences] nous manquent tout à coup" (they [our Sciences] suddenly fail us/are lacking to us) is translated as "our Ingenuity is at a stand". The translator makes explicit that it is human "Ingenuity" that reaches a halt, and "is at a stand" vividly describes this state of cessation.
The French "Cette Planete-cy" (This planet here), referring to Earth, is translated as "Our Globe". The translation makes this identification explicit using a common synonym for Earth.

The French "& on s'ennuye." (and one gets bored / one is bored) is expanded to "which must render their Lives very irksom.". The translator makes explicit the causal link ("which must render"), specifies what is affected ("their Lives"), and intensifies the state ("very irksom").

The French "entre les hommes pour la distribution du bonheur où des talens" (among men for the distribution of happiness or talents) is translated as "to us Mortals in little by making some happy, others miserable.". "Hommes" becomes "us Mortals," and the general "distribution" is illustrated with the stark, explicit outcomes of "making some happy, others miserable."

The French phrase "& de les égaler en mesme temps que les compensations" (and to make them equal at the same time by/through compensations) is substantially expanded to "tho she has made some equal in some respects, by compensating the want of any one thing, with another of equal value." This makes explicit that equality is partial ("in some respects") and clearly spells out the mechanism of "compensations" by defining it in detail.

chunks.source_manual: <P053>Etes-vous contente, Madame, ajoûtay-je en quittant le ton serieux? Vous ay-je dubité assez de chimeres? Vrayment, répondit-elle, il me semble que j'ay presentement moins de peine à attraper les differences de tous ces Mondes. Mon imagination travaille sur le plan que vous m'avez donné. Je me represente comme je puis des Caracteres & des Coûtumes extraordinaire pour les Habitans des Planetes, & je leur compose mesme des figures tout-à-fait bizarres. Je ne vous les pourrois pas décrire, mais je voy pourtant quelque chose. Pour ces figures-là, repliquay-je, je vous conseille d'en laisser le soin aux Songes que vous aurez cette nuit. Nous verrons demain s'ils vous auront bien servie, & s'ils vous auront appris comment sont faits les Habitants de quelque Planete.</P053>
chunks.target_manual: <P039>Are you satisfi'd, said I, Madam, very gravely; have not I told you Chimeras in abundance? Truly, I find not so much difficulty to comprehend these differences of Worlds; my Imagination is working upon the Model you have given me And I am representing to my own Mind odd Characters and Customs for these Inhabitants of the other Planets. Nay more, I am forming extravagant shapes and figures for 'em: I can describe 'em to you; for I fansie I see 'em here. I leave these shapes, said I, Madam, to entertain you in Dreams this Night, to morrow, we shall know, if they have assisted you, to describe the Inhabitants of some other Planet.</P039>
target_segments: in abundance
I am representing to my own Mind
Nay more
I fansie I see
'em here
explanations: The French "assez de" (enough of) is translated as "in abundance." While "assez" can imply a satisfactory or sufficient quantity, "in abundance" explicitly denotes a very large or plentiful amount, thus clarifying and amplifying the implied quantity of "chimeres" beyond the potential ambiguity of "assez."

The French reflexive "Je me represente" (I represent to myself / I imagine) implies an internal mental process. The English "I am representing to my own Mind" makes this internal locus explicit by adding "to my own Mind," specifying the faculty or location of the mental representation which was only implied by the reflexive pronoun "me" (to myself) in the original.

The French "mesme" (even, also), used here to introduce an additional and perhaps more striking example of what the Marquise is imagining, is translated as "Nay more." "Nay more" is an emphatic discourse marker that explicitly signals this additive and intensifying function, making the rhetorical connection clearer and stronger than the more subtle "mesme."

The general French verb "je voy" (I see), within the phrase "je voy pourtant quelque chose," is translated as "I fansie I see." This explicitates the nature of the Marquise's perception by adding "fansie" (fancy), clarifying that her "seeing" is an act of imagination. This mode of seeing is implied by the context in the French text (her imagination is at work) but is made explicit in the translation's choice of verb phrase.

The vague French "quelque chose" (something), within the phrase "je voy pourtant quelque chose" and referring to what the Marquise sees, is rendered as part of "'em here." This explicitates the vision by (a) using "'em" (them) to clearly identify the "something" as the previously discussed "shapes and figures," rather than an undefined object, and (b) contributing to the addition of "here" which specifies the immediacy or (mental) location of these figures, making the vision more concrete.

chunks.source_manual: <P054>QUATRIEME SOIR.</P054>
chunks.target_manual: <P040>The Fourth Night.</P040>
target_segments: Night
explanations: The French 'SOIR,' typically meaning 'Evening' (as in 'QUATRIEME SOIR' – 'Fourth Evening'), denotes the time of the dialogues. Translating this as 'Night' (e.g., 'The Fourth Night') makes more explicit the connection to the astronomical theme of the conversations. 'Night' directly evokes the optimal conditions for stargazing and celestial contemplation, which are central to the book's content. This choice clarifies the suitability of the dialogue's timing for its scientific subject matter, an aspect that was more implicitly suggested by 'SOIR' in the context of astronomical discussions.

chunks.source_manual: <P055><SC>Les songes ne furent point heureux: ils representerent toûjours quelque chose qui ressembloit à ce que l'on voit icy. J'eus lieu de reprocher à la <IIM>Marquise</IIM> ce que nous reprochent à la veüe de nos Tableaux, de certains Peuples qui ne font jamaïs que des peintures bizarres & grotesques. Bon, nous disent-ils, cela est tout fait comme des hommes, il n'y a pas là d'imagination. Il falut donc se resoudre à ignorer les figures des Habitans de toutes ces Planetes, & se contenter d'en deviner ce que nous pourrions, en continuant le Voyage des Mondes que nous avions commencé.</SC> Nous en estions à Venus. On est bien seur, dis-je à la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, que Venus tourne sur elle-mesme, <SC>mais on ne sçait pas bien en quel temps</SC>, ny par consequent combien ses jours durent. Pour ses années, elles ne sont que de huit mois, puis qu'elle tourne en ce temps-là autour du Soleil. Come elle est quarante fois plus petite que la Terre, la Terre de dedans Venus paroist une Planete quarante fois plus grande, que Venus ne nous paroist d'icy; & comme la Lune est aussi quarante fois plus petite que la Terre, elle paroist dedans Venus à peu prés de la mesme grandeur dont Venus nous paroist d'icy.</P055>
chunks.target_manual: <P041>THe Dreams <UP>of my Lady Marquiese</UP> were not lucky, they still represented to her something like what we see on Earth; so that I had as much reason to reproach her, as certain People have to blame us when they see some of our Pictures; for they being ignorant of drawing, and designing, and pleasing themselves with their extravagant and grotesque Figures, tell us, our Pictures are nothing but Men and Women, and that there is no Fancy in 'em; there was therefore a necessity of laying aside all sorts of the Forms and Figures of those Animals that inhabit several Planets, and to rest satisfy'd by guessing as well as we can, in pursuing our Journey, which we had begun, through the several Worlds of the Universe.</P041> <P042>We were at Venus: And there is no doubt, said I to my Lady Marquiese, but Venus turns upon her own Axis, but 'tis not known in what time, and by consequence, we know not the length of her Days, but her Years must consist but of eight Months, since Venus turns round the Sun <UP>in that space of time</UP>. As Venus is forty times less than the Earth, the Earth must necessarily appear to the Inhabitants of Venus, to be forty times bigger than Venus appears to us; and as the Moon is also forty times less than the Earth, by consequence, it must appear to the Inhabitants of Venus, about the same bigness that Venus appears to us.</P042>

the Forms and Figures of those Animals that inhabit

explanations: The French phrase "qui ne font jamaïs que des peintures bizarres & grotesques" (who only ever make bizarre and grotesque paintings) describes the artistic output of certain people. The English translation "for they being ignorant of drawing, and designing, and pleasing themselves with their extravagant and grotesque Figures" makes explicit a supposed reason for this artistic choice by adding the clause "for they being ignorant of drawing, and designing." This provides a specific rationale (lack of technical skill) which is not explicitly stated in the source, where these people's preference is later framed by their own words as a desire for "imagination" over simple mimesis.

The French "les figures des Habitans" (the figures/forms of the Inhabitants) uses the general term "Habitans." The English translation "the Forms and Figures of those Animals that inhabit" makes explicit the *type* of inhabitants by specifying "Animals." This renders Fontenelle's more general and speculative term for extraterrestrial life more concrete, potentially narrowing the scope of beings implied by the author.

The French "Venus tourne sur elle-mesme" (Venus turns on herself) describes planetary rotation in accessible, everyday language. The English translation "Venus turns upon her own Axis" makes the implicit astronomical concept of an axis of rotation explicit by using a more technical term, thereby clarifying the mechanism of rotation not spelled out in the source.

The French phrase "la Terre de dedans Venus paroist" (the Earth from within Venus appears) implies an observer located on Venus but does not explicitly name one. The English translation "the Earth must necessarily appear to the Inhabitants of Venus" makes this observer explicit by specifically naming "the Inhabitants of Venus," thus spelling out who is experiencing this perspective.

The French phrase "elle paroist dedans Venus" (it appears from within Venus) implies an observer on Venus without explicitly stating who it is. The English translation "it must appear to the Inhabitants of Venus" makes this observer explicit by specifically naming "the Inhabitants of Venus," clarifying who is perceiving the Moon's apparent size from that vantage point.

chunks.source_manual: <P056>Vous m'affligez, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>. Je voy bien que la Terre n'est pas pour Vénus l'Etoile du Berger, & la Mere des Amours, comme Vénus l'est pour la Terre; car la Terre de dedans Vénus paroist trop grande, mais la Lune qui y paroist de la mesme grandeur dont Vénus nous paroist d'icy, est justement taillée comme il faut pour y estre Mere des Amours, & Etoile du Berger <NCE></NCE>. Ces noms ne peuvent convenir qu'à une petite Planete qui soit jolie, claire, brillante, & qui ait un air galant. <UP></UP> C'est asseurément une destinée agréable pour nostre Lune que de presider aux Amours des Habitans de Venus; ces Gens là doivent bien entendre la galanterie. Oh! sans doute, répondis-je, le menu Peuple de Venus n'est composé que de Celadons & de Silvandres, & leurs Conversations le plus communes valent les plus belles de Clesie. <UP></UP> Le climat est tres-favorable aux Amours. Venus est plus proche que nous du Soleil, & elle en reçoit une lumiere plus vive & plus de chaleur.</P056> <P057>Je vois presentement, interrompit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, comment sont faits les Habitans de Venus. Ils ressemblent aux Mores Grenadins; un petit Peuple noir, brûlé du Soleil, plein d'esprit & de feu, toûjours amoureux, faisant des Vers, aimant la Musique, inventant tous les jours des Festes, des Danses, & des Tournois. Permettez-moy de vous dire, Madame, repliquay-je, que vous ne connoissez guere bien les Habitans de Venus. Nos Mores Grenadins n'auroient esté auprés d'eux que des Lappons & des Groënlandois pour la froideur & pour la stupidité.</P057>
chunks.target_manual: <P043>You afflict me, said the Marquiese <UP>, extremely</UP>; I see very well, that our Earth is not <IIM>that happy Planet to the Inhabitants of</IIM> Venus, as she is to us; for our Globe of the Earth must appear too big to the Inhabitants of Venus, to be the <IIM>Fountain</IIM> of Love, but the Moon, which appears to the World of Venus, of the same size that Venus appears to us, is exactly cut out to be <UP>the Source of their Amours, and the lucky Star of their Intrigues</UP>; which Titles are most agreeable to the pretty, clear, twinkling Planets, which have in 'em a certain Air of Gallantry. 'Tis certainly a happy Fate for our Moon to give Laws to the Loves of the Inhabitants of Venus: No doubt, but these People are very soft, and have the Art to please extreamly well. Without dispute, Madam, said I; the very Mobile of Venus are all made up of Celladons and Silvanders, and their most ordinary Conversations excel the finest in Clelia; the Climate being more savourable to Love: Venus being nearer the Sun than we, receives from its Influence a brighter Light, and a more enlivening Heat. I perceive very well, interrupted the Marquiese, what kind of People the Inhabitants of Venus are; they are, like our Moors of Granada, a sort of little Sun-burnt Gentlemen, always in Love, full of Life and Fire, given to making Verses, and great Lovers of Musick, and every Day inventing Feasts, Balls and Masquerades, to entertain their Mistresses. Pray, Madam, said I, you are very ill acquainted with the Inhabitants of Venus; for our Moors of Granada are, in respect to them, as the Inhabitants of Lapland, or Greenland, for Coldness and Stupidity.</P043>
