explanations: The translator makes the intensity of the Marquise's feeling explicit by adding 'extremely' to the rendition of 'Vous m'affligez.' The core phrase 'You afflict me' is intensified by 'extremely,' which is placed after the intervening 'said the Marquiese' in the target text.

The translator makes explicit a positive quality ('that happy Planet') implied by the negated poetic French appellations ('l'Etoile du Berger, & la Mere des Amours' - the Shepherd's Star and the Mother of Loves). Additionally, 'pour Vénus' (for Venus) is expanded to 'to the Inhabitants of Venus,' clarifying that the perspective or beneficiary is Venus's population.

The French 'la Terre' (the Earth) is rendered as 'our Globe of the Earth,' making its spherical nature explicit. Additionally, the locational phrase 'de dedans Vénus' (from within Venus, i.e., as seen from Venus) is clarified by expansion to 'to the Inhabitants of Venus,' specifying the viewpoint.

The translator expands the implicit French locative adverb 'y' (there), which refers to Venus, into the explicit phrase 'to the World of Venus.' This clarification specifies the location or perspective from which the Moon is viewed.

The French 'Mere des Amours' (Mother of Loves) is translated as 'the Source of their Amours.' While 'Mother' can imply origin, 'Source' makes this specific function explicit, interpreting 'Mère' not just genealogically or affectively but as the origin point.

The French 'Etoile du Berger' (Shepherd's Star), a poetic name for Venus (here contextually applied to the Moon as seen from Venus), is translated as 'the lucky Star of their Intrigues.' This translation makes explicit several implied aspects: 'lucky Star' adds a notion of fortune not directly in 'Etoile du Berger,' and 'of their Intrigues' specifies the nature of the 'Amours' (loves) as potentially secretive or complex, which is an interpretation beyond the original term.

The French 'presider aux Amours' (to preside over the Loves) is rendered as 'to give Laws to the Loves.' 'To give Laws to' is a more specific and authoritative interpretation of 'presider,' making explicit a governing or rule-setting role for the Moon that is only implied by 'presider.'

The French phrase 'ces Gens là doivent bien entendre la galanterie.' (those People must be well versed in/understand gallantry well) is significantly expanded to 'these People are very soft, and have the Art to please extreamly well.' The additions 'very soft' and the elaborated phrase 'have the Art to please extreamly well' make explicit certain characteristics (softness) and the specific manifestation of their understanding of gallantry, which are interpretations and elaborations of the original, more concise phrase.

The translator makes the implicit causal agent of the French pronoun 'en' in 'elle en reçoit' (it receives from it/them, referring to the Sun) explicit by expanding the translation to 'receives from its Influence,' thereby clearly spelling out the sun as the source of light and heat.

The French 'plus de chaleur' (more heat) is translated as 'a more enlivening Heat.' The adjective 'enlivening' is added by the translator to make explicit a quality or effect of the heat, which might be implied by the context of a planet closer to the sun being favorable to 'Amours,' but is not explicitly stated in the source.

The French 'un petit Peuple' (a small/little people/folk) within the phrase 'un petit Peuple noir, brûlé du Soleil' is translated as part of 'a sort of little Sun-burnt Gentlemen.' The addition of 'Gentlemen' makes explicit a certain social standing or refinement for the inhabitants of Venus that is not present in the more general term 'Peuple.'

The translator expands the list of activities from the French 'Festes, des Danses, & des Tournois' (Feasts, Dances, and Tournaments) to 'Feasts, Balls and Masquerades.' The addition of 'Masquerades' introduces a specific type of festivity not mentioned in the source list.

The translator adds the clause 'to entertain their Mistresses.' This makes explicit the purpose of the Venusians inventing festivities (described in the source as 'inventant tous les jours des Festes, des Danses, & des Tournois.'), a purpose which was only implied by the broader amorous context of Venus in the source text.

chunks.source_manual: <P058>Mais que sera-ce des Habitants de Mercure? Ils sont encore plus proches du Soleil; il faut qu'ils soient fous à force de vivacité. <UP></UP> Je croy qu'ils n'ont point de memoire, non plus que la plupart des Négres; qu'ils ne font jamais de reflexion sur rien, qu'ils n'agissent qu'à l'aventure, & par des mouvemens subits, & <IIM>qu'enfin c'est dans Mercure que sont les Petites Maisons de l'Univers.</IIM> <NCE></NCE> Ils voyent le Soleil beaucoup plus grand que nous ne le voyons, parce qu'ils en sont beaucoup plus proches. Il leur envoye une lumiere si forte, que s'ils estoient icy, ils ne prendroient nos plus beaux jours que pour de <IIM>tres-foibles</IIM> Crepuscules, & peut-estre n'y pourroient-ils pas distinguer les objets, & la chaleur à laquelle ils sont accoûtumez est si excessive, que celle qu'il fait icy au fond de l'Afrique, suffiroit pour les glacier. Leur année n'est que de trois mois. La durée de leur jour ne nous est point encore connuë, parce que Mercure est si petit & si proche du Soleil, dans les rayons duquel il est presque toûjours perdu, qu'il échappe à toute l'adresse des Astronomes, & qu'on n'a pû encore avoir assez de prise sur luy, pour observer le mouvement qu'il doit avoir sur son centre; mais sa petitesse fait croire qu'il acheve ce tour en peu de temps; que par consequent le jour de Mercure est fort court, & que les Habitans voyent le Soleil comme un <RW>grand poêle ardent</RW>, peu éloigné de leurs testes, & qui va d'une rapidité prodigieuse. Cela en est mieux pour eux, car apparemment ils soûpirent aprés la nuit. Ils sont éclairez pendant ce temps-là de Venus,& de la Terre, qui leur doivent paroistre assez grandes. Pour les autres Planetes, comme elles sont au-delà de la <IIM>Terre vers le Firmament</IIM>, ils les voyent plus petites que nous ne les voyons, & n'en reçoivent que bien peu de lumiere, peut-estre n'en reçoivent-ils point du tout. Les Etoles Fixes sont aussi plus petites pour eux, & même il doit y en avoir beaucoup qui disparoissent entierement; c'est, selon moy, une perte. Je suis bien fàché de voir cette <RW>grande voûte ornée de mois d'Etoiles, & de ne voir celles qui me resteroient</RW>, que plus petites, & d'une couleur plus effacée. <SC></SC>.</P058>
chunks.target_manual: <P044>But what then must the Inhabitants of Mercury be, for they are yet more near to the Sun? They must certainly be mad, by having too much Light and Fire; and I believe they have no more Memory, than the most part of our Negroes; they never think, and are void of all Reflection, and they only act by Chance, and by sudden Impulses. In short, the Planet Mercury <IIM>must certainly be the Bethlem</IIM> of the Universe; they see the Sun a great deal bigger than we do, because they are so much nearer to it; he darts upon 'em so strong a Light, that if the Inhabitants of Venus were here, they wou'd take our finest Days for the Remains of a <IIM>saint</IIM> Twi-light; and it may be, the Light we enjoy, wou'd not serve them to distinguish one Object from another; and the Heat they are accustom'd to is so excessive, that the greatest warmth enjoy'd by the Inhabitants of the middle of Africk, wou'd frieze them to death. Their Year casts but three Months; the length of their Day is yet unknown, Mercury being so little a Planet, and so near the Sun, in whose Rays he is so continually lost, that he is hitherto scarce discoverable by <RW>the Art and Skill of</RW> Astronomers, who cou'd never yet get so much hold of Mercury, as to observe the Time in which he performs his Revolution <RW>upon his own Axis</RW> or Centre; but the smallness <UP>of his Planet</UP> perswades me 'tis in a very short time, and then, by consequence, his Days are very short, and his Inhabitants must see the Sun <RW>as a very great flaming Brasier</RW>, very near their Heads, which, to their Apprehension, moves with wonderful Rapidity; this makes them so earnestly wish for the coming Night, which, no doubt, must be much more grateful to 'em than the Day; and during those cooler Hours, they are enlightned by Venus, and by the Earth; which two Planets must appear to them of considerable bigness. As for the other Planets, since they are remov'd further than <IIM>Mercury </IIM>, towards the Firmament, his Inhabitants must see them less than they appear to us, and receive but little Light from 'em, it may be, none at all; the fixed Stars must appear less to 'em also, and they lose the sight of some of 'em entirely, which, in my Opinion, is a very great Loss; for I shou'd be very sorry to see <RW>the vast arch'd Roof of the Heavens</RW> adorn'd with fewer Stars, or those I do see, appear less, and not so bright.</P044>

explanations: The French 'à force de vivacité' (by dint of liveliness/brightness), implying the Sun's intense effect, is translated as 'by having too much Light and Fire.' The translator makes explicit that this 'vivacité' is caused by an excess of 'Light and Fire' from the Sun, information that was only implied.

The French idiom 'les Petites Maisons' (literally 'the Little Houses'), an old term for insane asylums, is translated as 'the Bethlem of the Universe.' 'Bethlem' (Bedlam) is the English historical equivalent. This substitution makes the implicit meaning of the French idiom explicit for an English reader by using a well-known cultural reference, thus re-writing for clarity.

The French 'peut-estre n'y pourroient-ils pas distinguer les objets' (perhaps they could not distinguish objects there [on Earth]) is translated by adding the clarifying phrase 'the Light we enjoy.' This addition makes explicit the implied reason—the insufficiency of Earth's light for Mercurians—why they might not distinguish objects.

The French 'l'adresse' (skill, cleverness, dexterity) is translated as 'the Art and Skill.' This expansion into a doublet makes the single concept of 'adresse' more emphatic and explicit by presenting it as two related facets, a common rhetorical device used for elaboration.

The French 'le mouvement qu'il doit avoir sur son centre' (the movement it must have on its center), referring to planetary rotation, is translated as 'the Time in which he performs his Revolution upon his own Axis or Centre.' The translation explicitly identifies the 'mouvement' as a 'Revolution upon his own Axis' and adds the observational goal ('the Time in which he performs' it), thus clarifying the specific astronomical concept and the aim of observation, which were more general in the source.

The French 'un grand poêle ardent' (a large ardent/burning stove or furnace) is translated as 'a very great flaming Brasier.' While 'ardent' (burning, glowing) implies fire, the addition of 'flaming' makes the presence of visible flames explicit, adding a specific visual detail that was only implied by 'ardent'.

The French 'qui va d'une rapidité prodigieuse' (which goes/moves with a prodigious rapidity), describing the Sun's apparent motion, is translated with the addition of 'to their Apprehension.' This phrase explicitly clarifies that the perceived speed is from the subjective viewpoint of Mercury's inhabitants, a nuance that was implicit in the original context.

The French 'ils soûpirent aprés la nuit' (they sigh for/long for the night) is expanded to 'they so earnestly wish for the coming Night, which, no doubt, must be much more grateful to 'em than the Day.' The added clause 'which, no doubt, must be much more grateful to 'em than the Day' explicitly states the reason for their longing (the night's pleasantness compared to the harsh day), a reason only implied in the source text.

The French 'pendant ce temps-là' (during that time), referring to night on Mercury, is translated as 'during those cooler Hours.' The addition of 'cooler Hours' makes explicit an implied characteristic of the night (its lower temperature compared to the described heat of Mercury's day), adding descriptive information about why the night would be desired.

The French 'cette grande voûte' (this large vault) is translated as 'the vast arch'd Roof of the Heavens.' The phrase 'of the Heavens' explicitly identifies the referent of 'voûte' as the celestial sphere. Additionally, 'vast arch'd Roof' expands and makes more descriptive the simpler 'grande voûte'.

The French 'd'une couleur plus effacée' (of a more faded/erased/indistinct color) is translated as 'not so bright.' The translation makes explicit the consequence of a 'faded color' in terms of luminosity, clarifying the visual impact as a reduction in brightness, which was implied by 'effacée'.

chunks.source_manual: <P059>Je ne suis pas si touchée, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, de cette perte-là que sont les <IIM>Habitans de Mercure</IIM>, que de l'incommodité qu'ils reçoivent de l'excés de la chaleur. Je voudrois bien que nous les soulageassions un peu. Donnons à Mercure de longues & d'abondantes pluyes qui le rafraischissent, comme on dit qu'il en tombe icy dans les Pays chauds pendant des quatre mois entiers, justement dans les saisons les plus chaudes.</P059> <P060>Cela se peut, repris-je, & mesme nous pouvons rafraîchir encore Mercure d'une autre façon. Il y a des Pays dans la Chine qui doivent estre tres-chauds par leur situation, & où il fait pourtant de grands froids pendant les mois de Juillet & d'Aoust, jusque-là que les Rivieres se gelent. C'est que ces contrées là ont beaucoup de Salpêtre; les exhalaisons en sont fort froides, & la force de la chaleur les fait sortir de la Terre en grande abondance. Mercure sera, si vous voulez, une petite Planete toute de <IIM>Salpêtre</IIM>, & le Soleil tirera d'elle-mesme le remede au mal qu'il luy pourroit faire. Ce qu'il y a de seur, c'est que la Nature ne sçauroit faire vivre les Gens qu'où ils peuvent vivre, & que l'habitude jointe à l'ignorance de quelque chose de meilleur, survient, & les y fait vivre agréablement. Ainsi on pourroit même se passer dans Mercure du <IIM>Salpêtre</IIM> & des pluyes.</P060>
chunks.target_manual: <P045>I am not so much concern'd for that Loss, said the Marquiese, as for <IIM>their</IIM> being so extreamly incommoded with excessive Heat; and I wish with all my heart, we cou'd ease 'em of that Trouble. Let us therefore allow 'em long and continued Rain, to refresh 'em; such as are in some of the hot Countries of our Earth, which fall for four Months together, during the hottest Seasons. That may be done, said I; but we may find out another Remedy, to relieve the Inhabitants of Mercury; for there are Countries in China, which, by their Situation, must be very hot; yet notwithstanding, the Cold is so excessive during the Months of Iuly and August, that the Rivers are frozen: The Reason is, These Climates abound with <IIM>Salt-Petre </IIM> (whose Exhalations being very cold) the force of the Heat draws out of the Earth in great abundance. Let us therefore suppose Mercury to be a little Planet, made of <IIM>Salt-Petre </IIM>; and let the Sun extract out of himself a Remedy to his Disease which he gives to the Inhabitants. This is certain, that Nature produces no Animal, but in places where they may live; and Custom and Use, joined with Ignorance of what is better, supplieth all Defects, and makes Life agreeable; for ought we know, the Inhabitants of Mercury want neither Rain, nor Exhalations of <IIM>Salt-Petre</IIM>.</P045>

explanations: The French 'icy' (here) is implicitly understood to mean 'on Earth' within the context of the conversation comparing Earth to other planets. The translator makes this explicit by translating it as 'of our Earth,' thereby removing potential ambiguity and reinforcing the Earth-bound perspective of the speaker.

The French 'qui le rafraischissent' means 'that refresh it' (referring to the planet Mercury). The translator changes this to 'to refresh 'em' (them, referring to the inhabitants of Mercury). This explicitly states that the refreshment is for the inhabitants, a consequence that was only implied by refreshing the planet in the source text.

The translator adds 'therefore' at the beginning of the clause 'Let us therefore allow 'em', corresponding to the French 'Donnons à Mercure'. This explicitly states the logical connection between the Marquise's preceding wish to relieve the inhabitants of Mercury and her subsequent proposal to give Mercury rain. In the French, this causal link is implied by the juxtaposition of the two sentences.

The French 'rafraîchir encore Mercure' (to further cool Mercury) focuses on the action on the planet. The English translation, in the context of finding 'another Remedy', explicitly adds the purpose 'to relieve the Inhabitants of Mercury.' This makes the direct benefit to the inhabitants explicit, whereas in the source, this benefit is an implied consequence of cooling the planet.

The French 'C'est que' introduces an explanation. Translating it as 'The Reason is,' explicitly signposts the subsequent clause as a direct explanation, making the rhetorical function more overt than the somewhat more subtle French construction which could also be translated as 'It is that' or 'Because'.

The French 'les exhalaisons en sont fort froides' states as a separate, albeit linked, clause that the exhalations from saltpetre are very cold. The English translation incorporates this information as a parenthetical phrase '(whose Exhalations being very cold)', directly modifying 'Salt-Petre'. This makes the characteristic of saltpetre (that its exhalations are cold, thus it can cool) more explicit and integrated into the description of saltpetre's properties as the reason for its cooling effect.

The French 'Mercure sera, si vous voulez,' (Mercury will be, if you like,) introduces a hypothetical scenario. The English translation 'Let us therefore suppose Mercury to be' adds 'therefore,' explicitly linking this new hypothesis (Mercury being made of Salt-Petre) as a consequence or a next step in the reasoning aimed at solving the problem of Mercury's heat, a connection that was implicit in the French sequence of thoughts.

The French 'le remede au mal qu'il luy pourroit faire.' (the remedy to the harm/ill that it [the Sun] could do to it [Mercury]) focuses on the harm done to the planet Mercury. The English translation 'a Remedy to his Disease which he gives to the Inhabitants.' rephrases 'mal' (harm/ill) as 'Disease' and explicitly adds 'which he gives to the Inhabitants,' clarifying that the remedy (and implicitly the suffering from the 'disease') pertains directly to the inhabitants, not just the planet abstractly. This makes the anthropocentric concern explicit.

The French 'Gens' (people, folk) is translated as 'Animal.' While 'Gens' in this context refers to the inhabitants of planets, 'Animal' makes explicit the biological classification of these beings, broadening the scope from potentially just rational/human-like beings to any living creature. This emphasizes the biological aspect of adaptation, a common theme in natural philosophy, adding a layer of scientific specification not as overt in 'Gens'.

The French 'l'habitude' (habit, custom) is translated and expanded to 'Custom and Use.' This expansion clarifies that 'habitude' encompasses both societal norms ('Custom') and ingrained personal behaviors/practices ('Use'), making the dual nature of this adaptive mechanism more explicit by spelling out distinct facets of the single French concept.

The French 'survient' (arises, intervenes, comes along) describes habit and ignorance as factors that emerge and, in conjunction with '& les y fait vivre agréablement' (and makes them live there agreeably), enable a pleasant life. The English translation replaces 'survient' and its implied positive outcome with 'supplieth all Defects,' which explicitly states the *mechanism* or *function* by which habit and ignorance achieve this positive outcome. This adds clarifying information about how these factors operate, which was only implied in the source.

The French 'Ainsi on pourroit même se passer dans Mercure du Salpêtre & des pluyes.' (Thus one could even do without saltpeter and rains in Mercury.) presents a logical conclusion based on the preceding argument about adaptation. The English 'for ought we know, the Inhabitants of Mercury want neither Rain, nor Exhalations of Salt-Petre.' shifts the basis of this statement from a logical deduction to an expression of epistemic uncertainty. It explicitly highlights the limits of the speaker's knowledge regarding the actual needs of Mercury's inhabitants, a qualification not directly present in the more assertive 'Ainsi' (thus) of the source, thereby altering the rhetorical stance.

chunks.source_manual: <P061>Aprés Mercure vous sçavez qu'on trouve le Soleil. Il n'y a pas moyen d'y mettre d'Habitans. Le Pourquoy non nous manque-là. Nous jugeons par la Terre qui est habitée, que les autres Corps de la mesme espece qu'elle, doivent l'estre aussi; mais le Soleil n'est point un Corps de la mesme espece que la Terre, ny que les autres Planetes. Il est la source de toute cette lumiere que les Planetes ne font que se renvoyer les unes aux autres, aprés l'avoir reçeüe de luy. Elles ne peuvent faire, pour ainsi dire, des échanges entre elles, mais elles ne la peuvent produire. Luy seul tire de soy-mesme cette pretieuse substance; il la pousse avec force de tous costez; de là elle revient à la rencontre de tout ce qui est solide, & d'une Planete à l'autre il s'épand de longues & vastes traisnées de lumieres qui se croisent & se traversent, & s'entrelassent en mille façons diferentes, & forment d'admirables tissus de la plus riche matiere qui soit au monde. Aussi le Soleil est-il placé dans le centre, qui est le lieu le plus commode d'où il la puisse distribuer également, & animer tout par sa chaleur <NCP></NCP>. Le Soleil est donc un Corps <UP>particulier</UP>, mais quelle sorte de Corps? On est bien embarrassé à le dire. On avoit toûjours crû que c'estoit un feu tres-pur, mais on s'en desabusa au commencement de ce <IIM>Siecle</IIM>, qu'on apperceut des taches sur sa surface. Comme on avoit découvert peu de temps auparavant de nouvelles Planetes dont je vous parleray; que tout le <IIM>Monde Philosophe</IIM> n'avoit l'esprit remply d'autre chose, & qu'enfin les nouvelles Planetes s'estoient mises à la mode, on jugea aussi-tost que ces taches en estoient; <UP>qu'elles avoyent un mouvement autour du Soleil</UP>, & qu'elles nous en cachoient necessairement quelque partie, en tournant leur moitié obscure vers nous. Déja les Sçavans faisoient leur Cour de ces pretendües Planetes à tous les Princes de l'Europe. Les uns leur donnoient le nom d'un Prince, les autres d'un autre, & peut-estre il y auroit eu querelle entre-eux à qui seroit demeuré le maistre des taches pour les nommer comme il eust voulu...</P061>
chunks.target_manual: <P046>After Mercury, you know, the next Planet we find in our Journey, is the Sun; and if we judge by the Earth <NCP>(which is inhabited)</NCP> that other Bodies of the same kind may be so too, we are mistaken, and the Why not will fail us here; for the Sun is a Body of a quite different Nature from the Earth, and other Planets: He is the Source and Fountain of all that Light, which the other Planets do only reflect from one to another, after having receiv'd it from him; and so they can exchange Light one with another, but are incapable of producing it: The Sun alone draws from it self this precious Substance, which he darts a-round him with great Force and Violence, and which is intercepted by every Body that is solid; so that there is reflected from one Planet to another long streams and streaks of Light, which crossing and traversing each other in the Air, are interwoven a thousand different Ways, and so form a Mixture of the richest substance in Nature: For this end the Sun is plac'd in the Centre, which is the Situation most proper and commode; from whence he may equally dispense and distribute his Light and Heat, for the livening and enlightning all things round him. The Sun is therefore a Body of a particular Substance; but what kind of Body, or what kind of Substance, is all the difficulty: Heretofore 'twas believ'd, that the Sun was a pure Fire; but the Error of this Opinion was found out in the Beginning of this Age, by Spots which were discover'd upon the Surface of the Sun; as a little after that time, there were new Planets discover'd, of which I shall speak hereafter: The learned part of the World were full of nothing else but these new Planets; and Discourses of 'em were so much in fashion, that they believ'd the Spots in the Sun were nothing else but these new Planets, moving round 'em, which necessarily hid a part of his Body from our sight, when their obscure Side was turn'd towards us. The learned Men of the World made their Court to most Kings and Princes, with these new discover'd Planets; giving the Name of one Prince to one, and of another Prince to another; so that they were like to quarrel, to whom they shou'd belong.</P046>

the Error of this Opinion was found out
the Spots in the Sun were nothing else but these new Planets, moving round 'em,
explanations: The French "on trouve le Soleil" (literally, "one finds the Sun") is translated as "the next Planet we find in our Journey, is the Sun." The translator makes explicit: 1) The agent "on" (one) as "we" (the speaker and the Marquise). 2) The context of "finding" as being "in our Journey," clarifying their discussion is a metaphorical exploration. 3) A sequential descriptor "the next Planet" is added before "the Sun," framing it as the subsequent item in their celestial tour for the layperson, even though the Sun is a star. These additions spell out aspects of the narrative context and simplify the classification for the dialogue's flow.

The French "Source" (Source), referring to the Sun as the origin of light, is translated as "Source and Fountain." The addition of "and Fountain" expands on the original by explicitly evoking a more vivid image of a continuous, abundant, and outpouring supply of light, making the implied profusion of light from the sun more concrete.

The French "des échanges" (exchanges) is used in the context of planets reflecting light received from the sun. The translation "exchange Light" makes the object of these exchanges, "Light," explicit, whereas in the source it was implied by the preceding discussion of "lumiere" (light).

The French "avec force" (with force), describing how the sun emits light, is translated as "with great Force and Violence." The additions of "great" and "and Violence" explicitly intensify the description and characterize the nature of this force, suggesting a powerful and intense emission that was only generally implied by the word "force" alone.

The French phrase describes light spreading and interweaving from one planet to another without specifying the medium. The English translation adds "in the Air," explicitly naming the medium through which these light phenomena are described as occurring. The source text leaves this medium (space or the void) implicit.

The French adverb "Aussi" (in this context meaning Thus, Therefore, And so), which links the Sun's function to its position, is translated as "For this end." This explicitly introduces a teleological explanation for the Sun's central placement, framing it as being purposefully situated to achieve the effect of distributing light and heat, an idea that was more subtly implied in the original.

The source states the Sun can "distribuer également" (distribute equally - implicitly its light) and "animer tout par sa chaleur" (animate everything by its heat). The translation "equally dispense and distribute his Light and Heat, for the livening and enlightning all things round him" makes several implicit elements explicit: "Light" becomes an explicit object of distribution alongside "Heat"; "animer tout" (animate everything) is expanded to "livening and enlightning all things round him," which adds "enlightning" as a distinct effect (linked to light) and specifies the spatial scope of "tout" (everything) as "all things round him."

The French "un Corps particulier" (a particular Body), referring to the Sun, is translated as "a Body of a particular Substance." The addition of "of a particular Substance" explicitly clarifies the respect in which the Sun's body is considered "particular" or unique, a specification that was implied but not detailed in the source.

Following the previous explicitation of "Substance," the French question "quelle sorte de Corps?" (what kind of Body?) is expanded in the translation to "what kind of Body, or what kind of Substance,". The addition of "or what kind of Substance" explicitly broadens the inquiry, directly referencing the translator's earlier addition and making the focus of the philosophical difficulty more specific.

The French phrase "on s'en desabusa" (one was disabused of it/that idea) is an impersonal construction referring to the previous belief about the sun being pure fire. The translation "the Error of this Opinion was found out" makes explicit both the specific referent of "en" (it) as "this Opinion" and the nature of being "desabusé" as the discovery of an "Error."

The French "ces taches en estoient" (literally, "these spots were of them" or "were them," implying the spots were new planets) is translated with the additional clarifying phrase "moving round 'em" (i.e., the Sun), within the larger clause "they believ'd the Spots in the Sun were nothing else but these new Planets, moving round 'em,". This addition explicitly describes the hypothesized orbital motion of these "new Planets" (the spots), which would explain their appearance. This mechanism was implied by identifying them as planets in this context but is spelled out in the translation.

chunks.source_manual: <P062>Je ne trouve point cela bon, interrompit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>. Vous me disiez l'autre jour qu'on avoit donné aux differentes parties de la Lune des noms de Sçavans & d'Astronomes, & j'en estois fort contente. Puis que les Princes prennent pour eux la Terre, il est juste que les Sçavans se reservent le Ciel, & y dominent, mais ils n'en devroient point permettre l'entrée à d'autres. Souffrez, répondis-je, <UP></UP> qu'ils puissent, du moins en cas de besoin, engager aux Princes quelque Astre, ou quelque partie de la Lune. Quant aux taches du Soleil, ils n'en purent faire aucun usage. Il se trouva que ce n'estoient point des Planetes, mais des nuages, des fumées, des écumes, qui s'élèvent sur le Soleil. Elles sont tantost en grande quantité, tantost en petit nombre; tantost elles disparoissent toutes, quelquefois elles se mettent plusieurs ensemble, quelquefois elles se separent, quelquefois elles sont plus claires, quelquefois plus noires. Il y a des temps où l'on en voit beaucoup, il y en a d'autres, & mesme assez longs, où il n'en paroist aucune. Il semble que le Soleil soit une matiere liquide, quelques-uns disent de l'Or fondu, qui boüillonne incessamment <NCP></NCP>, & produit des impuretez, qui par la force de son mouvement sont rejettées sur sa surface. Elles s'y consument, & puis il s'en produit d'autres. Imaginez-vous quels Corps étrangers ce sont là. Il y en a tel qui est peut-estre aussi grand que la Terre. Jugez par là quelle est la quantité de cet Or fondu, ou l'étenduë de cette grande Mer de lumiere & de feu qu'on appelle le Soleil. D'autres disent que le Soleil paroît avec des Lunettes tout plein de Montagnes qui vomissent des flâmes, & que c'est comme un million de Monts Etna mis ensemble, mais on dit aussi que ces Montagnes sont une pure vision, causée par quelque chose qui arrive dans les Lunettes. Aquoy se fiera-t-on, s'il faut se défier des Lunettes mesme, ausquelles nous devons la connoissance de tant de nouveaux objects. Enfin, quoy que ce puisse estre que le Soleil, il ne paroist nullement propre à estre habité. C'est pourtant dommage, l'habitation seroit belle. On seroit au centre de tout, on verroit toutes les Planetes tourner regulierement autour de soy, au lieu que nous voyons dans leur cours une infinité de bizareries, qui n'y paroissent que parce que nous ne sommes pas en le lieu propre pour en bien juger, c'est à dire, au centre de leur mouvement. Cela n'est-il pas pitoyable? Il n'y a qu'un lieu dans le Monde, d'où l'étude des Astres puisse estre extremément facile, & justement dans ce lieu-là, il n'y a personne. Vous n'y songez pas, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>. Qui seroit dans le Soleil, verroit rien, ny Planetes, ny Etoiles Fixes. Le Soleil n'efface-t-il pas tout? Ce seroient ses Habitans qui seroient bien fondez à se croire seuls dans toute la Nature.</P062>
chunks.target_manual: <P047>I am not pleas'd with that at all, said the Marquiese: You told me the other Night, that the Philosophers and learned Men had given Names of Philosophers, Astronomers and Mathematicians to the several Countries of the Moon, and I was very well satisfy'd, and think it but just, that since the Kings and Princes possess the Earth, that they ought to suffer Philosophers and Astronomers to rule in the Moon and the Stars, without incroaching upon 'em. What, said I, Madam, Will not you allow Kings and Princes some Corner of the Moon, or some Star, to take their part in time of need? As to the Spots in the Sun, they can be of no manner of use to 'em; for it has been found, they are not Planets, but Clouds of Smoak and Vapours, and, as it were, a Scum arising from the Surface of the Sun; for sometimes they appear in great Quantities, sometimes in less, and at other times they dis-appear; sometimes they join in one, and other times they are dispers'd and dissipated; so that it shou'd seem, the Sun is a liquid Substance; some say, 'tis of melted Gold, <UP>which boils incessantly, and produces those Impurities</UP>; and by the force of its Motion, throws upon the Surface its Scum and Dross; and as those consume, new ones are produc'd. Pray, Madam, fansie to your self what strange Bodies these Spots of the Sun must be; there are some of 'em full as big as the Globe of the Earth; judge then what a great quantity there must be of this melted Gold, and of the Extent of this vast Ocean of Light and Fire, which we call the Sun. They say, the Sun appears, through Telescopes, to be full of great Mountains which vomit Flames, and that it is, as it were, a Million of Mount Aetna's, join'd together; but at the same time they acknowledge that these Mountains may be altogether visionary, and that they are nothing else but the Effects of the Glasses of the Telescopes. To whom shall we trust then, when these very Glasses, to which we owe so many new Discoveries, deceive us? In fine, Let the Sun be what it will, it does not at all seem proper to be inhabited; and yet 'tis pity, for the Situation wou'd be extreamly fine; its Inhabitants wou'd be plac'd in the Centre of the Universe, and wou'd see all the other Planets turn regularly round 'em, whereas we observe infinite Irregularities in their Course; and 'tis only because we are not in a proper Situation to consider 'em, as not being in the Centre of their Motion. Is it not hard, that there is but one place in the Universe, where the Study of the Stars wou'd be easie, and that that place alone shou'd be uninhabitable? You do not think, whilst you speak, said the Marquiese, were any living Creature in the Sun, he wou'd see neither Planets, nor fixed Stars; nor, indeed, any thing; the brightness of the Sun wou'd render all things else invisible; and if there were Inhabitants in the Sun, they wou'd be apt to believe themselves the only People in Nature.</P047>

explanations: The indefinite French pronoun "on" (one/they) is translated as "the Philosophers and learned Men," making explicit who is understood to be performing the action of naming the parts of the Moon.

The French phrase "des noms de Sçavans & d'Astronomes" (names of scholars & astronomers) is expanded in the translation to "Names of Philosophers, Astronomers and Mathematicians." While "Sçavans" (scholars) can encompass these fields, the target text explicitly lists them, making the categories of individuals whose names are used more specific than in the source.

The French "aux differentes parties de la Lune" (to the different parts of the Moon) is translated as "to the several Countries of the Moon." This specifies "parties" (parts) as "Countries," implying distinct, named regions similar to terrestrial geography, thus making the nature of these lunar divisions more explicit.

The general French term "le Ciel" (the Heaven/Sky) is translated as "the Moon and the Stars." This explicitation specifies the particular celestial domains that the "Sçavans" (scholars) are said to reserve for themselves.

The French phrase "sur le Soleil" (on the Sun) is rendered as "from the Surface of the Sun." This translation clarifies the location of the phenomena (clouds, smoke, scum) by explicitly stating they arise from the sun's exterior layer.

The French "elles se separent" (they separate) referring to sunspots is translated as "they are dispers'd and dissipated." This expansion makes explicit the manner and consequence of the sunspots' separation, implying they not only move apart ("dispers'd") but also break up or vanish ("dissipated").

The general French term "des impuretez" (impurities) produced by the Sun is translated as "its Scum and Dross." This choice of words makes explicit the specific nature of the impurities, linking them to the idea of molten material (like the mentioned "melted Gold") by using terms associated with metallurgy or boiling liquids.

The French phrase "Corps étrangers" (foreign/strange bodies) is expanded to "strange Bodies these Spots of the Sun must be." This addition explicitly identifies these "bodies" as the sunspots currently under discussion, a connection that was implicit in the conversational flow of the French text.

The French term "la Terre" (the Earth) is translated as "the Globe of the Earth." This addition of "the Globe of" explicitly refers to the Earth's spherical form, emphasizing its nature as a planet, which aligns with the scientific and astronomical context of the discussion.

The French word "Lunettes" (literally 'glasses'), used in the context of astronomical observation, is translated as "Telescopes." This makes explicit the specific type of optical instrument implied by Fontenelle, clarifying for the reader that it refers to telescopes for observing celestial bodies, not eyeglasses.

The somewhat vague French phrase "quelque chose qui arrive dans les Lunettes." (something that happens in the glasses/telescopes) is translated as "the Effects of the Glasses of the Telescopes." This makes explicit that the "something" refers to optical effects or distortions originating specifically from the lenses ("Glasses") of the telescopes, rather than an unspecified occurrence.

The French phrase "la connoissance de tant de nouveaux objects" (the knowledge of so many new objects) is translated as "so many new Discoveries." This shifts the emphasis from the state of knowing to the active process of finding or learning about these new objects, making explicit the act of scientific discovery implied by gaining knowledge through telescopes.
The indefinite French pronoun "On" (one/people) in "On seroit au centre de tout" is made explicit in the translation as "its Inhabitants," clearly referring to hypothetical beings living on the Sun.

The French phrase "au centre de tout" (at the center of everything) is translated as "in the Centre of the Universe." This specifies the general and potentially ambiguous "tout" (everything) as "the Universe," making the intended cosmological scope explicit.

The French term "le Monde" (the World), which in the 17th century could ambiguously refer to the Earth or the cosmos, is translated as "the Universe." This explicitly clarifies that Fontenelle refers to the entire cosmos in this astronomical context, not just the Earth.

The French phrase "il n'y a personne" (there is no one there/nobody is there) is rendered as "that place alone shou'd be uninhabitable." This translation makes explicit the *reason* for the absence of people by stating the inherent quality of the place (the Sun) as being uninhabitable.

The French expression "Vous n'y songez pas" (You don't think about it / You're not considering it) is expanded to "You do not think, whilst you speak." The addition of "whilst you speak" makes explicit the implication that the oversight or lack of consideration is occurring in the immediate act of speaking.

The general French pronoun "Qui" (Whoever/Anyone who) in the phrase "Qui seroit dans le Soleil" (Whoever might be in the Sun) is translated as "any living Creature." This specification makes explicit the nature of the hypothetical entity being discussed, clarifying that it is a living being.

The French sentence "verroit rien, ny Planetes, ny Etoiles Fixes." (would see nothing, neither Planets, nor Fixed Stars) is restructured and expanded to "he wou'd see neither Planets, nor fixed Stars; nor, indeed, any thing;". The concluding phrase "nor, indeed, any thing" explicitly re-emphasizes the totality of the invisibility, making the scope of "rien" (nothing) absolutely clear as covering all visual perception.

The French rhetorical question "Le Soleil n'efface-t-il pas tout?" (Doesn't the Sun erase/blot out everything?) is translated into an explanatory declarative statement: "the brightness of the Sun wou'd render all things else invisible;". This makes explicit *how* the Sun "erases" (through its brightness) and what "erasing everything" means in this visual context (rendering other things invisible).

The French emphatic construction "Ce seroient ses Habitans qui seroient bien fondez à se croire" (It would be its inhabitants who would be well-founded to believe) is rephrased with an explicit conditional clause: "and if there were Inhabitants in the Sun, they wou'd be apt to believe themselves". This spells out the hypothetical premise (inhabitants on the Sun) which was more implicitly carried over from the preceding sentence in the French.

chunks.source_manual: <P063>J'avoüe que je m'estois trompé, répondis-je, je ne songeois qu'à la situation où est le Soleil,& non à l'effet de sa lumiere; mais vous qui me redressez si à propos, vous voulez bien que je vous dise que vous vous estes trompée aussi; les Habitans du Soleil ne le verroient seulement pas. Ou ils ne pourroient soûtenir la force de sa lumiere, ou ils ne la pourroient recevoir, faute d'en estre à quelque distance, & tout bien considéré, le Soleil ne seroit qu'un séjour d'Aveugles; encore un coup, il n'est pas fait pour estre habité; mais voulez-vous que nous poursuivions nostre Voyage des Mondes? Nous sommes arrivéz au centre qui est toûjours le lieu le plus bas dans tout ce qui est rond, il faudroit presentement retourner sur nos pas, & remonter. Nous retrouverons Mercure, Venus, la Terre, la Lune, toutes Planetes que nous avons visitées. Ensuite c'est Mars qui se presente. Mars n'a rien de curieux que je sçache, ses jours ne sont pas d'une heure entiere plus longs que les nostres; ses années valent deux de nos années. Il est plus petit que la Terre, il voit le Soleil un peu moins grand & moins vif que nous ne le voyons; enfin Mars ne vaut pas trop la peine qu'on s'y arreste. Mais la jolie chose que Jupiter avec ses quatre Lunes ou <RW>Satellites</RW>! Ce sont quatre petites Planetes qui tournent autour de luy, comme nostre Lune tourne autour de nous. Mais, interrompit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, pourquoy y a-t-il des Planetes qui tournent autour d'autres Planetes qui ne valent pas mieux qu'elles? Serieusement il me paroîtroit plus regulier & plus uniforme que toutes les Planetes, grandes & petites, n'eussent que le mesme mouvement autour du Soleil!</P063> <P064>Ah! Madame, répliquay-je! Si vous sçaviez ce que c'est que les <RW><NCP>Tourbillons</NCP></RW> de Descartes, ces Tourbillons dont le nom est si terrible, & l'idée si agreable, vous ne parleriez pas comme vous faites. La teste me dust-elle tourner, dit-elle en riant, il est beau de sçavoir ce que c'est que les Tourbillons. Achevez de me rendre folle, je ne me ménage plus, je ne connois plus de retenuë sur la Philosophie; laissons parler le monde, & donnons-nous aux Tourbillons. Je ne vous connoissois pas de pareils emportemens, répris-je; c'est dommage qu'ils n'ayent que les Tourbillons pour objet. Ce qu'on appelle un Tourbillon, c'est un amas de matiere dont les parties sont détachées les unes des autres, & se meuvent toutes en un mesme sens; permis à elles d'avoir pendant ce temps-là quelques petites mouvemens particuliers, pourveu qu'elles suivent toûjours le mouvement general. Ainsi un Tourbillon de vent <UP></UP>, c'est une infinité de petites parties d'air, qui tournent en rond toutes ensemble, & enveloppent ce qu'elles rencontrent. Vous sçavez que les Planetes sont portées dans la matiere celeste, qui est d'une subtilité, & d'une agitation prodigieuse. Tout ce grand amas de matiere celeste, qui est depuis le Soleil <UP></UP>jusqu'aux Etoiles fixes, tourne en rond, & emportant avec soy les Planetes <UP></UP>, les fait tourner toutes en un mesme sens autour du Soleil, qui occupe le centre; mais en des temps plus ou moins longs, selon qu'elles en sont plus ou moins éloignées. Il n'y a pas jusqu'au Soleil qui ne tourne; mais il ne tourne que sur luy-mesme, parce qu'il est justement au milieu de toute cette <IIM>matiere celeste</IIM>; & vous remarquerez en passant, que quand la Terre seroit dans la place où il est, elle ne pourroit encore faire moins que de tourner sur elle-mesme.</P064> <P065>Voila quel est le grand Tourbillon dont le Soleil est comme le Maistre; mais en mesme temps les Planetes se composent de petits Tourbillons particuliers à l'imitation de celuy du Soleil. Chacune d'elles en tournant autour du Soleil, ne laisse pas de tourner autour d'elle-mesme, & fait tourner aussi autour d'elle en mesme sens une certaine quantité de cette matiere celeste, qui est toûjours preste à suivre tous les mouvemens qu'on luy veut donner, s'ils ne la détournent pas de son mouvement general. c'est-là le Tourbillon particulier de la Planete & elle le pousse aussi loin que la force de son mouvement se peut étendre. S'il faut qu'il tombe dans ce petit Tourbillon quelque Planete moindre que celle qui y domine, la voilà emportée par la grande, & forcée indispensablement à tourner autour d'elle, & le tout ensemble, la grande Planete, la petite, & le Tourbillon qui les renferme, n'en tourne pas moins autour du Soleil. C'est ainsi qu'au commencement du Monde nous nous fismes suivre par la Lune, parce qu'elle se trouva dans l'étenduë de nostre Tourbillon, & tout à fait à nostre bienséance. Jupiter dont je commençois à vous parler, fut plus heureux ou plus puissant que nous. Il y avoit dans son voisinage quatre petites Planetes, ils se les assujettit toutes quatre, & <UP></UP> nous qui sommes une Planete principale, croyez-vous que nous l'eussions esté, si nous nous fussions trouvés proches de luy? Il est quatre-vingt-dix fois plus gros que nous, il nous auroit engloutis sans peine dans son Tourbillon, & nous ne serions qu'une Lune de sa dépendance, au lieu que nous en avons une qui est dans la nostre, tant il est vray que le seul hazard de la situation décide souvent de toute la fortune qu'on doit avoir.</P065> <P066>Et qui nous assure, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, que nous demeurerons toûjours où nous sommes? Je commence à craindre que nous ne fassions la folie de nous approcher d'une Planete aussi entreprenante que Jupiter, ou qu'il <IIM>ne vienne</IIM> vers nous pour nous absorber; car il me paroist que dans ce grand mouvement, où vous dites qu'est la matiere Celeste, elle devroit agiter les Planetes irregulierement, tantost les approcher, tantost les éloigner les unes des autres. <UP>Nous pourrions aussi-tost y gagner qu'y perdre, répondis-je</UP>, peut-estre irions-nous soumettre à nostre domination Mercure & Venus, qui sont de petites Planetes, & qui ne nous pourroient résister. Mais nous n'avons rien à esperer ny à craindre; les Planetes se tiennent où elles sont, & les nouvelles conquestes leur sont défenduës, comme elles l'étoient autrefois aux Rois de la Chine. Vous sçavez bien que quand on met de l'huile avec de l'eau, l'huile surnage. Qu'on mette sur ces deux liqueurs un Corps extremement leger <UP></UP>, l'huile le soûtiendra, & il n'ira pas jusqu'à l'eau. Qu'on y mette un autre Corps plus pesant, & qui soit justement d'une certaine pesanteur, il passera au travers de l'huile, qui sera trop foible pour l'arrester, & tombera jusqu'à ce qu'il rencontre l'eau, qui aura la force de le soûtenir. Ainsi dans cette liqueur composée de deux liqueurs qui ne se mêlent point, deux Corps inégalement pesants se mettent naturellement à deux places differentes, & jamais l'un ne montera, ny l'autre ne descendra. Qu'on mette encore d'autres liqueurs qui se tiennent separées, & qu'on y plonge d'autres corps, il arrivera la mesme chose. Representez-vous que la Matiere Celeste qui remplit ce grand Tourbillon, à differentes couches qui s'envelopent les unes les autres, & dont les pesanteurs sont differentes, comme celles de l'huile & de l'eau, & des autres liqueurs. Les Planetes ont aussi differentes pesanteurs; chacune d'elles par consequent s'arreste dans la couche qui a précisément la force necessaire pour la soûtenir, & qui luy fait équilibre, & vous voyez bien qu'il n'est pas possible qu'elle en sorte jamais.</P066>
chunks.target_manual: <P048>I confess, said I, I am mistaken, I consider'd only the Situation of the Sun, without the Effects of its Light. But, pray, Madam, allow me to tell you, that you who have corrected me so justly, may also be mistaken your self: The Inhabitants of the Sun wou'd not so much as see it self; for they wou'd be incapable to support the dazling of his Light, or unable to receive it, by being too near; and all things well consider'd, the Sun wou'd be a Country of blind Men only. So that, once for all, I conclude, the Sun cannot be inhabited; and if you please, Madam, we will continue our Journey to the other Worlds: We are now come to the Centre, which is the lowest Point in all Circular Figures; and therefore must return back again, and go upwards. In the Way, we shall find Mercury, Venus, the Earth, and the Moon; all which Planets we have visited.</P048> <P049>The next that presents it self to our Observation is Mars, who contains nothing rare or curious that I know of: His Days are not a full Hour longer than ours, but his Years are double the length of ours. Mars is less than the Earth, and his Inhabitants see the Sun neither so big, nor so bright as we do. In short, Mars is not worthy the pains of a longer Discourse; but 'tis very curious to observe Iupiter, and his four Moons, or <RW>Guards</RW>: they are four little Planets, which turn round Iupiter, as our Moon turns round us. But, says the Marquiese, interrupting me, why are there some Planets attending upon others, who, it may be, are no better than themselves? In my Opinion, it wou'd be more regular and uniform if all the Planets, great and small, had but one Motion round the Sun. Ah, Madam! said I; if you understood the Tourbillions, or Whistlings of Monsieur Des Cartes, whose Name is so terrible, and Idea's so agreeable, you wou'd not talk at that rate. Let my Brains turn round, said she, laughing, if they will; I long to know what these Tourbillions are; make haste therefore to satisfie me, I'll manage my self no longer, but henceforth abandon all my Thoughts to Philosophy, without Reserve, let the World talk what they please; but let me understand these Whirling's. I did not think you capable of such Transports, said I, Madam; and I am sorry they have not a fitter Object: But to satisfie you, a Tourbillion is a heap of Matter, whose parts are disjoin'd one from another, yet moving round all one way; each little part being allow'd a particular Motion of its own, provided always they do not obstruct the general Circular Motion. As for Example; A Tourbillion of Air, <UP>call'd a Whirl-wind, or a Hurricain</UP>, is an infinite quantity of little Particles of Air, turning all round together, carrying along every thing they meet with in their way: You know that the Planets are carry'd round in the Celestial Matter, which is incredibly subtile and swift; all that <UP>vast Ocean,</UP> and Mass of Celestial Substance, which is between the Sun, <UP>and the Sphere</UP> of the fixed Stars, turns round, and carries with it the Planets one way, <UP>from East to West,</UP> round the Sun, which is plac'd in the Centre; but in shorter or longer time, as they are distant or nearer the Centre, all things turn round, even the Sun it self; but he turns round upon his own Axis: And you are to observe thus; if the Earth were in the middle of the Celestial Matter, as the Sun is, she wou'd also turn round upon her own Axis, like that: This is that great Tourbillion, of which the Sun is, as it were, Governor; but at the same time, all the Planets have little Whirlings peculiar to themselves, in imitation of that great one, the Sun; notwithstanding, they are all carry'd round the Sun, yet every one of them turns round upon his own Axis, and sweeps along with him a share of the Celestial Substance, which yields easily to any Impulse of Motion it receives, provided that does not obstruct its general Motion round the Sun; and this is call'd the particular Whirling, or Tourbillion of a Planet, which extends as far as <UP>the Sphere of its Activity</UP> can reach; and if it falls so out, that any lesser Planet than that which governs the Tourbillion comes in its way, 'tis carry'd with it, and indispensably forc'd round it; but yet that does not hinder both the greater Planet, and the lesser, with their Whirlings, to turn round with the great Tourbillion of the Sun. 'Twas thus that, after the Creation of the Universe, the Earth carry'd the Moon round it self, because the Moon fell within the Extent or Sphere of Activity, and forc'd its Obedience. Iupiter, of whom I have said somewhat already, was happier or stronger than we; there fell four little Planets in his Neighbourhood, and he subdu'd 'em all four: Our Earth, which is now a chief Planet, had it fallen within the Tourbillion of Iupiter, you may easily believe he wou'd have forc'd us to have turn'd round him also, Iupiter being ninety times bigger than our Earth; and then we had been nothing but a Moon depending upon Iupiter, whereas now the Earth has a Moon of her own turning round her: So true it is, that Chance of Situation has decided our Fortune. Pray, what Assurance have we, said the Marquiese, that our Earth shall always remain in the same Situation? I am afraid we may make a Trip one Day or other, towards some Planet as dangerous as Iupiter, who may sweep us round with it self; or that some other stronger Planet may approach nearer to us; for I fansie, that the violent Motions of the heavenly Matter you speak of, may agitate and shake the Planets so irregularly, that it might sometimes bring 'em nearer together, and at other times remove 'em farther from one another. We might gain rather than lose by that Bargain, said I; for it may be, our Earth wou'd be carry'd near Venus and Mercury, which are little Planets, and cou'd not resist ours: But we have nothing either to hope or fear from such an Accident; the Planets must remain where they are, new Conquests are forbid them, as they were heretofore to the Kings of China. You know very well, when one mixes Oil and Water together <UP>in a Vessel</UP>, the Oil will swim above; and if you throw any very light thing into the Vessel, the Oil will support it, and it will not penetrate into the Water: Throw in any other thing, somewhat heavier, of a proportionable weight to penetrate the Oil, which is too weak to stop it; 'twill fall upon the Water, and swim, the Water being sufficiently strong to bear it up. So that this Vessel, full of two Liquors, which does not mingle together two Bodies of an unequal weight, rests naturally in two different Positions, the one above the other; so as the lightest can never descend, the heaviest can never ascend. If you add other Liquors that will not mingle together, and throw as many Bodies into 'em of proportionable weight, 'twill still be the same thing. Imagine to your self, that the Celestial Substance which fills the vast Tourbillion, or Whirling of the Sun, is compos'd of different Coats, wrapp'd within one another, <UP>like an Onion</UP>; these Coats are of different weights and force, as Oil and Water, and other Liquors. The Planets also are of different weights; and by consequence, every one of the Planets must stop upon that Coat proportionable to its weight, and which has necessary strength for supporting it, and keeping it in an equal Balance; and you will perceive it is not possible in Nature they can remove from thence.</P049>

explanations: The French 'séjour' (abode, place of stay) is rendered as 'Country,' making the nature of this hypothetical solar dwelling more specific and akin to a defined territory. This interpretation is implied by the discussion of planets as 'worlds' but is made explicit as a 'Country,' potentially for reader accessibility.

The French 'Satellites' (whose Latin root 'satelles' means attendant/guard, though by Fontenelle's time it also meant astronomical moons) is translated with the addition of 'Guards'. The translator makes an etymologically-linked meaning of 'satellite' as an attendant or guard explicit, perhaps to make the concept more vivid or to emphasize a hierarchical relationship common in 17th-century social understanding.

The French 'tournent autour' (turn around) is translated as 'attending upon.' This explicitly spells out a hierarchical or subservient relationship (attendance, service) between the moons and their primary planet, which is only implied by the motion and complements the previous rendering of 'Satellites' as 'Guards.'

The translator adds 'or Whistlings' to 'Tourbillions' (whirlpools/vortices). While 'tourbillon' primarily refers to rotary motion, 'whistlings' makes explicit a potential auditory characteristic associated with some tourbillons (like whirlwinds of air), adding a sensory detail that might be implicitly connected but is not stated in the source.

The French 'un Tourbillon de vent' (a vortex/whirlwind of air) is expanded with 'call'd a Whirl-wind, or a Hurricain.' The translator explicitly provides common English equivalents ('Whirl-wind') and a more specific, powerful example ('Hurricain') for the French term, clarifying its meaning for the English reader.

The French 'grand amas de matiere celeste' (great mass of celestial matter) is translated as 'vast Ocean, and Mass of Celestial Substance.' The addition of 'Ocean' explicitly uses a metaphor to clarify the fluid, expansive, and immense nature of the celestial matter, which is only implied by 'grand amas.'

The French 'en un mesme sens' (in the same direction) concerning planetary motion around the Sun is translated as 'one way, from East to West.' This addition explicitly specifies the direction of this motion according to the prevailing understanding of Cartesian vortices (as viewed from Earth's northern hemisphere), information that was left unstated or assumed in the source.

The French 'il ne tourne que sur luy-mesme' (it only turns on itself), referring to the Sun, is translated as 'he turns round upon his own Axis.' The phrase 'upon his own Axis' explicitly clarifies the nature of the Sun's rotation, a technical detail that is implied by 'tourne sur luy-mesme' but spelled out in the translation for greater clarity.

The French 'tourner sur elle-mesme' (to turn on itself), referring to the Earth, is translated as 'turn round upon her own Axis'. This is similar to the previous explicitation for the Sun, making the technical detail of axial rotation explicit for the Earth as well.

The French 'Maistre' (Master) referring to the Sun's role in its vortex, is translated as 'Governor.' This explicitation specifies the *type* of mastery the Sun has, framing it in terms of governance or rule over its system, which is a more defined role than the general term 'Master.'

The French 'tourner autour d'elle-mesme' (turn around itself), referring to a planet's rotation, is translated as 'turns round upon his own Axis.' This explicitly clarifies that the planet's self-rotation is axial, a technical detail spelled out in the translation, consistent with previous similar explicitations.

The French 'la force de son mouvement se peut étendre' (the force of its movement can extend) is translated by specifying the limit as 'the Sphere of its Activity can reach.' This term makes the domain of the planet's tourbillon explicit using a more formal, perhaps scientific-sounding concept ('sphere of activity') for what Fontenelle describes more generally as the reach of its motional force.

The French 'au commencement du Monde' (at the beginning of the World) is translated as 'after the Creation of the Universe.' This explicitly links the beginning to the theological act of 'Creation' and broadens 'Monde' (World) to the more encompassing 'Universe,' potentially aligning the scientific discourse with a religious framework significant in the 17th-century cultural context.

The French 'l'étenduë de nostre Tourbillon' (the extent of our tourbillon) is translated as 'within the Extent or Sphere of Activity.' The addition of 'or Sphere of Activity' explicitly provides a more technical or formal term for the range of the Earth's vortex, clarifying the concept of its reach for the reader.

The French phrase 'tout à fait à nostre bienséance' (entirely to our convenience/suitability/fittingness), describing the Moon's capture by Earth's tourbillon, is translated as 'and forc'd its Obedience.' This explicitation dramatically re-frames the relationship, spelling out a dynamic of coercion and subjugation ('forc'd its Obedience') that is much stronger and more explicit than the original's idea of mere fittingness or suitability.

The French 'pour nous absorber' (to absorb us), referring to Jupiter's potential action on Earth, is translated as 'who may sweep us round with it self.' This explicitation clarifies the *mechanism* of absorption within the context of Cartesian vortex theory, specifying it as being swept into Jupiter's rotational motion rather than a more general or undefined absorption.

The French 'ce grand mouvement' (this great movement) of celestial matter is translated as 'the violent Motions.' The word 'violent' explicitly adds an attribute of intensity and potential for disruption to the 'great movement,' making its forceful nature clearer and more impactful than the more neutral 'grand.'

The French 'quand on met de l'huile avec de l'eau' (when one puts oil with water) implies a container for the experiment. The translation 'when one mixes Oil and Water together in a Vessel' makes this implicit container explicit by adding 'in a Vessel,' clarifying the experimental setup.

The French 'deux places differentes' (two different places) for objects in layered liquids is translated as 'two different Positions, the one above the other.' The addition 'the one above the other' explicitly describes the relative vertical arrangement of these positions, which is implied by the physics of the demonstration but is spelled out for clarity.

The French 'ce grand Tourbillon' (this great Vortex) is translated as 'the vast Tourbillion, or Whirling of the Sun.' The addition 'of the Sun' explicitly identifies this specific great vortex as belonging to the Sun (i.e., the solar system's main vortex). Furthermore, adding 'or Whirling' serves to explicate the term 'Tourbillion' by providing a more common or descriptive English word for the concept.

The French 'differentes couches qui s'envelopent les unes les autres' (different layers that envelop one another) is translated as 'different Coats, wrapp'd within one another, like an Onion;'. The addition of the simile 'like an Onion' explicitly provides a common, concrete image to help the reader visualize the abstract concept of nested celestial layers, enhancing clarity and accessibility.

The French 'dont les pesanteurs sont differentes' (whose weights/densities are different), referring to celestial layers, is translated as 'these Coats are of different weights and force.' The addition of 'and force' makes explicit another crucial property of these layers—their differing strengths or capacities to exert force (implied by their ability to support planets)—which was not directly stated by 'pesanteurs' alone.

chunks.source_manual: <P067>Je conçois, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, que ces pesanteurs-là reglent fort bien les rangs. Plust à Dieu qu'il y eust quelque chose de pareil qui les reglast parmi nous, & qui fixast les Gens dans les places qui leur sont naturellement convenables. Me voila fort en repos du costé de Jupiter. Je suis bien-aise qu'il nous laisse dans nostre petit Tourbillon <SC>avec nostre Lune unique</SC>. Je suis d'humeur à me borner aisément, & je ne luy envie point les quatre qu'il a.</P067>
chunks.target_manual: <P050>I understand very well, said the Marquiese, how these different Weights are regulated, according to their several degrees: Wou'd to God, there were some such Order amongst us Mortals, to confine every Man to the Station that is fit for him. I am now no longer in fear of Iupiter; I am satisfy'd that he will leave us at ease in our own little Whirling, or Tourbillion <SC>;</SC> I am easily pleas'd, and do not envy Iupiter his four Moons.</P050>

us Mortals

explanations: The French "les rangs" (the ranks/orders) implies the existence of different levels or degrees. The English translation makes the basis of this differentiation explicit by adding the clause "according to their several degrees," clarifying that the regulation of weights (which forms the ranks) occurs based on these inherent degrees, a mechanism not spelled out in the source.

The French pronoun "nous" (us), within the phrase "parmi nous" (among us), is general. The English translation "us Mortals" explicitly adds the qualifier "Mortals," specifying the human, finite nature of the "us" being referred to. This adds a layer of philosophical specification of the human condition that was only implied in the original.

The French "Tourbillon" refers to Descartes' theory of vortices, a specific scientific concept of the era. The English translation "Whirling, or Tourbillion" explicitly provides a more common English equivalent ("Whirling") alongside the loanword "Tourbillon," thus clarifying this potentially specialized scientific term for the contemporary English reader by expanding it.

The French "les quatre" (the four), part of the phrase "les quatre qu'il a" (the four that he has), is an elliptical reference to Jupiter's Galilean moons, which would be understood from the broader context of Fontenelle's work. The English translation "his four Moons" makes this referent explicit by adding the noun "Moons," removing potential ambiguity and ensuring the reader clearly understands the specific astronomical objects being discussed.

chunks.source_manual: <P068>Vous auriez tort de les luy envier, repris-je, il n'en a point plus qu'il ne luy en faut. Dans l'éloignement où il est du Soleil, les Lunes ne reçoivent & ne luy renvoyent, qu'une lumiere assez faible. Il est vray que comme il tourne sur luy-mesme en dix heures, & que ses nuits, qui par consequent <IIM>n'en durent que cinq</IIM>, sont fort courtes, quatre Lunes ne paroîtroient pas si necessaires, mais il y a autre chose à considerer. Icy sous les Pôles, on a six mois de jour, & six mois de nuit. C'est que les Pôles sont les deux extremitez de la Terre les plus éloignées des lieux où le Soleil donne à plomb, & sur lesquels il paroit faire sa course. La Lune ne tient, ou paroist tenir la même route à peu prés que le Soleil, & si les Habitans des Pôles voyent le Soleil pendant toute une moitié de sa course d'un an, & pendant toute l'autre moitié ne le voyent point, ils voyent aussi la Lune pendant toute une moitié de sa course d'un mois, c'est à dire, pendant quinze jours, & ils ne la voyent point pendant toute l'autre moitié. <IIM>Les années de Jupiter</IIM> en valent douze des nostre, & il doit y avoir dans cette Planete deux extremitez opposées, où l'on ait des jours & des nuits de six ans entiers. <IIM>Des nuits</IIM> de six ans sont bien longues, aussi est ce principalement pour elles que je crois que les quatre Lunes sont faites. Celle qui à l'egard de Jupiter est la plus élevée, fait son cercle autour de luy en dix-sept jours, la seconde en sept, la troisiéme en trois jours & demy, la quatrième en quarante-deux heures. Leurs courses estant coupées justement par la moitié pour ces malheureux <UP></UP> Pays qui ont six ans de nuit, il ne se peut passer vingt & une heures, qu'on ne voye paroistre au moins la derniere Lune. C'est quelque consolation pendant des tenebres d'une durée si ennuyeuse; mais quelque lieu que l'on habite dans Jupiter, ces quatre Lunes vous y donnent les plus jolis Spectacles <UP></UP> du monde. Tantost elles se lèvent toutes quatre ensemble, & puis se separent selon l'inégalité de leur cours; tantost elles sont toutes à leur Midy rangées l'une au dessus de l'autre, tantost <RW>on les</RW> voit toutes quatre sur l'Horizon à des distances égales; tantost quand deux se levent, deux autres se couchent; sur tout j'aimerois à voir ce jeu perpetuel d'Eclipses qu'elles font, car il ne se passe point de jour qu'elles ne s'éclipsent les unes les autres, ou qu'elles n'éclipsent le Soleil, & asseurément les Eclipses s'estant renduës si familieres en ce Monde-là, elles y sont un sujet de divertissement, & non pas de frayeur, comme en celuy-ci.</P068> <P069><SC>Gens de nostre Lune</SC>, me fait douter que Jupiter en ait beaucoup sur le Habitans de siennes, & je croy qu'un des avantages ausquels ils puissent le plus raisonnablemént pretendre, c'est de leur faire peur. <UP>Par exemple, dans celle qui est la plus proche de luy, ils le voyent trois cents soixante fois plus gros que nostre Lune ne nous paroist, car il la surpasse autant en grosseur. Il est, je croy, beaucoup plus proche d'eux, qu'elle n'est de nous, sa grosseur en augmente encore. Ils fent comme des Colonies de Jupiter; qu'elles eussent receu de luy, s'il estoit possible, leurs Loix & leurs Coûtumes; que par consequent elles luy redissent quelque sorte d'hommage, & ne regardassent la grande Planete qu'avec respect. Ne faudroit-il point aussi, luy dis-je, que les quatre Lunes envoyassent de temps en temps des Députez dans Jupiter, pour luy prester ferment de fidelité? Pour moy, je vous avoüe que le peu de superiorité que nous avons sur les Gens.</UP></P069>
chunks.target_manual: <P051>You wou'd be to blame if you shou'd, said I; for he has no more than what is necessary for him; considering the great distance he is from the Sun, his Moons receive and reflect but a very faint Light. 'Tis true, that Iupiter turns upon his own Axis in the space of ten Hours, his Nights are but four Hours long; and being so short, one wou'd think he had no great need of four Moons: But you must consider, in our Earth, <RW>under the North and South Poles</RW>, there are six Months of Day, and six Months of Night; because the two Poles being the two Points of the Earth, remotest from those Countries and Places, upon which the Sun darts his beams directly, and over which, to our Apprehensions, he seems to perform his Course: The Moon holds, or appears to us to hold the same Road with the Sun: So that if the Inhabitants <UP>near the South and North Poles</UP> see the Sun during one half of his yearly Course, and then lose his Light during the other half, it must follow, that they see the Moon during one half of her monthly <RW>Revolution</RW>, and lose her during the other half; that is, for the space of fifteen Days. One of Iupiter's Years is twelve of ours, and there must be two opposite Poles in that Planet where there are Days and Nights of six Years long apiece. A Night of six Years long is very long, and I believe these four Moons were chiefly created for that reason: The highest of the four, as to Iupiter, performs its Course round him in seventeen Days, the second in seven Days, the third in three Days and an half, and the fourth in forty two Hours. These Revolutions being thus divided by equal halves in these unhappy <IIM>Climates </IIM>, where there are six Years of continued Night, one and twenty Hours cannot pass without their seeing appear, at least, the last of the four Moons; which is a very great satisfaction, during so long and irksome a Darkness: But upon whatever place of Iupiter you shou'd inhabit, these four Moons wou'd represent to your view one of the most agreeable Sights in Nature: Sometimes they rise all four together, then they separate according to the inequality of their Motions; sometimes they see 'em over their Heads, directly above one another; at other times they see 'em appear above their Horzion, at equal distances; at another time, two of the four are rising, when the other two are setting; but above all, I shou'd be pleas'd to see their constant Eclipsing one another, or the Sun; for there passes no Day, without one of the two; and since Eclipses are so familiar to that World, they must certainly be a Divertissement to them, whereas they fight the Inhabitants of our Earth.</P051>

explanations: The French 'Icy' (Here), used when discussing Earth's polar phenomena, implicitly refers to Earth. The translation 'in our Earth' makes this reference explicit, clarifying the specific location being discussed.

The French 'sous les Pôles' (under the Poles) refers generally to Earth's polar regions. The translation 'under the North and South Poles' explicitly specifies both individual poles, adding a level of geographical detail that was only implied by the plural 'Pôles'.

The French 'il paroit faire sa course' (it appears to make its course) suggests the apparent motion of the Sun. The translation 'to our Apprehensions, he seems to perform his Course' explicitly adds the subjective observer's perspective ('to our Apprehensions'), reinforcing that the Sun's movement is an observed phenomenon from a human viewpoint, a concept central to Copernican popularization.

The French 'paroist tenir' (appears to hold), describing the Moon's apparent path, is translated as 'appears to us to hold'. The addition of 'to us' explicitly introduces the observer, clarifying that this appearance is from an Earth-based perspective and thus emphasizing the subjective nature of the astronomical observation.

The French 'Habitans des Pôles' (Inhabitants of the Poles) is translated as 'Inhabitants near the South and North Poles.' The translator makes the general term 'les Pôles' explicit by specifying 'the South and North Poles,' providing more concrete geographical detail.

The French 'sa course d'un mois' (its/her one-month course), referring to the Moon's movement, uses the general term 'course.' The translation 'her monthly Revolution' makes the scientific nature of this movement explicit by using the specific astronomical term 'Revolution,' which clearly denotes an orbital path.

The French 'deux extremitez opposées' (two opposite extremities) of Jupiter are described following a discussion of Earth's poles. While the context implies these Jovian extremities are analogous to Earth's poles, the translation 'two opposite Poles' explicitly names them as such, thereby spelling out the implied analogy and clarifying their nature.

The French 'Celle qui à l'egard de Jupiter est la plus élevée' (The one that... is the highest) refers to one of Jupiter's moons, which were just introduced as a set of four. The translation 'The highest of the four, as to Iupiter' explicitly adds 'of the four,' clarifying the referent by directly linking this specific moon to the previously established group of Jupiter's moons.

The French 'fait son cercle autour de luy' (makes its circle around him) uses the geometric term 'cercle' to describe a moon's orbit. The translation 'performs its Course round him' replaces 'cercle' with 'Course' (in the sense of a path or orbit), making the astronomical context of a regular, dynamic celestial movement more explicit than the simpler geometric description.

The French 'la derniere Lune' (the last Moon) refers to one of Jupiter's moons in the descriptive sequence. The translation 'the last of the four Moons' explicitly adds 'of the four,' clarifying its membership within the previously mentioned set of Jupiter's four moons and specifying which 'last Moon' is indicated.

The French 'les plus jolis Spectacles du monde' (the prettiest/nicest spectacles of the world/in the world) is a general superlative. The translation 'one of the most agreeable Sights in Nature' makes the context explicit by adding 'in Nature,' framing these astronomical views as natural phenomena and aligning the description with the work's scientific popularization theme.

The French 'à leur Midy' (at their Midday/Noon) indicates the moons' culmination or meridian transit from the perspective of an observer on Jupiter. The translation 'over their Heads' makes explicit the visual experience and spatial orientation implied by 'Midy' for such an observer, clarifying how this astronomical event would appear.

The French 'comme en celuy-ci' (as in this one) implicitly refers to the speaker's world, Earth. The translation 'whereas they fight [frighten] the Inhabitants of our Earth' makes this reference explicit by stating 'our Earth' and further clarifies who experiences the fear by adding 'the Inhabitants of,' information that was only implied in the source.
