chunks.source_manual: <P070>Et vous ne manquerez pas, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, à faire habiter ces quatre Lunes, quoy que ce ne foient que de petites Planetes subalternes, destinées seulement à en éclairer une autre pendant ces nuits? N'en doutez nullement, répondis-je. Ces Planetes n'en sont pas moins dignes d'estre habitées pour avoir le malheur d'estre asservies à tourner autour d'une autre plus importante.</P070> <P071>Je voudrais donc, reprit-elle, que les Habitans des quatre Lunes de Jupiter <UP></UP>, fussont donc toûjours cette monstrueuse Planete suspédüe sur leurs testes à une distance assez petite. En verité, si les Gaulois craignaient anciennement que le Ciel ne tombast sur eux, les Habitans de cette Lune auroient bien plus de sujet de craindre une chute de Jupiter <UP></UP>. C'est peut-estre là aussi la frayeur qu'ils ont, dit- elle, au lieu de celle des Eclipses, dont vous m'avez asseuré qu'ils sont exempts, & qu'il faut bien remplacer par quelque autre sottise? Il le faut de necessité absolüe, répondis-je. L'Inventeur du troisième Systême dont je vous parlois l'autre jour, le celebre Ticho-Brahé <UP></UP>, un des plus grands Astronomes qui furent jamais, n'avoit garde de craindre les Eclipses, comme le Vulgaire les craint, il passoit sa vie avec elles. Mais croiriez-vous bien ce qu'il craignoit en leur place? Si en sortant de son logis, la premiere personne qu'il rencontroit estoit une Vieille, si un Lievre traversoit son chemin, Ticho-Brahé croyoit que la journée devoit estre malheureuse, & retournoit promptement se renfermer chez luy, sans oser commencer la moindre chose.</P071>
chunks.target_manual: <P052>And you will not fail, I hope, says the Marquiese, to bestow Inhabitants upon these four Moons, though they be little, inferior Planets, and only made to enlighten the Inhabitants of a greater, during their long Nights. You need not doubt of it, said I, Madam; these four Planets are no less deserving of Inhabitants, because they are so unhappy as to be subject to, and turn round a more important Planet. I wou'd, says the Marquiese, have the Inhabitants of these four Moons to be Colonies of Iupiter, and receive their Laws and Manners from thence, and pay Homage and Respect to Iupiter, and not to look upon that great Planet, but with Veneration. And wou'd you not also, said I, have these four Moons to send Ambassadors, from time to time, to the Inhabitants of Iupiter, and swear Fealty to him? For my part, we having no Authority over the Inhabitants of our Moon, makes me think that Iupiter has no more over the Inhabitants of his four; and I believe, one of the Advantages he has most reason to brag of, is, that he frightens 'em. For Example; The Inhabitants of that Moon next to Iupiter, see him three hundred and sixty times bigger than our one Moon appeareth to us: And as I believe that little Moon to be much nearer to Iupiter than Ours is; so his greatness must be by that considerably augmented; and they must constantly see that monstrous Planet hanging over their Heads, at a very small distance. And if it be true, that the Gauls of old, apprehended the falling of the Heavens: The Inhabitants of that Moon have more Reason to fear the falling of Iupiter. It may be, said she, they have that fright, instead of that of the Eclipses, which you told me, they are free from; and which must be supply'd by some other piece of Folly. It must be so infallibly, said I, Madam, for the great inventer of the third System, of which I spoke to you the other Day, the Ticho-Brahe one of the greatest Astronomers that ever liv'd, was far from fearing Eclipses as the Vulgar do; but instead of that, he fear'd, if the first he met (as he went out of his House <UP>in the Morning)</UP> were old, or if a Hare happen'd to cross his way, he instantly return'd home, shut himself up, and did believe that day to be unlucky; nor wou'd he dare to attempt <IIM>Business of the smallest Consequence </IIM>.</P052>

explanations: The French "à en éclairer une autre" (to provide light to another one [i.e., Jupiter]) implicitly suggests that this enlightenment benefits potential inhabitants. The translator makes this explicit by specifying "to enlighten the Inhabitants of a greater [planet]", directly stating who benefits from the light, which aligns with the book's theme of discussing habitable worlds.

The French "pendant ces nuits" (during these nights) is translated as "during their long Nights." The addition of the adjective "long" is an explicitation. While the astronomical context might imply that nights on Jupiter's moons could be long, the source text doesn't state it. The translator adds this detail to make the description more vivid and specific.

The source text describes the Marquise's wish for the inhabitants of Jupiter's moons to experience "cette monstrueuse Planete suspédüe sur leurs testes à une distance assez petite" (this monstrous Planet suspended over their heads at a rather small distance). This implies a visually overwhelming presence. The English translation explicitly elaborates on the scale and reason for this appearance by adding the specific comparative detail "see him three hundred and sixty times bigger than our one Moon appeareth to us" and the astronomical reasoning "And as I believe that little Moon to be much nearer to Iupiter than Ours is; so his greatness must be by that considerably augmented". This quantification and causal explanation make the implied visual impact explicit.

The French phrase "en sortant de son logis" (on leaving his dwelling/house) generally implies the beginning of the day's activities. The English translation "(as he went out of his House in the Morning)" makes this temporal context explicit by adding "in the Morning," thereby specifying the time of day for Tycho Brahe's superstitious behavior more precisely than the source text.

chunks.source_manual: <P072>Il ne seroit pas juste, <IIM>reprit-elle</IIM>, aprés que cet homme-là n'a pû se delivrer impunément de la crainte des Eclipses, que les Habitans de cette <UP></UP> Lune de Jupiter, dont nous parlions, en fussent quittes à meilleur marché. Nous ne leur ferons pas de quartier, ils subiront la Loy commune <UP></UP>, & donneront dans quelque autre erreur, mais comme je ne me pique pas de la pouvoir deviner, éclaircissez-moy, je vous prie, une autre difficulté qui m'occupe depuis quelques momens. Si la Terre est si petite à l'égard de Jupiter, Jupiter nous voit-il? Je crains que nous ne luy soyons inconnus.</P072> <P073>De bonne foy, je croy que cela est, répondis-je. Il faudroit qu'il vist la Terre quatre-vingt-dix fois plus petite que nous ne le voyons. C'est trop peu, il ne la voit point. Voicy seulement ce que nous pouvons croire de meilleur pour nous. Il y aura dans Jupiter des Astronomes, qui aprés avoir bien pris de la peine à composer des Lunettes excellentes, aprés avoir choisy les plus belles Nuits pour observer, auront enfin découvert dans les Cieux une petite Planete qu'ils n'avoyent jamais veüe. D'abord le <NCE>Journal des Sçavans</NCE> de ce Pays-là en parle; le Peuple de Jupiter, ou n'en entend point parler, ou n'en fait que rire. Les Philosophes dont cela détruit les opinions, forment le dessein de n'en rien croire, il n'y a que les Gens tres-raisonnables qui en veulent bien douter. On observe encore, on revoit la petite Planete, on s'asseure bien que ce n'est point une vision, on commence même à soupçonner qu'elle a un mouvement autour du Soleil; on trouve au bout de mille observations, que ce <RW>mouvement</RW> est d'une année; & enfin, grace à toutes les peines que se donnent les Sçavans, <NCP></NCP> on sçait dans Jupiter que nostre Terre est un Monde. Les Curieux vont la voir au bout d'une Lunette, & la veüe à peine peut-elle encore l'attraper.</P073>
chunks.target_manual: <P053>It is not just, said the Marquiese, that since that great Man was not free from the Fear of Eclipses for nothing, that the Inhabitants of that little Moon, shou'd come off at an easier rate: Let us give 'em no Quarter, but force 'em to submit to the common Law <UP>of Nature</UP>, and oblige 'em to yield to some other Folly. But since I will not trouble my self to guess at this time, what that may be, pray solve me one difficulty, which my Fancy has just now suggested; if the Earth be so little, in respect of Iupiter; does <UP>the Inhabitants of</UP> Iupiter see our Earth? I am afraid we are altogether unknown to 'em. Really, I believe it to be so, said I, for the Inhabitants of Iupiter must see the Earth ninety times less than Iupiter appears to us; which is too small to be perceiv'd by them; and all we can imagine for our advantage, is, to suppose that there are Astronomers in Iupiter, who after having taken a great deal of Pains, and fitting excellent Telescopes; and having chosen a very clear Night for making the Observation, they at last discover in the Heavens a little Planet, they had never seen before; and streight they set it down in the <NCE>Philosophical Transactions </NCE> of that Country. The rest of the Inhabitants of Iupiter, either never hear of it, or laugh at it if they do; the Philosophers themselves whose Opinion that discovery destroys, resolve not to believe it; and there are but some very rational People, that will trouble themselves with the thoughts of it. These Astronomers make new Observations; they again look upon this little Planet, and they begin to be assur'd that it is no Fancy but a real thing; then they begin to conclude, this little Planet has a Motion round the Sun; and after a thousand Observations, they at last find out that this Motion <RW>or Revolution</RW>, is performed in a Years time. So that, thanks to these learned Men, the Inhabitants of Iupiter know our Earth is a Planet and a World: The Curious are earnest to look on it through a Telescope; tho 'tis so little, 'tis hardly discoverable.</P053>

explanations: The French "la Loy commune" (the common Law) is translated as "the common Law of Nature". The translator makes explicit that this "common Law" refers to natural laws or universal principles, a specification implied by Fontenelle's philosophical context discussing inherent human tendencies or natural phenomena, thus clarifying the scope of this law.

The French "Jupiter nous voit-il?" (Does Jupiter see us?) uses personification, implicitly suggesting observers on Jupiter. The translation "does the Inhabitants of Iupiter see our Earth?" explicitly identifies these potential observers as "the Inhabitants of Iupiter," clarifying the agency of seeing which was poetically implied in the original.

The French "Il faudroit qu'il vist la Terre" (He/It [Jupiter] would have to see the Earth) uses the pronoun "il" (he/it), which in context refers to Jupiter, implying observation by its inhabitants. The translation "for the Inhabitants of Iupiter must see the Earth" makes this implicit agency explicit by naming "the Inhabitants of Iupiter" as the seers.

The French "C'est trop peu, il ne la voit point." (That's too little/small, he/it doesn't see it) concisely states a condition ("C'est trop peu") and a result ("il ne la voit point"). The translation "which is too small to be perceiv'd by them;" explicates the reason by expanding "trop peu" to "which is too small" and clarifies who is unable to perceive ("by them," referring to the inhabitants of Jupiter) and the nature of the inability ("to be perceiv'd"), making the causal link and the subjects of perception more explicit than the condensed source.

The French "le Journal des Sçavans" (a renowned French scientific journal founded in 1665, literally "Journal of the Learned") is translated as "the Philosophical Transactions". This is the name of the contemporaneous influential journal of the Royal Society in England. By using this specific English equivalent, the translator explicitly clarifies the *nature, prestige, and function* of the publication as a leading scientific periodical for the English-speaking audience of the period, making the reference culturally specific and immediately understandable in their context.

The French impersonal pronoun "On" in "On observe encore" (One observes further/again) is translated as "These Astronomers make new Observations". While "on" often requires an explicit subject in English, the translator’s choice of "These Astronomers" specifically links the action to the previously mentioned "Astronomes...dans Jupiter". This makes an implicit anaphoric reference explicit, clearly identifying the agents performing the continued observations, rather than using a more general subject.

The French "ce n'est point une vision" (it is not a vision) is translated as "it is no Fancy but a real thing". The term "vision" can imply an illusion or something unreal. The translator explicates this by introducing the contrast "no Fancy but a real thing," thereby spelling out the implied opposition between illusion/imagination ("Fancy") and objective reality ("a real thing"), ensuring the reader grasps the intended meaning more clearly.

The French "mouvement" (movement), in the phrase "que ce mouvement est d'une année" (that this movement is of one year), is translated as "Motion or Revolution" in the corresponding phrase "that this Motion or Revolution, is performed in a Years time." By adding "or Revolution," the translator specifies that the type of movement being discussed is an orbital period or celestial revolution, an important astronomical concept. This explicitation clarifies the scientific nature of the "mouvement" within the astronomical context of the dialogue.

The French "on sçait dans Jupiter" (one knows in Jupiter) uses the impersonal pronoun "on". The translation "the Inhabitants of Iupiter know" makes the agent of knowing explicit by specifying "the Inhabitants of Iupiter". This clarifies that the knowledge about Earth has become widespread among the general populace of Jupiter, not confined to the previously mentioned astronomers, making the scope of this knowledge explicit.

The French "un Monde" (a World), in the statement "nostre Terre est un Monde" (our Earth is a World), is translated as "a Planet and a World" in "our Earth is a Planet and a World:". Fontenelle's work consistently argues for the interconnected ideas that other planets are worlds and Earth itself is a planet. The translator makes this central thesis explicit by adding "a Planet", thereby clarifying that "Monde" here signifies not just a place of habitation but also Earth's status as a celestial body comparable to other planets in the Copernican system, a key popularizing point of the book.

chunks.source_manual: <P074>Si ce n'estoit, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, qu'il n'est point trop agreable de sçavoir qu'on ne nous peut découvrir de dedans Jupiter qu'avec des Lunettes d'approche, je me representerois avec plaisir ces Lunettes de Jupiter dressées vers nous, comme les nostres le sont vers luy, & cette curiosité mutuelle avec laquelle les Planetes s'entre-considerent & demandent l'une de l'autre, Quel monde est-ce-là? Quelles Gens l'habitent?</P074>
chunks.target_manual: <P054>If it were not, said the Marquiese, very disagreeable for me to believe, that our Earth is not to be perceiv'd by the Inhabitants of Iupiter, but by the help of a Telescope, I shou'd find an Infinite Pleasure in imagining, I shou'd see those Telescopes <SC></SC> pointing towards us; and ours from a mutual Curiosity are levell'd at them, whil'st those two Planets gravely considering one another, the Inhabitants of both ask at one and the same time, What World is that? What People are those?</P054>

explanations: The French indefinite pronoun 'on' (one/they/people), found in the phrase 'qu'on ne nous peut découvrir de dedans Jupiter' (that one cannot discover us from within Jupiter), is translated as 'the Inhabitants of Iupiter.' The translator makes explicit the agent of perception from Jupiter, which is implied by the work's context of discussing life on other planets but is not specified by the general pronoun 'on' in the source.

The French pronoun 'nous' (us), from the phrase 'qu'on ne nous peut découvrir' (that one cannot discover us), is translated as 'our Earth.' In the context of being potentially observed from Jupiter, 'nous' implicitly refers to humanity or the planet Earth itself. The translation makes this specific object of perception explicit.

The source phrase 'comme les nostres le sont vers luy' (as ours are [directed] towards it [Jupiter]) is expanded in the translation to 'and ours from a mutual Curiosity are levell'd at them.' The translator introduces the phrase 'from a mutual Curiosity' to explicitly state the motivation for aiming 'our' telescopes. While the source mentions 'cette curiosité mutuelle' (this mutual curiosity) in the subsequent clause describing how the planets consider each other, the translation rewrites this section to directly link this curiosity as the reason for the action of aiming our telescopes, a causal connection that was only implied by the sequential structure of the original sentence.

The source text uses 'les Planetes' (the Planets) as the subject of the verb 'demandent' (ask) in the phrase 'les Planetes s'entre-considerent & demandent l'une de l'autre' (the Planets consider each other and ask one another). This is a metonymic expression where planets stand for their inhabitants. The translation replaces 'les Planetes' with 'the Inhabitants of both' as the subject of 'ask,' thereby explicitly identifying the actual agents performing the action of asking.

The French phrase 'demandent l'une de l'autre' (ask one another/of each other), describing the interaction between the planets (or their inhabitants), implies a reciprocal questioning. The translation renders this part of the action as 'ask at one and the same time.' This addition makes the simultaneity of the mutual questioning explicit, an aspect of timing that was not overtly stated in the source phrase, thus spelling out a detail of the interaction.

chunks.source_manual: <P075><IIM>Cela ne va pas si viste que vous pensez</IIM>, repliquay-je. Quand on verroit nostre Terre de dedans Jupiter, quand on l'y connoistroit, nostre Terre ce n'est pas nous; on n'a pas le moindre soupçon qu'elle puisse estre habitée. Si quelqu'un vient à se l'imaginer, Dieu sçait comme tout Jupiter se moque de luy. Peut-estre mesme sommes-nous cause qu'on y <UP>a fait le procés</UP> à des Philosophes qui ont voulu soûtenir que nous estions. Cependant je croirois plus volontiers que les Habitans de Jupiter sont assez occupez à faire des découvertes sur leur Planete, pour ne songer point du tout à nous. Elle est si grande, que s'ils navigent, asseurément <UP>leurs Cristophles Colombs ne sçauroient manquer d'employ</UP>. Il faut que les Peuples de ce Monde-là ne connoissent pas seulement de réputation la centiéme partie des autres Peuples, au lieu que dans Mercure, <NCP>qui est fort petit</NCP>, ils sont tous voisins les uns des autres, ils vivent familierement ensemble, & ne comptent que pour une promenade de faire le tour de leur Monde. Si on ne nous voit point dans Jupiter, vous jugez bien qu'on y voit encore moins Venus & Mercure, qui sont des Mondes, & plus petits, & plus éloignez de luy. En récompense ses Habitans voyent Mars, & leurs quatre Lunes, & Saturne <RW>avec les siennes</RW>. Voila assez de Planetes pour embarasser ceux d'entre eux qui sont Astronomes; la Nature a eu la bonté de leur cacher ce qui en reste dans l'Univers.</P075>
chunks.target_manual: <P055>Don't go so fast, Madam, said I; suppose, the Inhabitants of Iupiter, cou'd see our Earth; yet, they cou'd never see us, or so much as suspect our Earth to be inhabited; or if any Body were Fool enough to imagine it, God knows, how he wou'd be laugh'd at and ridicul'd by the rest of the Inhabitants. And it may be, we are the Cause, that some Philosophers in that World have been <UP>sued and persecuted</UP> for this Opinion: However, I believe, that the Inhabitants of Iupiter are employed enough in the discovery of their own Planet, without troubling themselves with the thoughts of us. And had Christopher Columbus been of that Country, and understanding Navigation so well, he cou'd not have wanted employment. And the People of that World know not the hundredth part of its own Inhabitants; whereas, in Mercury <NCP>(which is a very little Planet)</NCP> they are all Neighbours one to another, and converse familiarly together; and they esteem it, as but a Walk to go round their little World; and if the Inhabitants of Iupiter do not see us, you may easily judge, they can far less perceive Venus and Mercury, both which are more diminutive Worlds, and further distant from it than we: But in lieu of this, they see Mars, and there are four Moons, and Saturn <RW>with the five that belong to him</RW>. There are Planets enough, to perplex all the Astronomers there: And Nature has had the goodness to hide from 'em what remains of the Universe.</P055>

explanations: The French phrase uses the impersonal pronoun "on" in "on verroit" (one would see). The translation makes this agent explicit by specifying "the Inhabitants of Iupiter" as those who would see Earth, replacing the general "one" with a specific group.

The concise French statement "nostre Terre ce n'est pas nous" (our Earth is not us) implies that seeing the planet is distinct from perceiving its inhabitants. The translation "they cou'd never see us" makes the consequence of this distinction—the inability of Jovians to visually perceive Earth's inhabitants—explicit.

The translator adds "Fool enough" to characterize someone imagining Earth to be inhabited. The French "Si quelqu'un vient à se l'imaginer" (If someone happens to imagine it) is neutral about the imaginer's wisdom, whereas the translation explicitly inserts a judgment of foolishness, which was only implied by the subsequent mockery in the source.

The French "tout Jupiter" (all of Jupiter), metaphorically signifying its population, is clarified as "the rest of the Inhabitants." Additionally, the verb "se moque" (mocks) is expanded to the doublet "laugh'd at and ridicul'd," which specifies and potentially intensifies the nature of the mockery, making the social condemnation more explicit.

The French "fait le procés" (put on trial) is translated as "sued and persecuted." The addition of "persecuted" explicitly broadens and intensifies the implied consequences beyond a formal trial. Furthermore, the elliptical French clause "que nous estions" (that we existed/were) is made explicit as "for this Opinion," clearly stating the reason for the philosophers' treatment.

The French "on ne nous voit point" (one does not see us) uses the impersonal pronoun "on." The translation specifies this "on" as "the Inhabitants of Iupiter," explicitly identifying the agent who does not perform the act of seeing.

The French "on y voit" (one sees there) uses the impersonal pronoun "on." The translation uses "they," which, following the previous clause's mention of "the Inhabitants of Iupiter," explicitly refers back to this specific group. This clarifies the agent compared to the general "on."

The French "leurs Cristophles Colombs" (their Christopher Columbuses) implies multiple, analogous figures skilled in navigation. The translation shifts to a singular, specific hypothetical ("had Christopher Columbus been...") and explicitly adds the condition "and understanding Navigation so well," which makes an assumed quality of such figures (navigational skill) explicit and reframes the general statement into a more concrete conditional.

The French "des autres Peuples" (of the other peoples), in the context of Jupiter ("ce Monde-là"), refers to different groups of inhabitants on that same planet. The translation "of its own Inhabitants" makes this intra-planetary reference explicit, clarifying that "other peoples" refers to other inhabitants of Jupiter itself, not peoples from other worlds.

The French "plus éloignez de luy" (more distant from it [Jupiter]), referring to Venus and Mercury, implies a comparison point. The translation "further distant from it than we" makes this implicit comparison point (Earth, or "us") explicit by adding "than we."

The French "Saturne avec les siennes" (Saturn with its own [moons]) is general regarding the number of Saturn's moons. The English translation "Saturn with the five that belong to him" specifies the exact number "five." This addition makes implicit astronomical knowledge (the count of moons known by 1686-1688) explicit, providing contemporary scientific precision not overtly stated by Fontenelle.

chunks.source_manual: <P076>Quoy, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, vous comptez cela pour une grace? Sans doute, répondis-je. Il y a dans tout ce grand <RW>Tourbillon</RW> seize Planetes. La Nature qui veut nous épargner la peine d'étudier tous leurs mouvemens, ne nous en montre que sept, n'est-ce pas là une assez grande faveur? Mais nous, qui n'en sentons pas le prix, nous faisons si bien que nous attrapons les neuf autres, qui avoient esté cachees; aussi en sommes-nous punis par les grands travaux que l'Astronomie demande presentement.</P076>
chunks.target_manual: <P056>What, said the Lady Marquiese, do you look upon that as a Favour? Without doubt, said I, Madam, there is in this great Tourbillion <RW>or whirling of the Sun</RW>, Sixteen Planets. And Nature, who is willing to save us the labour of studying all their Motions, has discover'd to us only seven of them; and is not that a great Favour. But we who are not sensible of this Grace, have so ordered the matter that by our Endeavours we have found out the other nine, which Nature had conceal'd from us, and we are sufficiently punish'd for it, by the great Pains and Labour, which is at present requisite for the Study of Astronomy.</P056>
target_segments: the Lady Marquiese
Without doubt, said I, Madam,
this great Tourbillion or whirling of the Sun
have so ordered the matter that by our Endeavours
which Nature had conceal'd from us
which is at present requisite for the Study of Astronomy.
explanations: The French title "la Marquise" implies high noble status. The addition of "Lady" in "the Lady Marquiese" makes the implied general status of being a "lady" (a woman of rank) explicit, potentially for emphasis or to align with English forms of address for nobility, thereby clarifying her social standing for the English reader.

The French dialogue implies the philosopher's direct address to the Marquise through the conversational context ('répondis-je' following her speech). The English translation makes this explicit by inserting "Madam," specifying the formal term of address used.

The French term "Tourbillon" refers to a specific cosmological concept from Cartesian physics (a vortex system). The translator makes this implicit scientific reference explicit by adding the explanatory appositive "or whirling of the Sun," clarifying for the reader what this "Tourbillon" entails in the context of the Sun-centered system being discussed.

The French phrase "nous faisons si bien que" (literally "we do so well that" or "we manage that") is a concise expression of successful human action. The English translation "have so ordered the matter that by our Endeavours" expands on this by making explicit the deliberate nature of the action ("so ordered the matter") and the means ("by our Endeavours") through which humanity discovers the other planets.

The French passive voice "qui avoient esté cachees" (which had been hidden) implies an agent but does not explicitly state it within this specific subordinate clause. The English translation "which Nature had conceal'd from us" explicitly re-introduces "Nature" as the agent of concealment, spelling out a connection that was previously left to inference at this point in the sentence, although Nature was mentioned earlier as the entity initially limiting the visible planets.

The French "que l'Astronomie demande presentement" (that Astronomy presently demands) personifies Astronomy as an entity making a requirement. The English translation "which is at present requisite for the Study of Astronomy" rephrases this by making explicit that the "great Pains and Labour" are a necessary component or condition *for the activity of studying* astronomy, thus clarifying the context and nature of this requirement.

chunks.source_manual: <P077>Je voy, reprit-elle, par ce nombre de seize Planetes qu'il faut que Saturne ait cinq Lunes. Il les a aussi, repliquay-je, & de ces cinq Lunes, il y en a deux bien fraischement découvertes; mais il ya a quelque chose qui est encore bien plus remarquable. Comme son année est de trente des nostres, & que par consequent il a <IIM>des Pays</IIM>, où une seule nuit dure des quinze ans entiers, devinez ce que la Nature a inventé pour éclaires des nuits si affreuses. Elle ne s'est pas contentée de donner cinq Lunes à Saturne, elle a mis autour de luy un grand Cercle, ou un grand Anneau qui l'environne entierement, & qui estant assez élevé pour estre hors de l'ombre du Corps de cette Planete, refléchit perpetuellement la lumiere du Soleil <RW>dans les lieux qui ne le voyent point</RW>.</P077>
chunks.target_manual: <P057>I see, answer'd she, by the number of sixteen Planets, that Saturn must have five Moons. He has so, said I, Madam, and two of the five are discover'd very lately, but there is yet something more remarkable in that Planet; for his Year is as long as thirty of ours; and consequently there are <IIM>Climates in that World [translates "des Pays",</IIM> where one Night lasts for fifteen Years together. Can you guess what Nature has intended for the enlightning of Nights so long and dreadful? She was not satisfied to bestow on Saturn five Moons; but has also given him a great Circle or Ring, which environs him entirely, and which is elevated sufficiently high enough to be out of the shadow of this Planet. It reflects the Light of the Sun perpetually upon the <RW>Inhabitants of Saturn, who have the Misfortune to live in that Climate</RW>, that is, so long a time depriv'd of the influence of his Beams.</P057>

explanations: The French "repliquay-je" (I replied) is rendered as "said I, Madam". The addition of "Madam" explicitly incorporates a term of polite address to the Marquise. While the formal relationship and polite dialogue are evident from the overall context and tone in French, the English translation spells out this specific instance of address, making an implicit social convention of direct address explicit within the dialogue at this point.

The French "quelque chose qui est encore bien plus remarquable" (something that is even more remarkable) implicitly refers to a characteristic of Saturn, the subject of discussion. The English translation "something more remarkable in that Planet" makes this reference explicit by adding "in that Planet," clarifying that the remarkable quality pertains to Saturn itself, information that was contextually implied in the source.

The French "des Pays" (countries/regions/lands), in the context of Saturn having them ("il a des Pays"), is translated as "Climates in that World." The translation explicitates "des Pays" in two ways:
    1.  "Pays" (a general term for regions) is rendered as "Climates," specifying the nature of these regions in an astronomical context, making explicit the *type* of region.
    2.  The phrase "in that World" is an explicit addition, clarifying that these "Climates" are located on Saturn (the "World" under discussion), a detail implied in the source by "il [Saturn] a des Pays," which spells out this locational aspect.

The French "quinze ans entiers" (fifteen whole/entire years) is translated as "fifteen Years together." The word "entiers" implies completeness and an uninterrupted stretch of time. The addition of "together" in the English translation explicitly emphasizes the continuous, unbroken nature of this fifteen-year duration, spelling out an aspect strongly implied by "entiers".

The French phrase "dans les lieux qui ne le voyent point" (in the places that do not see it [the Sun]) is significantly expanded. The target "upon the Inhabitants of Saturn, who have the Misfortune to live in that Climate, that is, so long a time depriv'd of the influence of his Beams" makes several implicit aspects explicit and adds new layers:
    1.  "les lieux" (the places) is explicitated by identifying who or what is in these places ("the Inhabitants of Saturn") and the nature of these places ("in that Climate," referring to the areas experiencing the long nights).
    2.  The translator introduces an interpretive layer with "who have the Misfortune," making explicit a negative consequence for the inhabitants that was implied by "nuits si affreuses" (such dreadful nights) earlier in the French text but not directly stated here for "les lieux".
    3.  The simple negation "qui ne le voyent point" (that do not see it [the Sun]) is rephrased and expanded into a more detailed causal explanation: "that is, so long a time depriv'd of the influence of his Beams," specifying the duration and the nature of the deprivation (lack of "influence of his Beams" rather than just not seeing "it"). This transforms a concise statement into a descriptive elaboration.

chunks.source_manual: <P078>En verité, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, <IIM>de l'air d'une personne qui rentroit en elle-mesme avec étonnement</IIM>, tout cela est d'un grand ordre; il paroist bien que la Nature a eu en veüe les besoins de quelques Estres vivans, & que la distribution des Lunes n'a pas esté faite au hazard. Il n'en est tombé en partage qu'aux Planetes éloignées du Soleil, à la Terre, à Jupiter, à Saturne, car ce n'estoit pas la peine d'en donner à Venus & à Mercure, qui ne reçoivent que trop de lumiere, dont les nuits sont fort courtes, & qui les comptent apparemment pour de plus grands bienfaits de la Nature que leurs jours mesmes. Mais attendez, il me semble que Mars, qui est encore plus éloigné du Soleil que la Terre, n'a <IIM>point de Lune</IIM>. On ne peut pas vous le dissimuler, répondis-je, il n'en a point, & il faut qu'il ait pour ses nuits des ressources que nous ne sçavons pas. Vous avez veu des <SC>Phosphores</SC>, de ces matieres liquides ou seches, qui en recevant la lumiere du Soleil, s'en imbibent, & s'en penetrent, & ensuite jettent un assez grand éclat dans l'obscurité. <SC>Peut-estre Mars a-t-il</SC> de grands Rochers fort élevéz, qui sont des <SC>Phosphores</SC> naturels, & qui prennent pendant le jour une provision de lumiere qu'ils rendent pendant la nuit. Vous ne sçauriez nier que ce ne fust un Spectacle assez agreable, de voir tous ces Rochers s'alumer de toutes parts dés que le Soleil seroit couché, & faire sans aucun art des illuminations magnifiques. Vous sçavez encore qu'il y a en Amerique des Oyseaux qui sont si lumineux dans les tenebres, qu'on s'en peut servir pour lire. Que sçavons-nous si Mars n'a point un grand nombre de ces Oyseaux, qui dés que la nuit est venuë, se dispersent de tous costéz, & vont répandre un nouveau jour?</P078>
chunks.target_manual: <P058>Well, said the Marquiese, <NCP>(with the Air of a Person return'd to herself from some great astonishment)</NCP> all that you say is contriv'd with wonderful Order, and sure Nature has seen and provided for the necessity of some animate Beings; and that the distribution of these Moons, was not a work of Chance, since they are bestowed only upon these Planets, that are at a great distance from the Sun, the Earth, Iupiter and Saturn; for Venus and Mercury have no need on 'em; they enjoy but too much Light already; and their Nights are very short; and it may be the Inhabitants of this Planet esteem Night a greater benefit of Nature, than the Day it self. But hold, said Madam the Marquiese, it seems to me, that Mars, who is farther distant from the Sun than the Earth, <IIM>ought to have a Moon too </IIM>. I must confess, said I, Madam, he has none; but certainly, the Inhabitants of that Planet enjoy some other advantage, which supplies that defect. You have seen several bodies <SC></SC>, both liquid and dry, which draw in the Light of the Sun; and afterwards shine and cast a light in the dark. It may be, that there are <SC></SC> great Rocks very high; which are naturally of such a kind of Substance, as to receive great Provision of Light in the Day time from the Sun, which they restore in the Night; and if it be so, you cannot deny, but it must be a very pleasant Scene or Representation, to see all those Rocks from all Quarters begin to shine, as soon as the Sun is down, and make Magnificent Illuminations without Art or Expence. You know also that in America, there are certain Birds, which shine so in the dark; that one may read by their Light, as well as by that of a Candle; and who knows, but there are many of these Birds in the Planet Mars, which fly about and enlighten that World as soon as the Sun is set?</P058>

explanations: The French "a eu en veüe" (literally "had in view," meaning considered or kept in mind) regarding "les besoins" (the needs) is translated and expanded to "has seen and provided for the necessity." The addition of "and provided for" makes explicit an action (provision) by Nature that is only implied as a potential consequence of Nature "having in view" the needs, thus emphasizing Nature's active role.

The French pronoun "les" in "qui les comptent" (who apparently count/esteem them), referring to the inhabitants of Venus and Mercury or an impersonal "one", is made explicit in the translation as "the Inhabitants of this Planet" esteeming Night. (Note: "this Planet" appears to be a mistranslation for "these planets" or contextually "those planets" (Venus and Mercury), but the explicitation of "Inhabitants" as the agent performing the action of esteeming is the key aspect here). This clarifies who is doing the esteeming.

The French "il faut qu'il ait ... des ressources que nous ne sçavons pas." (it [Mars] must have ... resources that we don't know.) is translated as "the Inhabitants of that Planet enjoy some other advantage, which supplies that defect." This explicitation has two main parts: first, it makes the beneficiaries of the resources explicit ("the Inhabitants" instead of the planet Mars itself); second, the added clause "which supplies that defect" spells out the implied purpose of these resources/advantage (to compensate for Mars's lack of a moon, the "defect"), a connection only implied in the source's statement that Mars needs resources "pour ses nuits" (for its nights).

The French term "des Phosphores naturels" (natural phosphors) is expanded by the translator into a full description of their light-absorbing and emitting properties: "which are naturally of such a kind of Substance, as to receive great Provision of Light in the Day time from the Sun, which they restore in the Night". The source implies these properties by using the concise term; the target spells them out explicitly instead of using the term itself.

The French "un Spectacle assez agreable" (a rather agreeable sight/show) is translated and expanded to "a very pleasant Scene or Representation." The addition of "or Representation" alongside "Scene" clarifies and elaborates on the nature of the "Spectacle" by offering more specific or alternative English terms, making its visual and depictive qualities more explicit.

The French phrase "sans aucun art" (without any art/artifice), part of "faire sans aucun art des illuminations magnifiques" (to make magnificent illuminations without any art), is translated as "without Art or Expence." The addition of "or Expence" makes explicit an economic implication: that naturally occurring illuminations, being uncrafted, would also be without monetary cost. This idea is implied by "sans art" (in contrast to artificial, and thus potentially costly, human or intelligent endeavors) but is not directly stated in the source.

The French "qu'on s'en peut servir pour lire" (that one can use them/their light to read) implies a certain level of brightness sufficient for reading. The translation makes this level of brightness more explicit by adding the comparative phrase "as well as by that of a Candle," providing a familiar benchmark for the implied luminosity.

The French phrase "vont répandre un nouveau jour" (go to spread a new day/light) describes the action of the birds on Mars. The translation "enlighten that World" makes the object or location of this light-spreading explicit by specifying "that World" (referring to Mars). While Mars is the clear context of the discussion, the French phrase itself does not syntactically include "Mars" or "the world" as the direct object being enlightened; the translation spells this out.

chunks.source_manual: <P079>Je ne me contente, reprit-elle, ny de vos Rochers, ni de vos Oyseaux. Cela ne laisseroit pas d'estre joly, mais puis que la Nature a donné tant de Lunes à Saturne & à Jupiter, c'est une marque qu'il faut des Lunes. J'eusse esté bien-aise que tous les Mondes éloignez du Soleil en eussent eu, si Mars ne nous fust point venu faire une exception desagreable. Ah! vrayment, repliquay-je, si <LS><IIM>vous vous mêliez de Philosophie plus que vous ne faites</IIM></LS>, il faudroit bien que vous vous accoûtumassiez à voir des exceptions dans les meilleurs Sistêmes. Il y a toûjours quelque chose qui y convient le plus juste du monde, & puis quelque chose aussi qu'on y fait convenir comme on peut, ou qu'on laisse-là, si on desespere d'en pouvoir venir à bout. Usons-en de mesme pour Mars, puis qu'il ne nous est point favorable, & ne parlons point de luy. Nous serions bien étonnez, si nous estions dans Saturne, de voir sur nos testes pendant la nuit ce grand Anneau qui iroit en forme de demy Cercle d'un bout à l'autre de l'Horison, & qui nous renvoyant la lumiere du Soleil feroit l'effet d'une Lune continuë. Et ne mettrons-nous point d'Habitans dans ce grand Anneau, interrompit-elle en riant? Quoy que je sois d'humeur, répondis-je, à en envoyer par tout assez hardiment, je vous avoüe que je n'oserois en mettre là, cet Anneau me paroist une habitation trop irreguliere. Pour les cinq petites Lunes, on ne peut pas se dispenser de les peupler. Si cependant l'Anneau n'estoit, comme quelques-uns le soupçonnent, qu'un Cercle de Lunes qui se suivissent de fort prés, & eussent un mouvement égal, & que les cinq petites Lunes fussent trois échapées de ce grand Cercle, que de Mondes dans le Tourbillon de Saturne! Quoy qu'il en soit, avec le secours même de l'Anneau, les Gens de Saturne sont assez miserables. Il leur donne de la lumiere, mais quelle lumiere, dans l'éloignement où il est du Soleil! Le Soleil même n'est pour eux qu'une petite Etoile blanche & pâle, qui n'a qu'un éclat & une chaleur bien foible, & si vous les mettiez dans nos Pays les plus froids, dans la Groënlande, ou dans la Laponie, vous les verriez suër à grosses gouttes & expirer de chaud.</P079> <P080>Vous me donnez une idée de Saturne qui me gele, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, au lieu que tantost vous m'échauffiez en me parlant de Mercure. Il faut bien, repliquay-je, que les deux Mondes qui sont aux extremitez de ce grand Tourbillon, soient opposées en toutes choses.</P080> <P081>Ainsi, reprit-elle, on est bien sage dans Saturne, car vous m'avez dit que tout le monde estoit fou dans Mercure. Si on n'est pas bien sage dans Saturne, repris- je, du moins, selon toutes les apparences, on y est bien flegmatique. Ce sont Gens qui ne sçavent ce que c'est que de rire, qui prennent toûjours un jour pour répondre à la moindre question qu'on leur fait, & qui eussent trouvé Caton d'Utique <IIM>trop badin & trop folâtre</IIM>. <NCE></NCE>.</P081>
chunks.target_manual: <P059>Your Rocks, and your flying Birds, said the Marquiese, do not at all satisfie me. I confess such objects wou'd be very pretty; but since Nature has given so many Moons to Saturn and Iupiter; 'tis a sign, that they are absolutely necessary as well to Mars. I shou'd have been glad that all the Worlds distant from the Sun, cou'd have had their Moons; and that Mars might not have been so disagreeably excepted. Oh! Madam, said I, <IIM>if you think it worth your pains to make any further Progress in Philosophy, you must accustom your self to such Exceptions</IIM>; in the best Systems, there are always some things that agree exactly; but there are other things, that one must adjust as well as one can, or leave them as they are, if there be no hopes to overcome the difficulty: Let us do so if you please with Mars; and since he is not favourable to us, say no more of him. And tell me if it wou'd not be strangely surprizing, if we were in the World of Saturn, to see above our Heads in the Night that great Ring in the form of a Semi-Circle, going from opposite Points of the Horizon; and which reflecting the Light of the Sun upon us, wou'd have the effect of a continu'd Moon. And shall we place no Inhabitants upon that great Ring, said the Marquiese, laughing? I answer'd her, that (tho in the Humour I was in, I was enclin'd to put Inhabitants every where) I confess, I dare not set any upon so irregular a Habitation; but for the five little Moons, there is no dispensing with them, for they must have Inhabitants. But some do imagine, that this Ring or great Circle is compos'd of Moons join'd very near together, having all an equal Motion, and turning one way, and that the five little Moons I spoke of, had only escaped out of this great Ring; what an Infinity of Worlds are there then in the Tourbillion or whirlings of Saturn? and yet whatever is the Cause, the Inhabitants of Saturn are miserable enough, notwithstanding the Assistance of this great Ring. 'Tis true, it gives them Light, but what kind of Light? Sure a very feeble one at that great distance from the Sun, where she her self appears to 'em, but as a little pale Star, a very faint heat and Light, so that if you wou'd carry some of the Inhabitants of Saturn to our coldest Countries, as Green-Land, or Lap-Land, you wou'd see 'em all of a sweat, and melt away with heat. You give me an Idea of Saturn, said the Marquiese; that makes me shiver with cold; whereas before you warm'd me as much with the descriptions you gave me of Mercury. There is a Necessity, said I, that the two Worlds that are at the extremity of this great Tourbillion, must be contrary one to another in every thing. At that rate, said she, the Inhabitants of Saturn must be very wise; for you told me the Inhabitants of Mercury were down-right mad. If the People of Saturn, said I, be not wise, they are at least in all Appearance so, and are very flegmatick, they know not what it is to laugh; and who take a whole days time at least, to answer the most trifling Question: They wou'd have look'd upon the grave Cato <IIM>the Censor</IIM>, as <IIM>too wild and youthful for their Conversation </IIM>.</P059>

explanations: The French "qu'il faut des Lunes" (that moons are needed) suggests a general necessity. The English translation strengthens this by adding "absolutely" and explicitly extends this supposed necessity "as well to Mars" within the Marquise's initial inference, whereas the French text presents Mars's lack of moons as a subsequent, separate point of disappointment for her. This re-writing makes an explicit (and somewhat premature) connection to Mars's specific situation.

The French phrase "si vous vous mêliez de Philosophie plus que vous ne faites" (if you involved yourself in Philosophy more than you do) is expanded in the English translation to "if you think it worth your pains to make any further Progress in Philosophy." This addition of "worth your pains" and "further Progress" makes explicit the implied effort and deliberateness of engaging more deeply with philosophy, elaborating on the philosopher's polite suggestion.

The English translation adds the phrase "if you please" to the French "Usons-en de mesme pour Mars..." (Let us do the same for Mars...). This addition makes explicit a polite conversational deference or suggestion that was not formally marked in the French, thereby adjusting the social nuance of the dialogue for an English sensibility.

The French "d'un bout à l'autre de l'Horison" (from one end to the other of the Horizon) is rendered as "going from opposite Points of the Horizon." The English translation provides a more geometrically precise description, explicitly clarifying that for a semi-circle on the horizon, "from one end to the other" means from two opposite points.

The French text uses the Cartesian term "Tourbillon de Saturne." The English translation retains "Tourbillion" but immediately adds "or whirlings" as an explanatory gloss. This addition explicitly defines or clarifies the potentially unfamiliar scientific term for the English-speaking reader, aiding comprehension in a work of popular science.

In response to the Marquise's suggestion that Saturn's inhabitants are wise, the philosopher in French says, "Si on n'est pas bien sage dans Saturne... du moins, selon toutes les apparences, on y est bien flegmatique" (If one isn't very wise in Saturn... at least, according to all appearances, one is very phlegmatic there). The English translates this as, "If the People of Saturn... be not wise, they are at least in all Appearance so, and are very flegmatick." The addition of "so" (referring back to "wise") explicitly states that they *appear wise*, thus making the connection between being phlegmatic and appearing wise more direct than in the French, which states they appear phlegmatic, leaving the inference of appearing wise more implicit.

The French text refers to "Caton d'Utique" (Cato of Utica, i.e., Cato the Younger). The English translation changes this to "the grave Cato the Censor" (Cato the Elder). The addition of the epithet "the grave" makes an implicit characteristic (seriousness, moral austerity) of such a Roman figure explicit. Furthermore, replacing "d'Utique" with "the Censor" (another famously stern Roman) might be an attempt to use a more widely recognized or descriptively potent identifier of severity for an English audience, thus re-writing the reference to clarify the *type* of exemplary figure intended.

chunks.source_manual: <P082>Il me vient une pensée, dit-elle. Tous les Habitans de Mercure sont vifs, tous ceux de Saturne sont lens. Parmy nous les uns sont vifs, les autres lents; cela ne viendroit-il point de ce que nostre Terre étant justement au milieu des autres Mondes, nous participons des extremitez? Il n'y a point pour les hommes de Caractere fixe & déterminé; les uns sont faits comme les Habitans de Mercure, les autres comme ceux de Saturne, & nous sommes un mélange de toutes les especes qui se trouvent dans les autres Planetes. J'aime assez cette idée, repris- je, nous formons un assemblage si bizarre, qu'on pourroit croire que nous serions ramassez de plusieurs Mondes différens. A ce compte, il est assez commode d'estre icy, on y voit tous les autres Mondes en abregé.</P082> <P083>Du moins, reprit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, une commodité fort réelle qu'a nostre Monde par sa situation, c'est qu'il n'est ny si chaud que celuy de Mercure ou de Venus, ny si froid que celuy de Jupiter ou de Saturne. De plus, nous sommes justement dans un endroit de la Terre où nous ne sentons l'excés ny du chaud ni du froid. En verité si un certain Philosophe rendoit grace à la Nature d'estre Homme, & non pas Beste, Grec, & non pas Barbare, moy je veux luy rendre grace d'estre sur la Planete la plus tempérée de l'Univers, & dans un des lieux les plus temperez de cette Planete. Si vous m'en croyez, Madame, répondis-je, vous luy rendrez grace d'estre jeune & non pas vieille; jeune & belle, & non pas jeune & laide; jeune & belle Françoise, & non pas jeune & <UP></UP> belle Italienne. Voila bien d'autres sujets de reconnoissance que ceux que vous tirez de la situation de vostre Tourbillon, ou de la temperature de vostre Pays.</P083> <P084>Mon Dieu! repliqua-t-elle, laissez-moy avoir de la reconnaissance sur tout, jusque sur le Tourbillon où je suis placée. La mesure de bonheur qui nous a esté donnée, est assez petite; il n'en faut rien perdre, & il est bon d'avoir pour les choses les plus communes, & les moins considerables, un goust qui les mette à profit. Si on ne vouloit que des plaisirs vifs, on en auroit peu, on les attendroit long-temps, & on les payeroit bien. Vous me promettez donc, repliquay-je, que si on vous proposoit de ces plaisirs vifs, vous vous souviendriez des Tourbillons & de moy, & que vous vous borneriez à nous? Ouy, répondit-elle, mais faites que la Philosophie me fournisse toûjours des plaisirs nouveaux. Du moins pour demain, répondis-je, j'espere qu'ils ne vous manqueront pas. J'ai des Etoiles Fixes qui passent tout ce que vous avez veu jusqu'icy.</P084>
chunks.target_manual: <P060>There is a thought come into my Head, said the Marquiese; all the Inhabitants of Mercury are very lively, and the Inhabitants of Saturn extremely dull: Now upon our Earth, we have a mixture of both, some are very airy, and some as insipid: Does not that proceed from our being situate in the middle, between these two Worlds, that we participate so of the Qualities of both these Extremes; and there is no fixt settled Character of Mankind; some resemble the Inhabitants of Mercury, others of Saturn; and we are a mixture of all the several kinds of People, that inhabit all the other Planets? I like that Idea well enough, said I, we are of such an extravagant Composition, that one wou'd really believe, that we were collected and drawn together from all the other Worlds. And at this rate, 'tis very convenient to live in ours, since here we see an abridgement of all that can be seen in the other Worlds. At least, said the Marquiese, Our World has one real advantage and conveniency, that it is neither so hot as Mercury or Venus, nor so cold as Iupiter and Saturn: And we have the good luck over and above, to be born in a Climate of this Earth, that has neither excess of heat nor cold. And if a certain Philosopher thank'd Nature for being a Man and not a Beast, a Grecian, and not a Barbarian; for my Part, I thank her, that I inhabit the most temperate Planet of the Universe, and the most temperate Climate of that Planet. If you will trust me, said I, Madam, you ought to thank her for being young, and not old, young and handsome, and not young and ugly, young, handsome, and a French Woman, and not a young and handsome Italian. You have abundance of other Reasons of Gratitude, than those of the Situation of your Tourbillion, or the temperate Qualities of your Country. Good God, said she, suffer me to be grateful for every thing; even to the very Tourbillion where I was born: The measure of the Happiness bestow'd upon us, is too little to lose any part of it; and it is good to have such a Sense and Taste of the commonest and most considerable things, as to turn all to our Advantage and Profit. If we shou'd look after no other Pleasure or Satisfaction, than this World afforded, we shou'd enjoy but very few, expect 'em long, and pay dear for 'em. If Philosophy be the Pleasure, you propose, said I, Madam, I have the Boldness to wish, that when you remember the Tourbillions, you wou'd be pleas'd to think of me. Yes, answer'd she, provided you take care your Philosophy furnishes me always with new Pleasures. At least, for to Morrow, answer'd I, I hope you shall not want; for I have the fixed Stars prepared for you, which surpass all you have hitherto heard.</P060>

explanations: The French 'lents' (slow, dull) is translated as 'as insipid.' 'Insipid' specifies a particular quality of dullness (lacking spirit or character), and the comparative phrasing 'as insipid' (following 'very airy') makes the contrast with the 'vifs' (lively) characters more explicit and rhetorically heightened than the simpler 'lents.'

The French 'au milieu des autres Mondes' (in the middle of the other Worlds) is translated as 'in the middle, between these two Worlds.' This addition of 'between these two Worlds' makes explicit that 'autres Mondes' refers specifically to Mercury and Saturn, the two planets just mentioned, clarifying a connection that was only implied.

The French 'nous participons des extremitez' (we participate of the extremities) is expanded to 'we participate so of the Qualities of both these Extremes.' The addition of 'the Qualities of' spells out what is being participated in, and 'so' adds emphasis to the degree of participation, making the nature and extent of the connection more explicit.

The French phrase 'on y voit tous les autres Mondes en abregé.' (one sees there all the other worlds in abridgement/summary) is expanded in the translation to 'since here we see an abridgement of all that can be seen in the other Worlds.' The addition of 'of all that can be seen in' makes explicit the scope or content of what is seen in abridged form from the other worlds.

The singular French 'une commodité fort réelle' (a very real convenience/suitability/advantage) is translated using the doublet 'one real advantage and conveniency.' This explicitation spells out two distinct facets or interpretations of 'commodité,' making the nature of the benefit more detailed and emphatic.

The French 'justement dans un endroit de la Terre' (precisely in a place on Earth) is translated as 'to be born in a Climate of this Earth.' The introduction of 'Climate' makes explicit the specific aspect of the 'endroit' (place) that accounts for the subsequent description of balanced temperature, a connection merely implied in the source. The addition of 'to be born in' also specifies the nature of their presence in this location with greater detail.

The French 'dans un des lieux les plus temperez de cette Planete.' (in one of the most temperate places of this Planet) is translated as 'and the most temperate Climate of that Planet.' The change from 'lieux' (places) to 'Climate' makes explicit that the temperateness of the location refers specifically to its climatic conditions, rather than other possible interpretations of a 'temperate place.'

The French 'la temperature de vostre Pays.' (the temperature of your Country) is expanded to 'the temperate Qualities of your Country.' This explicitation clarifies that the reference is not just to a specific thermal measurement but to the broader set of beneficial, moderate characteristics or overall nature of her country implied by its temperateness.

The French 'le Tourbillon où je suis placée.' (the Vortex where I am placed/situated) referring to her existence within the Cartesian vortex system, is translated as 'the very Tourbillion where I was born:'. This makes an explicit claim about her origin or a lifelong connection to the Tourbillon, adding a specific biographical interpretation or assumption not explicitly present in the more general 'placée.'

The French 'un goust' (a taste) is translated as 'such a Sense and Taste.' The addition of 'Sense' to 'Taste' (a doublet) expands the original term, making explicit a broader or additional faculty of perception or appreciation beyond simple taste, or emphasizing discernment.

The French 'qui les mette à profit.' (that puts them to use/profit from them) is translated as 'as to turn all to our Advantage and Profit.' This expansion makes explicit the scope ('all'), the beneficiary ('our'), and uses the doublet 'Advantage and Profit' to elaborate on the nature of the benefit, which was more condensed in the source.

The French phrase 'Si on ne vouloit que des plaisirs vifs' (If one only wanted vivid/intense pleasures) is interpreted and rephrased by the translator as 'If we shou'd look after no other Pleasure or Satisfaction, than this World afforded'. This explicitation spells out the translator's understanding of these 'plaisirs vifs' as being specifically mundane or worldly pleasures, clarifying their nature and source.

In the source, the philosopher asks if the Marquise would remember 'des Tourbillons & de moy' (the vortices and me) if offered 'vivid pleasures,' implicitly positioning their shared discussions as an alternative. The translation rephrases this by explicitly identifying 'Philosophy' as 'the Pleasure' (which the Marquise supposedly proposes or is the subject of their engagement), thus spelling out the specific nature of their intellectual activity that was only implied by the personal and topical reference ('Tourbillons & de moy') in the source.

chunks.source_manual: <P085>CINQUIEME SOIR.</P085>
chunks.target_manual: <P061>The Fifth Night.</P061>
target_segments: Night
explanations: The French 'SOIR,' which translates to 'evening,' is used in the chapter title ('CINQUIEME SOIR'). The English translation renders this as 'Night' ('The Fifth Night'). This choice constitutes an explicitation by re-writing because it makes more explicit the astronomical context of the dialogues described in the book. While 'evening' (the direct translation of 'SOIR') broadly indicates the time of day, 'Night' more specifically points to the period of darkness optimal for observing stars and celestial bodies, which is the central subject of Fontenelle's work. The translator thereby clarifies and emphasizes the functional suitability of the setting for the book's astronomical themes, an aspect that is implied in the original by the combination of 'soir' and the subject matter, but made more direct by the choice of 'Night'.

chunks.source_manual: <P086><UP></UP>. La <IIM>Marquise</IIM> sentit une vraye impatience de sçavoir ce que les Etoiles Fixes deviendroient. Seront-elles habitées comme les Planetes, me dit-elle? Ne le seront-elles pas? Enfin qu'en ferons-nous? Vous le devineriez peut-estre, si vous en aviez bien envie, répondis-je. Les Etoiles Fixes ne sçauroient estre moins éloignées de la Terre que de quelques cinquante millions de lieuës, & si vous fâchiez un Astronome, il les mettroit encore plus loin. La distance du Soleil à la Planete la plus éloignée, n'est rien par rapport à la distance du Soleil ou de la Terre aux Etoiles Fixes, & on ne prend pas la peine de la compter. Leur lumiere, comme vous voyez, est assez vive & assez éclatante. Si elles la recevoient du Soleil, il faudroit qu'elles la receussent déja bien foible aprés un trajet de <IIM>cinquante millions de lieuës</IIM> <UP></UP>; il faudroit que par une reflexion qui l'affoibliroit encore beaucoup, elles nous la renvoyassent à cette mesme distance. Il seroit impossible qu'une lumiere qui auroit essuyé une reflexion, & fait deux fois <IIM>cinquante millions de lieuës</IIM>, eust cette force et cette vivacité qu'a celle des Etoiles Fixes. Les voila donc lumineuses par elles-mêmes, & toutes, en un mot, autant de Soleils.</P086> <P087>Ne me trompay-je point, s'écria la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, ou si je vois où vous me voulez mener? M'allez-vous dire: Les Etoiles Fixes sont autant de Soleils, nostre Soleil est le centre d'un Tourbillon qui tourne autour de luy, pourquoy chaque Etoile Fixe ne sera-t-elle pas aussi le centre d'un Tourbillon qui aura un mouvement autour d'elle? Nostre Soleil a des Planetes qu'il éclaire, pourquoy chaque Etoile Fixe n'en aura-t-elle pas aussi qu'elle éclairera? Je n'ay à vous répondre, luy dis-je, que ce que répondit Phedre à Enone, C'est toy qui l'as nommé. <UP></UP>.</P087> <P088>Mais, reprit-elle, voila l'Univers si grand que je m'y perds, je ne sçais plus où je suis, <RW>je ne suis plus rien</RW>. Quoy, tout sera divisé en Tourbillons jettez confusément les uns parmi les autres? Chaque Etoile sera le centre d'un Tourbillon peut-estre aussi grand que celuy où nous sommes? Tout cet espace immense qui comprend nostre Soleil & nos Planetes, ne sera qu'une petite parcelle de l'Univers? Autant d'espaces pareils que d'Etoiles Fixes? <UP></UP>. Cela me confond, me trouble, m'épouvante. Et moy, répondis-je, cela me met à mon aise. Quand le Ciel n'estoit que cette voûte bleuë, où les Etoiles estoient cloüées, l'Univers me paroissoit petit & étroit, je m'y sentois comme oppressé; presentement qu'on a donné infiniment plus d'étenduë & de profondeur à cette voûte <UP></UP>, en la partageant en mille & mille <RW>Tourbillons</RW>, il me semble que je respire avec plus de liberté, & que je suis dans un plus grand air, & asseurement l'Univers a toute une autre magnificence. La Nature n'a rien épargné en le produisant, elle a fait une profusion des richesses qui est tout-à-fait digne d'elle. Rien n'est si beau à se representer que ce nombre prodigieux de Tourbillons, dont le milieu est occupé par un Soleil qui fait tourner des Planetes autour de luy. Les Habitans d'une Planete d'un de ces Tourbillons infinis voyent de tous costez les centres lumineux des Tourbuillons dont ils sont environnez, mais ils n'ont garde d'en voir les Planetes qui n'ayant qu'une lumiere foible, empruntée de leur Soleil, ne la poussent point au delà de leur Monde.<UP></UP>.</P088> <P089>Vous m'offrez, dit-elle, une espece de Perspective si longue, que la veuë n'en peut attraper le bout. Je voy clairement les Habitans de la Terre, ensuite vous me faites voir ceux de la Lune & des autres Planetes de nostre Tourbillon assez clairement à la verité, mais moins que ceux de la Terre; apres eux viennent les Habitans des Planetes des autres Tourbillons. Je vous avoüe qu'ils sont tout-à-fait dans l'enfoncement, & que quelque effort que je fasse pour les voir, je ne les apperçois presque point. Et en effet ne sont-ils pas presque aneantis par l'expression dont vous estes obligé de vous servir en parlant d'eux? Il faut que vous les appeliez, les Habitans d'une des Planetes, de l'un de ces Tourbillons infinis? <IIM>Nous mesmes, à qui la mesme expression convient, avoüez que vous ne sçauriez presque plus nous déméler au milieu de tant de Mondes</IIM>. Pour moy, je commence à voir la Terre si effroyablement petite, que je ne croy pas avoir desormais d'empressement pour aucune chose. <IIM>Asseurément, si on a tant d'ardeur de s'agrandir, si on fait desseins sur desseins, si on se donne tant de peine, c'est que l'on ne connoist pas les Tourbillons</IIM>. <UP></UP>. Je pretends bien que ma paresse profite de mes nouvelles lumieres, & quand on me reprochera mon indolence, je répondray: Ah! si vous sçaviez ce que c'est que les Etoiles Fixes! Il faut qu'Alexandre ne l'ait pas sceu, repliquay-je, car un certain Auteur qui tient que la Lune est habitée, dit fort serieusement qu'il n'estoit pas possible qu'Aristote ne fust dans une opinion si raisonnable (comment une verité eust-elle échappé à Aristote?) <UP></UP> mais qu'il n'en voulut jamais rien dire, de peur de déplaire, à Alexandre, qui eust esté au despoir de voir un Monde qu'il n'eust pas pû conquerir. A plus forte raison luy eust-on fait mystere des Tourbillons, des Etoiles Fixes, quand on les eust connus en ce temps-là; c'eust esté faire trop mal sa Cour que de luy en parler. Pour moy qui les connois, je suis bien fâché de ne pouvoir tirer d'utilité de la connoissance que j'en ay. Ils ne guerissent tout au plus, selon vostre raisonnement, que de l'ambition & de l'inquietude, & je n'ay point ces maladies-là. Un peu de foiblesse pour ce qui est beau, voila mon mal, & je ne croy pas que les Tourbillons y puissent rien. Les autres Mondes vous rendent celuy-cy petit, mais ils ne vous gâtent point de beaux yeux, ou une belle bouche, cela vaut toûjours son prix en dépit de tous les Mondes possibles.</P089>
chunks.target_manual: <P062><UP>MY</UP> Lady Marquiese was very impatient to know what shou'd become of the fix'd Stars. Can they be inhabited as the Planets are, said she to me? or are they not inhabited? what shall we make of 'em? If you wou'd take the Pains, you cou'd not fail to guess, said I, Madam, the fixt Stars cannot be less distant from the Earth, than <IIM>fifty Millions of Leagues</IIM>; nay, some Astronomers make the distance yet greater; that between the Sun and the remotest Planet is nothing if compared to the distance between the Sun or Earth, and the fix'd Stars; we do not trouble our selves to number 'em, their Lustre as you see is both clear and bright. If the fix'd Stars, receive their Light from the Sun, it must certainly be very weak and faint before it comes to 'em, having passed through a <IIM>hundred and fifty Millions of Miles</IIM> of the Celestial Substance, I spoke of before: Then consider, the fix'd Stars are oblig'd, to reflect this borrow'd Light upon us at the same distance, which Is every fixt Star the Center of a Tourbillion; and it may be full as big as our Sun? Is it possible, that all this Immense space, wherein our Sun and Planets have their Revolution, is nothing but an inconsiderable part of the Universe? And that every fix'd Star must comprehend and govern an equal space with our Sun? This confounds, afflicts, and frightens me. And for my part, said I, it pleases and rejoices me; when I believ'd the Universe to be nothing, but this great Azure Vault of the Heavens, wherein the Stars were placed, as it were so many golden Nails or Studs, the Universe seem'd to me too little and strait; I fansied my self to be confin'd and oppress'd: But now when I am perswaded, that this Azure Vault has a greater depth and a vaster Extent, and that 'tis divided into a thousand and a thousand different Tourbillions or Whirlings, I imagine I am at more Liberty, and breath a freer Air; and the Universe appears to me to be infinitely more Magnificent. Nature has spared nothing in her Production, and hath profusely bestow'd her Treasures upon a glorious Work worthy of her: You can represent nothing so august to your self, as this prodigious Number of Tourbillions, whose Center is possess'd by a Sun, that makes the Planets turn round him. The Inhabitants of the Planets of any of these infinite Tourbillions, see from all sides the enlightned Center of the Tourbillion with which they are inviron'd; but cannot discover the Planets of another, who enjoy but a faint Light, borrow'd from their own Sun, which it does not dart further than its own Sphere or Activity. You show me, said the Marquiese, so vast a Prospect, that my sight cannot reach to the end of it: I see clearly the Inhabitants of our World; and you have plainly presented to my Reason the Inhabitants of the Moon, and other Planets of our Tourbillion or Whirling: After this you tell me of the Inhabitants of the Planets of all the other Tourbillions. I confess, they seem to me to be sunk into so boundless a depth, that whatever force I put upon my Fancy, I cannot comprehend 'em; and indeed you have annihilated 'em by the Expressions you made use of in speaking of 'em and their Inhabitants. You must certainly call 'em the Inhabitants of one of the Planets, of one of these infinite Tourbillions; and what shall become of us in the middle of so many Worlds; since the Title you give to the rest agrees to this of ours? And for my Part, I see the Earth so dreadfully little, that hereafter I shall scorn to be concern'd for any part of it. <UP>And I admire why Mankind are so very fond of Power </UP>, so earnest after Grandure, laying design upon design, circumventing, betraying, flattering, and poorly lying, and are at all this mighty Pains to grasp a part of a World they neither know nor understand, nor any thing of these mighty Tourbillions: For me, I'll lazily contemn it, and my carelesness shall have this Advantage by my Knowledge, that when any Body shall reproach me with my Poverty, I will with vanity reply, Oh! you do not know what the fix'd Stars are. I do believe, said I, Madam, that Alexander the Great himself did not know: For a certain Author who holds that the Moon is inhabited, says very gravely, that it was impossible, but Aristotle must be of so reasonable an Opinion (for how cou'd such a truth escape so <UP>great a Man</UP> as Aristotle?) but that he wou'd never say any thing of it for fear of displeasing Alexander; for had he known there had been a World which he cou'd not have conquer'd, it wou'd have reduc'd him to certain Despair. There was yet more Reason to conceal the Tourbillions of the fix'd Stars from him; if they had been known in those Days, he wou'd have made his Court very ill to that great Prince, who shou'd but have mention'd 'em. As for me who know 'em, I am very sorry I can draw no advantage from that Knowledge, which can cure nothing but Ambition and Disquiet, and none of these Diseases trouble me. I confess a kind of Weakness in Love, a kind of frailty for what is delicate and handsom, this is my Distemper, wherein the Tourbillions are not concern'd at all. The infinite Multitude of other Worlds may render this little in your Esteem, but they do not spoil fine Eyes, a pretty Mouth, or make the Charms of Wit ever the less: These will still have their true Value, still bear a price in spight of all the Worlds in the Universe.</P062>
