explanations: The French 'un trajet de cinquante millions de lieuës' (a journey of fifty million leagues) is translated with the addition 'of the Celestial Substance, I spoke of before'. This makes explicit the medium (Cartesian ether, referred to as 'Celestial Substance') through which light travels and links it to a presumed earlier explanation by the philosopher, information not present in the original French phrase.

The French 'où les Etoiles estoient cloüées' (where the stars were nailed) hints at an archaic cosmological model. The translation 'wherein the Stars were placed, as it were so many golden Nails or Studs' makes this allusion explicit by adding the descriptive simile 'as it were so many golden Nails or Studs,' fully articulating the pre-Copernican imagery.

The French 'en mille & mille Tourbillons' (into a thousand and a thousand Vortices) is translated as 'into a thousand and a thousand different Tourbillions or Whirlings'. The translator adds 'or Whirlings' as an English gloss for 'Tourbillions,' explicitly providing a synonym to ensure comprehension for an English audience potentially unfamiliar with the specific Cartesian term.

The French 'ne la poussent point au delà de leur Monde..' (do not push it beyond their World) is translated as 'which it does not dart further than its own Sphere or Activity.'. The translator makes the vague 'leur Monde' more specific by defining its limit as the sun's 'Sphere or Activity,' employing a more technical and explicit astronomical/physical concept.

The French 'de nostre Tourbillon' (of our Vortex) is translated as 'of our Tourbillion or Whirling'. Similar to a previous instance, the addition of 'or Whirling' explicitly provides an English equivalent for the French term 'Tourbillion' to aid reader understanding.

The French 'à qui la mesme expression convient' (to whom the same expression is fitting/suitable) is expanded to 'since the Title you give to the rest agrees to this of ours?'. This translation spells out the implied relationship by explicitly identifying 'l'expression' as a 'Title' and clarifying the comparison being made between 'us' and 'the rest'.

The general French phrase 'si on se donne tant de peine' (if one gives oneself so much trouble/pain) is significantly expanded to 'circumventing, betraying, flattering, and poorly lying, and are at all this mighty Pains to grasp a part of a World they neither know nor understand'. The translator makes explicit the kinds of human folly and effort by adding a list of specific negative actions and an explanatory clause about ignorance, which were only implied by Fontenelle's more general statement.

The French parenthetical question '(comment une verité eust-elle échappé à Aristote?)' (how could a truth have escaped Aristotle?) is translated as '(for how cou'd such a truth escape so great a Man as Aristotle?)'. The addition of 'so great a Man as' makes explicit the implied high esteem and authority of Aristotle, which underpins the surprise in Fontenelle's rhetorical question.

The French 'Un peu de foiblesse pour ce qui est beau' (A little weakness for what is beautiful) is translated as 'a kind of Weakness in Love, a kind of frailty for what is delicate and handsom'. The addition of 'in Love' specifies the domain of this weakness, making an implicit potential interpretation (especially in a gallant conversation) explicit. Fontenelle's phrase is more general.

The French 'mais ils ne vous gâtent point de beaux yeux, ou une belle bouche' (but they don't spoil for you beautiful eyes, or a beautiful mouth) lists only physical attributes. The translation 'but they do not spoil fine Eyes, a pretty Mouth, or make the Charms of Wit ever the less' expands this by adding an intellectual/social attribute, 'or make the Charms of Wit ever the less,' making explicit a type of enduring value that was unstated in the original.

chunks.source_manual: <P090>C'est une étrange chose que l'Amour, répondit-elle en riant; il se sauve de tout, & il n'y a point de Systême qui luy puisse faire de mal. Mais aussi parlez-moy franchement, vostre Systême est-il bien vray? Ne me déguisez rien, je vous garderay le secret. Il me semble qu'il n'est appuyé que sur une petite convenance bien legere. Une Etoile Fixe & lumineuse d'elle-mesme comme le Soleil, par consequent il faut qu'elle soit comme le Soleil, le centre & l'ame d'un Monde, & qu'elle ait ses Planetes qui tournent autour d'elle. Cela est-il d'une necessité bien absoluë? Ecoutez, Madame, répondis-je, puis que nous sommes en humeur de mêler toûjours des folies de galanterie à nos Discours les plus serieux, les raisonnemens de Mathematique sont faits comme l'Amour. Vous ne sçauriez accorder si peu de chose à un Amant, que bien-tost aprés il ne faille luy en accorder davantage, & puis encore davantage, & à la fin cela va loin. De mesme accordez à un Mathematicien le moindre principe, il va vous en tirer une consequence, qu'il faudra que vous luy accordiez aussi, & de cette consequence encore une autre, & malgré vous-mesme il vous mene si loin, qu'à peine le pouvez-vous croire. Ces deux sortes de Gens-là prennent toûjours plus qu'on ne leur donne. Vous convenez que quand deux choses sont semblables en tout ce qui me paroist, je les puis croire aussi semblables en ce qui ne me paroist point, s'il n'y a rien d'ailleurs qui m'en empesche. De là j'ay tiré que la Lune estoit habitée, parce qu'elle ressemble à la Terre, les autres Planetes, parce qu'elles ressemblent à la Lune. Je trouve que les Etoiles Fixes ressemblent à nostre Soleil, je leur attribuë tout ce qu'il a. Vous estes engagée trop avant pour pouvoir reculer, il faut franchir le pas de bonne grace. Mais, dit-elle, sur le pied de cette ressemblance que vous mettez entre les Etoiles Fixes & nostre Soleil, il faut que les Gens d'un autre grand Tourbillon ne le voyent que comme une petite Etoile Fixe, qui se montre à eux seulement pendant leurs nuits.</P090> <P091>Cela est hors de doute, répondis-je. Nostre Soleil est si proche de nous en comparaison des Soleils des autres Tourbillons, que sa lumiere doit avoir infiniment plus de force sur nos yeux que la leur. Nous ne voyons donc que luy quand nous le voyons, & il efface tout; mais dans un autre grand Tourbillon c'est un autre Soleil qui y domine, & il efface à son tour le nostre, qui n'y paroist que pendant les nuits avec le reste des autres Soleils étrangers, c'est à dire, des Etoiles Fixes. On l'attache avec elles à cette grande voûte du Ciel, & il y fait partie de quelque Ourse, ou de quelque Taureau. Pour les Planetes qui tournent autour de luy, <NCP>nostre Terre, par exemple</NCP>, comme on ne les voit point de si loin, on n'y songe seulement pas. Ainsi tous les Soleils, sont Soleils de jour pour le Tourbillon où ils sont placez, & Soleils de nuit pour tous les autres Tourbillons. Dans leur Monde, ils sont les uniques de leur espece, par tout ailleurs ils ne servent qu'à faire nombre. Ne faut-il pas pourtant, reprit-elle, que les Mondes, malgré cette égalité different en mille choses, car un fond de ressemblance ne laisse de porter des differences infinies?</P091>
chunks.target_manual: <P063>It is a strange thing, said the Marquiese laughing, that Love saves himself from all Dangers, and there is no Systeme or Opinion can hurt him: But tell me frankly, are your Systemes certainly true? Do not dissemble, for I promise to keep it secret: I fansie 'tis founded upon a very small bottom, a fix'd Star enlightned of it self, as the Sun is, and therefore it must be a Sun, the Soul and Center of the World having Planets turning round it as that also has. Is this absolutely necessary, says she? I fear, Madam, said I: Since we are always in the humour of mixing some little Gallantries with our most serious Discourses, give me leave to tell you, that Mathematical reasoning is in some things near a-kin to Love; and you cannot allow the smallest Favour to a Lover, but he will soon perswade you to yield another, and after that a little more, and in the end prevails entirely; so if you grant the least Principle to a Mathematician, he will instantly draw a consequence from it, which you must yield also, and from that another, and then a third, and maugre all your Resistance, in a short time, he will lead you so far, that you cannot retreat. These two sorts of Men, The Lover and Philosopher always take more than is given 'em. You must acknowledge that when I see two Objects alike in every thing that I do see, I have Reason to believe them to be also alike in what I see not; for where is the hindrance or difficulty? From thence I have argu'd that the Moon is inhabited because it is like the Earth; that the other Planets are inhabited because they are like the Moon. I find that the fix'd Stars are like our Sun as to what I see; and therefore, I conclude they are Suns, and have Planets turning round about 'em; and every thing else we attribute to our Suns. Now, Madam, you are too far engag'd to retire; and therefore you must generously yield. By this rule of resemblance, said she, which you make betwixt our Sun and the fix'd Stars, the Inhabitants of another Tourbillion, must only see our Sun as a small fix'd Star, which only appears to them, during their Night. Without doubt, said I, Madam, our Sun is so near us, in respect of the Suns of the other Tourbillions, that his Light must have infinitely greater force upon our Sight than the Light of the other Suns; when we see our Sun, we see nothing else, his brightness makes all other things disappear: In another great Tourbillion, where another Sun governs, he in his turn removes and darkens our Sun, which does not appear, but in the Night as a fix'd Star amongst the other strange Suns (that is) fix'd Stars, and our Sun appears to the Inhabitants of that Tourbillion in the great Vault of the Heavens, as a Star of some Constellation, such as the Bear or the Bull: As to the Planets which turn round about him <NCP>(as our Earth for example)</NCP> since they cannot see it at so great a distance, they do not so much as think of it, so that all these Suns are Suns by day for the Tourbillion which they govern, and fix'd Stars by Night; for all the other, every one of them is the only one of his kind in his own World; but serve only to make up the Number of fix'd Stars for all the other Worlds. Notwithstanding, said she, of this Equality of Resemblance of the Worlds, yet I cannot believe, but they differ in a thousand things, for likeness upon the main does not hinder infinite little differences.</P063>

explanations: The French 'Systême' (System) could refer to a structured philosophical or scientific system. The English translation 'Systeme or Opinion' explicitly broadens this to include 'Opinion,' clarifying that it encompasses not only formal systems but also more general viewpoints or beliefs, which was only implied in the French within the conversational context.

The French 'qu'elle ait ses Planetes qui tournent autour d'elle' (that it [the star] has its planets that turn around it) implies that a star like the Sun would also have planets. The English 'having Planets turning round it as that also has' explicitly adds 'as that also has,' spelling out that 'that' (our Sun) possesses planets, thereby reinforcing the analogical step in the argument.

The French 'les raisonnemens de Mathematique sont faits comme l'Amour.' (Mathematical reasonings are made like Love.) directly states the analogy. The English translation prefaces this with 'give me leave to tell you,' an added discourse marker that makes the speaker's act of introducing the comparison explicit, highlighting the rhetorical move more directly than the French.

In the context of courtship ('Amant'), the French 'si peu de chose' (so small a thing) is translated as 'the smallest Favour.' The English 'Favour' explicitly specifies the nature of the 'small thing' being conceded, making explicit information that was implied by the gallant context in the French.

The French 'cela va loin' (that goes far) describes the escalating consequence of yielding in an argument or to a lover. The English 'prevails entirely' makes the ultimate outcome of this escalation explicit by specifying complete success or dominance, offering a more definitive and spelled-out interpretation of the French phrase.

The French '& de cette consequence encore une autre' (and from this consequence yet another) implies an ongoing series of consequences. The English 'and from that another, and then a third' makes this iterative process more concrete and explicit by enumerating a specific next step ('a third'), whereas the French leaves the continuation more open-ended.

The French 'qu'à peine le pouvez-vous croire' (that you can hardly believe it) describes the astonishing extent of mathematical deduction. The English 'that you cannot retreat' shifts the focus by explicitly stating the consequence as the irreversible commitment to the conclusions drawn. This makes a specific type of consequence (inescapability) explicit, which was only one possible implication of being led 'si loin' (so far) in French.

The French 'Ces deux sortes de Gens-là' (These two sorts of people there) implicitly refers to the previously discussed lover and mathematician/philosopher. The English 'These two sorts of Men, The Lover and Philosopher' explicitly names these categories, making the referents of 'Gens-là' clear and directly stated.

The French 'je leur attribuë tout ce qu'il a.' (I attribute to them all that it [our Sun] has.) is a concise statement. The English expansion 'and therefore, I conclude they are Suns, and have Planets turning round about 'em; and every thing else we attribute to our Suns.' explicitly details what 'all that it has' entails in this astronomical context (being suns, having planets), spelling out the conclusion and specific attributes implied by the French.

The French 'il faut franchir le pas de bonne grace.' (one must take the step/plunge with good grace.) is an idiomatic expression for accepting a situation. The English 'and therefore you must generously yield.' makes the nature of this 'step' explicit in the context of an argument: it is an act of 'yielding' to the reasoning, with 'generously' capturing 'de bonne grace.'

The French 'que la leur.' (than theirs.) elliptically refers to 'la lumière des autres Soleils' (the light of the other Suns). The English translation 'than the Light of the other Suns;' explicitly spells out the elided noun 'Light' and its possessors 'of the other Suns,' resolving the pronominal reference and making the comparison fully explicit.

The French 'il efface tout;' (it erases/effaces everything;) concisely describes the sun's overwhelming effect. The English 'his brightness makes all other things disappear:' explicitly states the cause of this effect ('his brightness') and provides a more descriptive consequence ('makes all other things disappear'), clarifying the mechanism and result that was more generally stated in French.

The French 'il efface à son tour le nostre' (it, in its turn, effaces ours [our Sun]) uses the general verb 'effacer' (to efface/erase). The English translation 'he in his turn removes and darkens our Sun' explicitly details *how* the other sun 'effaces' our Sun from view, by specifying the visual effects of 'removes and darkens.'

The French uses the impersonal 'On l'attache avec elles à cette grande voûte du Ciel,' (One attaches it with them to this great vault of the Sky,). The English 'and our Sun appears to the Inhabitants of that Tourbillion in the great Vault of the Heavens,' makes explicit who the perceivers are ('the Inhabitants of that Tourbillion') and the nature of the phenomenon (it 'appears' to them), shifting from an abstract 'attachment' to an explicit perceptual experience.

The French 'il y fait partie de quelque Ourse, ou de quelque Taureau.' (it there is part of some Bear or some Bull.) implies that the Bear and Bull are celestial groupings. The English 'as a Star of some Constellation, such as the Bear or the Bull:' explicitly adds the categorizing term 'Constellation,' clarifying the nature of these astronomical figures.

The French 'où ils sont placez' (where they are placed) describes the location of the Suns in their respective Tourbillions. The English 'which they govern' explicitly adds the functional role of the Sun within its system, stating its dominance or regulatory influence ('govern'), a concept implied by Cartesian physics but spelled out here.

The French 'Soleils de nuit' (Suns of night) is a somewhat paradoxical phrase. The English 'fix'd Stars by Night' explicitly clarifies how these 'Suns of night' are perceived from other tourbillons—as fixed stars—thus resolving the potential ambiguity by providing the specific astronomical equivalent.

The French 'ils ne servent qu'à faire nombre.' (they only serve to make up a number / to count.) is a general statement about the role of distant suns. The English 'but serve only to make up the Number of fix'd Stars for all the other Worlds.' explicitly specifies what kind of 'number' they contribute to—'the Number of fix'd Stars'—clarifying their perceived role in the cosmos from the perspective of other worlds.

chunks.source_manual: <P092>Assurément, repris-je, mais la difficulté est de deviner. Que sçay-je? Un Tourbillon a plus de Planetes qui tournent autour de son Soleil, un autre en a moins. Dans l'un il y a des Planetes subalternes, qui tournent autour des Planetes plus grandes; dans l'autre il n'y en a point. Icy elles sont toutes ramassées autour de leur Soleil <UP></UP>, & font comme un petit peloton, au-delà duquel s'étend un grand espace vuide, qui va jusqu'aux Tourbillons voisins; ailleurs elles prennent leur cours vers les extremitez du Tourbillon & laissent le milieu vuide. Je ne doute pas mesme qu'il ne puisse y avoir quelques Tourbillons deserts, & sans Planetes, d'autres dont le Soleil, n'estant pas justement au centre, ait un veritable mouvement, & emporte ses Planetes avec soy; d'autres dont les Planetes s'élèvent ou s'abaissent à l'égard de leur Soleil par le changement de l'équilibre qui les tient suspenduës. Enfin, que voudriez-vous? En voila bien assez pour un homme qui n'est jamais sorty de son Tourbillon.</P092>
chunks.target_manual: <P064>Most certainly, said I; but the difficulty will be, to find out those Differences. What do I know but in one Tourbillion, there are more Planets turning round it than in another? In one there are Inferior Planets turning round the greater, in another there are none at all: In one Tourbillion the Planets are gather'd together, as it were a little Party, round their Sun, and beyond them a vast Vacuity, extending to the next Tourbillion; in another, the Planets take their Course towards the Extremity of their Tourbillion, and leave a Void in the middle, and I do not doubt but there are Tourbillions destitute of Planets; and others, where their Sun is not plac'd in the middle, and yet has a free Motion, and carries his Planets round with him; others, where the Planets rise and fall in respect of their Sun, according to the Changes of the Counterpoise which balances 'em. What wou'd you have, Madam? Have not I said enough for a Man that was never out of his own Tourbillion?</P064>
target_segments: to find out those Differences
In one Tourbillion
in another
the Counterpoise
What wou'd you have, Madam?
explanations: The French verb "deviner" (to guess, surmise) is general. The English translation "to find out those Differences" explicitly states the object of the guessing process—"those Differences"—which refers to the potential variations between cosmic systems (Tourbillons) that the philosopher is about to enumerate. This object is only implied by the subsequent list in the French text.

The French adverb "Icy" (Here), used metaphorically to mean "in this case" or "in one instance," is translated as "In one Tourbillion." This change makes the implicit referent of "Icy"—a specific type of cosmic system (a Tourbillon, central to Cartesian physics as popularized by Fontenelle)—explicit, grounding the abstract case in the concrete subject of discussion.

The French adverb "ailleurs" (elsewhere), used metaphorically to mean "in another case" or "in other instances," is translated as "in another." Following the pattern established by the translation of "Icy" as "In one Tourbillion," this "another" explicitly refers to "another Tourbillion." The translation thus makes the specific context of comparison (different types of Tourbillons) explicit, where the French relies on the general flow of argument.

The French "l'équilibre" (the equilibrium/balance) is a general term for the state that maintains planetary positions. The English translation uses "the Counterpoise," which in the 17th-century scientific context often referred to a more specific mechanism or force that creates balance (e.g., a counterbalancing weight or influence). This choice makes the nature of the balancing principle more explicit and suggestive of a mechanical model than the broader French term.

The French question "que voudriez-vous?" is addressed to the Marquise using the pronoun "vous." The English translation "What wou'd you have, Madam?" explicitly adds "Madam," directly naming the addressee. This clarifies the specific interlocutor where the French relies on the dialogic context of "vous."

chunks.source_manual: <P093>Ce n'en est guere, répondit-elle, pour la quantité des Mondes. Ce que vous dites ne suffit que pour cinq ou six, & j'en voy d'icy des milliers?</P093>
chunks.target_manual: <P065>No, said she, not for the quantity of Worlds which you say there is: What you have describ'd will suffice but for five or six, and I see thousands.</P065>
target_segments: the quantity of Worlds which you say there is
What you have describ'd
explanations: The French phrase "la quantité des Mondes" (the quantity of Worlds), within the conversational context, implicitly refers to the number of worlds previously outlined or suggested by the philosopher. The English translation "the quantity of Worlds which you say there is" makes this implicit reference explicit by adding the relative clause "which you say there is". This addition directly attributes the proposition of this specific "quantity of Worlds" to the philosopher's preceding statements, clarifying a connection that was left unstated in the more elliptical French original.

The French "Ce que vous dites" (literally "What you say") is a general reference to the philosopher's preceding discourse. The English translation "What you have describ'd" renders this more specifically, making explicit the *nature* of the philosopher's communication as being a "description." While the philosopher's utterances do involve describing astronomical concepts, the French verb "dire" (to say/tell) is broader. The translator's choice of "describ'd" specifies and highlights one particular aspect (the descriptive one) of the philosopher's speech, which was implied but not explicitly defined by the general verb in the source text.

chunks.source_manual: <P094>Que serait-ce donc, repris-je, si je vous disois qu'il y a bien d'autres Etoiles Fixes, que celles que vous voyez; qu'avec des Lunettes on en découvre un nombre infiny qui ne se montrent point aux yeux, & que dans une seule Constellation, où l'on en comptoit peut-estre douze ou quinze <RW></RW>, il s'en trouve autant que l'on en voyoit <UP></UP> auparavant dans tout le Ciel?</P094>
chunks.target_manual: <P066>What wou'd you say, Madam, said I, if I shou'd tell you that there are infinitely more fixed Stars than those you see, that by the help of Telescopes an uncountable number are discover'd, which we cannot see with our Eyes alone; and that in one Constellation, where we counted but twelve or fifteen <RW>fixed Stars </RW>, there have been discover'd more than we see with our Eyes in the whole Heavens?</P066>
source_segments: qui ne se montrent point aux yeux
target_segments: Telescopes
which we cannot see with our Eyes alone
twelve or fifteen fixed Stars
we see with our Eyes
explanations: The French "Lunettes," in the context of astronomical observation in Fontenelle's work, implicitly refers to telescopes ('lunettes d'approche'). The translator makes this specific meaning explicit by using the term "Telescopes," thereby removing potential ambiguity with eyeglasses and clarifying for the English reader the scientific instrument being discussed.

The French phrase "qui ne se montrent point aux yeux" (which are not visible to the eyes/do not show themselves to the eyes) implies that these stars are invisible to unaided vision. The translator makes this implication explicit by adding "alone" after "with our Eyes," thereby specifying that the limitation is for the naked eye, contrasting with vision aided by instruments.

The French "douze ou quinze" (twelve or fifteen) is part of the phrase "où l'on en comptoit peut-estre douze ou quinze" (where one counted perhaps twelve or fifteen of them). The pronoun "en" (of them) and the preceding context of "Etoiles Fixes" (Fixed Stars) imply that stars are being counted. The translator makes the object of the count explicit by adding "fixed Stars" directly after the numerals in the target text.

The French "l'on en voyoit" (one saw of them/one used to see of them), from the phrase "que l'on en voyoit auparavant dans tout le Ciel" (than one previously saw of them in the whole Sky), refers to stars visible before the advent or use of "Lunettes" (telescopes) and thus implies observation with the naked eye. The translator makes this implicit mode of seeing explicit by adding "with our Eyes" in the target text.

chunks.source_manual: <P095>Je vous demande grace, s'écria-t-elle, je me rends, vous m'accablez de Mondes & de Tourbillons. Je sçay bien, ajoûtay-je, ce que je vous garde ancore. Vous voyez cette blancheur qu'on appelle la Voye de Lait. Vous figureriez-vous bien ce que c'est? Une infinité de petites Etoiles invisibles aux yeux à cause de leur petitesse, & semées si prés les unes des autres qu'elles paroissent former une blancheur continuë. Je voudrois que vous vissiez avec des Lunettes cette Fourmilliere d'Astres, & cette graine de Mondes (si ces expressions sont permises.) Ils ressemblent en quelque sorte aux Isles Maldives, à ces douze mille petites Isles ou Bancs de Sable, separez seulement par des Canaux de Mer, que l'on sauteroit presque comme des Fossez. Ainsi les petits Tourbillons de la Voye de Lait sont si serrez, qu'il me semble que d'un Monde à l'autre on pourroit se parler, ou mesme se donner la main. Du moins je croy que les Oyseaux d'un Monde passent aisément dans un autre, & que l'on y peut dresser des Pigeons à porter des Lettres comme on fait icy dans le Levant. Ces petits Mondes sortent apparemment de la regle generale, par laquelle un Soleil dans son Tourbillon efface dés qu'il paroist tous les Soleils étrangers. Si vous estes dans un des petits Tourbillons de la Voye de Lait, vostre Soleil n'est presque pas plus proche de vous, & par consequent n'a pas sensiblement plus de force sur vos yeux, que cent mille autres Soleils des Tourbillons voisins. Vous voyez donc vostre Ciel briller d'un nombre infiny de feux, qui sont fort proches les uns des autres, & peu éloignez de vous. Lors que vous perdez de veuë vostre Soleil particulier, il vous en reste encore assez, & vostre nuit n'est pas moins éclairée que le jour, du moins la diference ne peut pas estre sensible, & pour parler plus juste, vous n'avez jamais de nuit. Ils seroient bien étonnez, les Gens de ces Mondes-là, accoûtumez comme ils sont à une clarté perpetuelle, si on leur disoit qu'il y a des malheureux qui ont de veritables nuits, qui tombent dans des tenebres tres-profondes, & qui quand ils joüissent de la lumiere, ne voyent mesme qu'un seul Soleil. Ils nous regarderoient comme des Estres disgraciez de la Nature, & fremiroient de l'horreur de nostre condition.</P095>
chunks.target_manual: <P067>I ask your Pardon, said she; I yield and confess, you have over-charg'd me with Worlds and Tourbillions. Madam, said I, I have still a Reserve for you: You see that Whiteness in the Hemisphere, call'd The Milky Way; Can you imagine what it is? 'Tis nothing but an Infinity of little fixed Stars, which cannot be seen by our Eyes, because they are so very small, and are plac'd so near to one another, that they appear to be but one continued Whiteness: I wish you cou'd see this Anthill or Stars, and these Seeds of Worlds; they look like the Maldevia- Islands, or those twelve thousand little Isles, or Banks of Sand, separate only by small Canals of the Sea, which one may over-leap with as much Ease as a Ditch. So that these little Tourbillions of the Milky Way, being so near one to another, may converse and shake hands with those of their Neighbouring World; at least, the Birds of one World may fly into another; and they may teach Pidgeons to carry Letters, as they do in the Levant. By which, the Sun, in his own Tourbillion, as soon as he begins to spread his Light, he faceth that of all other Stranger-Suns; for if you were in one of these little Tourbillions of the Milky Way, your Sun wou'd not be so near to you; and by consequence, wou'd have but little more power, force, or influence upon your Eyes, than a hundred thousand other Suns of the neighbouring Tourbillions; you wou'd then see your Heaven shining with an infinite number of Fires, very near to one another, and not far distant from you; and tho' you shou'd lose the sight of your own Sun, you wou'd still have Light enough, and your Nights wou'd be no less bright than your Days; at least, you wou'd not be sensible of the difference; or, to speak more properly, you wou'd have no Night at all: The Inhabitants of this World, accustom'd to perpetual Day, wou'd be strangely surpriz'd if one shou'd tell 'em, that there are several People in the Universe, who are under the Tribulation of dismal, real Nights, and who fall into long and profound Darknesses, and who, when the Light returns, behold one and the same Sun: They wou'd look upon such People as the Out-casts of Nature, and the very Thoughts of our sad Condition wou'd sieze them with Horrour.</P067>
source_segments: d'un Monde à l'autre on pourroit se parler, ou mesme se donner la main
qu'il y a des malheureux qui ont de veritables nuits
ne voyent mesme qu'un seul Soleil
fremiroient de l'horreur de nostre condition
target_segments: I yield and confess
Madam, said I
that Whiteness in the Hemisphere
fixed Stars
this Anthill or Stars
which one may over-leap with as much Ease as a Ditch
may converse and shake hands with those of their Neighbouring World
as soon as he begins to spread his Light
power, force, or influence upon your Eyes
that there are several People in the Universe, who are under the Tribulation of dismal, real Nights
behold one and the same Sun
Out-casts of Nature
the very Thoughts of our sad Condition wou'd sieze them with Horrour.
explanations: The French "je me rends" (I yield/surrender) implies an admission of being overwhelmed by the arguments. The translator makes this admission explicit by adding "and confess," clarifying the nature of the Marquise's concession beyond simple yielding.

The French "ajoûtay-je" (added I) simply indicates the speaker. The translator adds the vocative "Madam," making explicit the formal and courteous address from the philosopher to the Marquise, which is implied by their social relationship and the polite tone of their conversations in the 17th-century context.

The French "cette blancheur" (this whiteness) refers to the Milky Way. The translator adds "in the Hemisphere," explicitly stating its location in the sky, a detail that is understood from the astronomical context but not specified in the original phrase.

The French "Etoiles" (Stars) is a general term. The translator specifies "fixed Stars," making explicit the astronomical classification relevant to Fontenelle's discussion of distant suns (as opposed to planets or 'wandering stars'), which is an important distinction in the Copernican and early modern astronomical context.

The French "Fourmilliere d'Astres" (anthill of celestial bodies) uses "Astres," a general term for celestial bodies. The translation "this Anthill or Stars" (with "this" referring to the previously mentioned "Whiteness") explicitly clarifies that these "Astres" are specifically stars, ensuring the reader understands the concrete nature of the celestial bodies in the metaphor.

The French "que l'on sauteroit presque comme des Fossez" (that one would almost jump like ditches) implies that crossing the canals is easy. The translation "which one may over-leap with as much Ease as a Ditch" makes this implied ease of action explicit by adding "with as much Ease as," emphasizing the triviality of the obstacle.

The French "d'un Monde à l'autre on pourroit se parler, ou mesme se donner la main" (from one World to another one could speak, or even shake hands) implies interaction between inhabitants of different worlds. The translation "may converse and shake hands with those of their Neighbouring World" explicitly identifies the other party in the interaction (the inhabitants/entities of the neighboring world), clarifying who is being conversed with or whose hand is being shaken.

The French "dés qu'il paroist" (as soon as it [the Sun] appears) is concise. The translation "as soon as he begins to spread his Light" explicitly describes the initial action and mechanism of the sun's appearance and its power, adding a layer of descriptive detail about how it comes to dominate visually.

The French "force sur vos yeux" (force on your eyes) uses a single term to describe the sun's impact. The translation expands this to "power, force, or influence upon your Eyes," explicitly enumerating different facets of this impact (its general strength, direct physical effect, and broader ability to affect vision) that were subsumed under the more general term "force."

The French "qu'il y a des malheureux qui ont de veritables nuits" (that there are unfortunate ones who have real nights) attributes misfortune to the people. The translation "that there are several People in the Universe, who are under the Tribulation of dismal, real Nights" makes the suffering more explicit and graphic by adding the phrases "under the Tribulation of" and "dismal" to directly characterize the experience of having nights, thus intensifying the negative description of their state.

The French "ne voyent mesme qu'un seul Soleil" (don't even see but a single Sun) states a limitation. The translation "behold one and the same Sun" explicitly emphasizes the monotony and lack of variety implied by seeing only a single, unchanging sun, an implication more pronounced in contrast to the inhabitants of the Milky Way worlds who would see many.

The French "Estres disgraciez de la Nature" (Beings disgraced by Nature) implies a fall from favor or a state of being unfortunate in Nature's allocation. The translation "Out-casts of Nature" makes the consequence of this state more explicit and severe, suggesting active expulsion or definitive rejection by Nature rather than just a lack of grace.

The French "fremiroient de l'horreur de nostre condition" (would shudder with the horror of our condition) describes a reaction to the condition. The translation "the very Thoughts of our sad Condition wou'd sieze them with Horrour" explicitly clarifies that even the mere idea or mental conception of such a condition (additionally labelled "sad") is enough to induce horror, intensifying the psychological impact and its cause.

chunks.source_manual: <P096>Je ne vous demande pas, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, s'il y a des Lunes dans les Mondes de la Voye de Lait; je voy bien qu'elles n'y seroient de nul usage aux Planetes principales qui n'ont point de nuit, & qui d'ailleurs marchent dans des espaces trop étroits pour s'embarrasser de cet attirail de Planetes subalternes. Mais sçavez-vous bien qu'à force de me multiplier les Mondes si liberalement, vous me faites naistre une veritable difficulté? Les Tourbillons dont nous voyons les Soleils, touchent le Tourbillon où nous sommes. Les Tourbillons sont ronds, n'est-il pas vray? Et comment tant de Boules en peuvent-elles toucher une seule? Je veux m'imaginer cela, & je sens bien que je ne le puis.</P096>
chunks.target_manual: <P068>I do not ask you, said the Marquiese, whether there be any Moons in the World of the Milky Way; I see very well, that they wou'd be of no use to these Planets that have no Night; and who besides, move in too little Room to be troubled with an Equipage of inferior Planets. But do you know that by your multiplying upon me such a multitude of Worlds, you have started a great Difficulty to my Fancy, which, I doubt, you will hardly satisfy: The Tourbillions, whose Suns we see touch the Tourbillions where we are, and all the Tourbillions are round, how is it possible that so many different Globes can touch one single one? This I wou'd willingly understand, but find I cannot.</P068>
source_segments: vous me faites naistre une veritable difficulté?
target_segments: you have started a great Difficulty to my Fancy, which, I doubt, you will hardly satisfy:
This I wou'd willingly understand
explanations: The French 'vous me faites naistre une veritable difficulté?' (approximately 'you make a real difficulty arise for me?') is significantly expanded in the target text. The translator adds 'to my Fancy,' making explicit that the difficulty is conceptual or imaginative for the Marquise, a nuance only implied in the source. More substantially, the clause 'which, I doubt, you will hardly satisfy:' is an addition by the translator that makes explicit a skepticism and direct challenge from the Marquise regarding the philosopher's ability to resolve the issue. This information is not directly stated in the source, thus re-writing her utterance to be more overtly confrontational and specific about her internal state.

The French 'Je veux m'imaginer cela' (I want to imagine that / I am trying to picture that) is translated as 'This I wou'd willingly understand'. The translator makes the implied intellectual goal of the Marquise's effort explicit by changing 'm'imaginer' (to imagine/picture) to 'understand', thereby clarifying that her mental visualization is a means to achieve intellectual comprehension rather than just forming a mental image. Furthermore, the addition of the adverb 'willingly' makes her cooperative and eager disposition explicit, a nuance which is only generally implied by the French 'Je veux' (I want).

chunks.source_manual: <P097>Il y a beaucoup d'esprit, répondis-je, à avoir cette difficulté-là, & mesme à ne la pouvoir résoudre; car elle est tres-bonne en soy, & de la maniere dont vous la concevez, elle est sans réponse, & c'est avoir bien peu d'esprit que de trouver des réponses à ce qui n'en a point. Si nostre Tourbillon estoit de la figure d'un Dé, il auroit six faces plates, & seroit bien éloigné d'estre rond, mais sur chacune de ces faces on y pourroit mettre un Tourbillon de la mesme figure. Si au lieu de six faces plates, il en avoit vingt, cinquante, mille, il y auroit jusqu'à mille Tourbillons qui pourroient poser sur luy, chacun sur une face, & vous concevez bien que plus un corps a de faces plates qui le terminent au dehors, plus il <IIM>approche d'estre rond</IIM>, en sorte qu'un Diamant taillé à facetes de tous costez, si les facetes estoient fort petites, seroit quasi aussi rond qu'une Perle de mesme grandeur. Les Tourbillons ne sont ronds que de cette maniere-là. Ils ont une infinité de faces en dehors, chacune des quelles porte un autre Tourbillon. Ces faces sont fort inégales; icy elles sont plus grandes, là plus petites. Les plus petites de nostre Tourbillon, par exemple, répondent à la Voye de Lait, & soutiennent tous ces petits Mondes. Que deux Tourbillons qui sont appuyez sur deux faces voisines, laissent quelque vuide entre eux par en bas, comme cela doit arriver tres-souvent, aussi-tost la Nature <UP></UP> qui ménage bien le terrain, vous remplit ce vuide par un petit Tourbillon ou deux, peut-estre par mille, qui n'incommodent point les autres, & ne laissent pas d'estre un ou deux, ou mille Mondes de plus. Ainsi nous pouvons voir beaucoup plus de Mondes que nostre Tourbillon n'a de faces pour en porter <UP></UP>. Je gagerois que quoy que ces petits Mondes n'ayent esté faits que pour estre jettez dans des coins de l'Univers qui fussent demeurez inutiles, quoy qu'ils soient inconnus aux autres Mondes qui les touchent, ils ne laissent pas d'estre fort contents d'eux-mesmes <UP></UP>. Ce sont ceux sans doute dont on ne découvre les petits Soleils qu'avec des Lunettes d'approche, & qui sont en une quantité si prodigieuse. Enfin tous ces Tourbillons s'ajustent les uns avec les autres le mieux qu'il est possible, & comme il faut que chacun tourne autour de son Soleil sans changer de place, chacun prend la maniere de tourner, qui est la plus commode & la plus aisée dans la situation où il est. Ils s'engrainent en quelque façon les uns dans les autres comme les rouës d'une Montre, & aident mutuellement leurs mouvemens. Il est pourtant vray qu'ils agissent aussi les uns contre les autres. Chaque Monde, à ce qu'on dit, est comme un <IIM>Ballon</IIM> <UP></UP> qui s'enfle de soy-mesme, & qui s'étendroit, si on le laissoit faire, mais il est aussi-tost repoussé par les Mondes voisins, & il rentre en luy-mesme, aprés quoy il recommence à s'enfler, & ainsi de suite <UP></UP>; & on pretend que les Etoiles Fixes ne nous envoyent cette lumiere tremblante, & ne paroissent briller à reprises, que parce que leurs Tourbillons poussent perpetuellement le nostre, & en sont perpetuellement repoussez.</P097>
chunks.target_manual: <P069>There's a great deal of Sense, said I, Madam, in your proposing of this Difficulty, and no less in your not knowing how to salve it; for 'tis very judicious in it self, and unanswerable, as you understand it; and 'tis an Argument of very little Wit, to answer an Objection that is unanswerable. If our Tourbillion were in the shape of a Dy, it wou'd have six plain Superficies, and wou'd be very far from being round; yet upon every one of these six Superficies, or flat Sides, a Tourbillion might be plac'd, being of the same Figure: But instead of six flat sides, suppose it had twenty, fifty, or a thousand; then it were possible to place a thousand Tourbillions upon it, every Side bearing one; and you easily understand, that the more Superficies, or flat Sides any Body has, the nearer it approaches to <IIM>a Globe </IIM>: So a Diamond cut in Fossets on all sides, if those Fossets were very small, that Diamond wou'd be as round almost as a Pearl of the same bigness; the Tourbillions are only round in this sense, they are compos'd of an infinite number of flat Sides, and every one of 'em carries another Tourbillion: The flat Superficies are very unequal; here they are big, there they are little; the smallest Superficies of our Tourbillion, for Example, answer to the Milky Way, and support all those little Worlds; but if two Tourbillions, that rest upon two neighbouring Sides or Faces, have any void space below between 'em (as that must fall out very often) Nature, who will lose nothing, and turns all her work to the best advantage, instantly fills up that Vacuity with one, two, or it may be a thousand little Tourbillions, which does not at all trouble or incommode the rest, and yet every one of these may have a World in it; so that there may be more Worlds, than our Tourbillion has flat Sides to support: And I dare say, that although these little Worlds were only made to fill up Chinks of the Universe, which otherwise wou'd have been useless, and that they are altogether unknown to the other Worlds which touch them; yet I doubt not but they are very well contented with their own Condition, and 'tis they whose little Suns we discover by the helps of Telescopes, whose number is so prodigious. In fine, all these Tourbillions are so rightly adjusted, and join'd to one another in so delicate a Form, that every one turns round his own Sun, without changing his Situation; every one takes that way of turning, which is most proper and commode to its place: They are fixed to one another like the Wheels of a Watch, assisting one another in their Motions, and yet moving contrary to one another. And 'tis said, that every World is like a Balloon, or Foot-ball, which swells and fills of it self, and which wou'd extend farther, if it were not hinder'd by neighbouring Worlds, who press it, and then it shrinks to its first form; after that, it swells a-new, and is again depress'd. And the <UP>Philosophers </UP> pretend, that the fixed Stars transmit to us a trembling Light, and an unequal Sparkling, because their Tourbillions push against ours, and ours against theirs.</P069>

The translator renders "ce qui" (that which) as "an Objection," thereby clarifying the nature of the unanswerable thing as an "Objection," a specification implied by the preceding mention of "Difficulté" but made explicit here.

This addition of "or flat Sides" explicates the meaning of "Superficies" or offers a more common equivalent for "faces", enhancing clarity for the reader.

The phrase "or flat Sides" explicitly provides an alternative or clarification for "Superficies" (which translates "faces," with "flat" corresponding to "plates"), thereby spelling out the meaning.

The French "de cette maniere-là" (in that way/manner) is translated as "in this sense." This explicitation clarifies the *kind* of "manner" being discussed, specifying it as a conceptual or interpretive "sense," an idea implied in the philosophical discourse but made explicit in the translation.

The French "Ils ont" (they have, from "Ils ont une infinité de faces en dehors") is translated as "they are compos'd of." This change makes explicit the *nature* of possession, indicating that the tourbillons have sides by virtue of being composed of them, a structural detail implied but not stated.

The French "faces en dehors" (faces on the outside, from "Ils ont une infinité de faces en dehors") is translated as "flat Sides." The addition of "flat" makes explicit a quality of these sides which is implied from the earlier discussion of "faces plates" (flat faces) but not specified in this particular French phrase.

The French "Ces faces" (these faces) is translated as "The flat Superficies." The adjective "flat" is added by the translator, making explicit a characteristic of the "faces" (translated as "Superficies") that is contextually understood from prior descriptions (like "faces plates") but not reiterated in this specific French phrase.

The French "faces" (from "deux faces voisines" - two neighboring faces/sides) is translated as "Sides or Faces." By providing "Sides" and then the synonym "or Faces," the translator explicitly offers an alternative term, clarifying the meaning through redundancy for an English audience.

The French idiomatic expression "la Nature qui ménage bien le terrain" (Nature, who manages space well/is economical with space) is significantly expanded. The translation "Nature, who will lose nothing, and turns all her work to the best advantage" explicitly spells out the *manner and implications* of Nature's economy, making the abstract concept more concrete and detailed.

The French states that the small tourbillons "ne laissent pas d'estre... Mondes de plus" (do not fail to be... more Worlds). The translation adds "and yet every one of these may have a World in it," which explicitly clarifies *how* these numerous small entities constitute additional worlds, by specifying that each individual tourbillon can contain a world. This spells out the mechanism only implied in the French.

The French "jettez dans des coins de l'Univers" (thrown into corners of the Universe) is translated as "to fill up Chinks of the Universe." The phrase "to fill up" makes explicit the *purpose or function* of these worlds being in "corners" (rendered as the more specific "Chinks"), a nuance not explicitly stated in "jettez dans" (thrown into).

The French "fort contents d'eux-mesmes" (very content with themselves) is translated as "very well contented with their own Condition." The addition of "with their own Condition" explicitly clarifies the *aspect or reason* for their contentment, expanding on the more general "d'eux-mesmes."

The French descriptive term "Lunettes d'approche" (literally "approach glasses" or spyglasses) is translated using the more specific and scientific term "Telescopes." This explicitation clarifies the exact nature of the instrument by using its established technical name, which might be more familiar or precise to the intended scientifically curious audience.

The French phrase "s'ajustent les uns avec les autres le mieux qu'il est possible" (adjust to each other as best as possible) is expanded by the addition of "and join'd to one another in so delicate a Form." This phrase makes explicit the *nature and quality* of this adjustment, specifying that the tourbillons are "join'd" and describing the manner as "in so delicate a Form," details not explicitly present in the source.

The French "un Ballon" (a ball, an inflatable sphere) is translated as "a Balloon, or Foot-ball." The addition of "or Foot-ball" provides a concrete, possibly more familiar, example for the English readership of the time, thereby explicating the type of "Ballon" by analogy.

The French "il rentre en luy-mesme" (it re-enters itself, it collapses) is translated as "it shrinks to its first form." The phrase "to its first form" explicitly states the *resulting state* or consequence of the action "rentre en luy-mesme," clarifying what this "re-entering" entails.

The French impersonal construction "on pretend que" (one pretends/claims that, it is pretended/claimed that) uses the indefinite pronoun "on." The translation "the Philosophers pretend, that" makes the agent explicit by identifying "on" as "the Philosophers," a specific group highly relevant to the context of disseminating philosophical and scientific ideas, but not explicitly named in the French phrase.

chunks.source_manual: <P098>J'aime fort toutes ces Idées-là, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>. J'aime ces Balons qui s'enflent & se desenflent à chaque moment, & ces Mondes qui se combattent toûjours, & sur tout j'aime à voir comment ce combat fait entre eux un commerce de lumiere, qui asseurément est le seul qu'ils puissent avoir.</P098>
chunks.target_manual: <P070>I am extreamly in love, said the Marquiese, with these Idea's you give me of the Balloons, which swell and fall every Moment; and those Worlds, which are always justling together: But, above all, I am pleas'd to consider, that this Strife amongst 'em produces a Commerce of Light, which is the only Traffick they can have.</P070>
target_segments: these Idea's you give me
justling together
explanations: The French phrase "ces Idées-là" (those ideas) refers to ideas previously discussed by the philosopher, implied by the dialogic context and the deictic "là". The English translation "these Idea's you give me" makes the origin of these ideas (the philosopher, the interlocutor "you") explicit, thereby clarifying the source of the information for the reader.

The French verb "se combattent" (fight/combat each other), used to describe the interaction of the "Mondes" (Worlds), is a general term. The English translation renders this as "justling together," which specifies a particular manner of interaction – a physical bumping or pushing. This explicitation provides a more concrete image of the interaction, whereas the original "se combattent" could imply a broader or more metaphorical range of conflicts.

chunks.source_manual: <P099>Non, non, repris-je, ce n'est pas le seul. Les Mondes voisins nous envoyent quelquefois visiter, & mesme assez magnifiquement. Il nous en vient des Cometes, qui sont toûjours ornées, ou d'une chevelure éclatante, ou d'une barbe venerable, ou d'une queüe majestueuse.</P099>
chunks.target_manual: <P071>No, no, said I, Madam; that is not the only Traffick; the neighbouring Worlds send Envoys sometimes to us, and that with a great deal of Splendor: We have Comets from thence too, who are always adorn'd with shining Hair, a venerable Beard, and a Royal Train.</P071>

chunks.source_manual: <P100>Ah! quels Deputez dit-elle en riant! On se passeroit bien de leur visite, elle ne sert qu'à faire peur. Ils ne font peur qu'aux <UP></UP> enfants, repliquay-je, à cause de leur équipage extraordinaire, mais <RW>les enfants sont en grand nombre</RW>. Les Cometes ne sont que des Planetes qui appartiennent à un Tourbillon voisin. Elles avoyent leur mouvement vers ses extremitez, mais ce Tourbillon estant peut-estre differemment pressé par ceux qui l'environnent, est plus rond par en haut, & plus plat par en bas, & c'est par en bas qu'il nous regarde. Ces Planetes <UP></UP> qui auront commencé vers le haut à se mouvoir en Cercle, ne prévoyoient pas qu'en bas le Tourbillon leur manqueroit, parce qu'il est là comme écrasé, & pour continuer leur mouvement circulaire, il faut necessairement qu'elles entrent dans un autre Tourbillon, que je suppose qui est le nostre, & qu'elles en coupent les extremitez. Aussi sont-elles toûjours fort élevées à nostre égard, elles marchent beaucoup au dessus de Saturne. Il est necessaire dans nostre Sistême, pour des raisons qui ne sont rien à nostre sujet present, que depuis Saturne jusqu'aux deux extremitez de nostre Tourbillon, il y ait un grand espace vide, & sans Planetes. Nos Ennemis nous reprochent sans cesse inutilité de ce grand espace. Qu'ils ne s'inquietent plus, nous en avons trouvé l'usage, c'est l'apartement des Planetes étrangeres qui entrent dans nostre Monde.</P100>
chunks.target_manual: <P072>Good God! said the Marquiese, laughing; What Ambassadors are these? We cou'd easily dispence with their Visits, for they do nothing but fright us. They fright <UP>only Fools </UP> and Children, Madam, said I; but of those <UP>Ignorants</UP>, I confess, there are a great number: The Comets are nothing but Planets which belong to some neighbouring Tourbillion, who make their Course toward the Extremity, or Out-side of it: But this Tourbillion being press'd by others that encompass it, 'tis rounder above than it is below, and it is from below that they appear to us. These Planets, which have begun to move in a Circle above, and not fore-seeing that their Tourbillion will sail 'em below, because it is, as it were, braz'd or squeez'd in that part; these Planets, <UP>which we call Comets, </UP> are necessitated, for the Continuance of their Circular Motion, to come into another Tourbillion, which happens sometimes to be ours, making their passage through the Extremity of it: They all appear to us highly elevated, their Course being constantly above Saturn.</P072> <P073>'Tis very necessary for the Defence of our System <NCP>(for Reasons that do not at all relate to our present Subject) </NCP> that there shou'd be a great vast space betwixt Saturn, and the Extremities of our Tourbillion, free from Planets. Our Adversaries do constantly reproach us with the unusefulness of this great Void; but let 'em not trouble their Heads with that, for we have found an Use for it; <UP>and it is the Appartment, or Chambers of State, where we receive the Stranger Planetary Ambassadors.</UP></P073>

The source states that comets only frighten "enfants" (children). The translation expands this to "Fools and Children." The addition of "Fools" makes explicit the implication that such fear is due not just to childish inexperience but also to a lack of reason or understanding in adults.

The French "ses extremitez" (its extremities/ends) is translated as "the Extremity, or Out-side of it." The French "comme écrasé" (as if crushed/flattened) is rendered as "as it were, braz'd or squeez'd". While "squeez'd" conveys a similar meaning to "écrasé," the addition of "braz'd or" expands the description. The translator uses two verbs to describe the state of the Tourbillon where the original used one, thus providing a more elaborate or emphatic depiction of its deformation.

The French text refers to "Ces Planetes" (These Planets), which are understood from prior context to be comets. When these planets are referred to again in a subsequent clause (implicitly as "elles" - they - in French, which the English translation renders by repeating "these Planets"), the translator adds the clarifying clause "which we call Comets". This addition explicitly spells out the identity of these planets, a connection the original text left for the reader to maintain.

The French "dans nostre Sistême" (in our System) is translated as "for the Defence of our System." The translator adds "for the Defence of," making explicit the polemical context that the features of the Cartesian system (like the empty space discussed) were often presented to counter criticisms or to argue for the system's theoretical validity. This shifts from a simple locative description to an explicit statement of purpose or justification.

The French "l'apartement" (the apartment/suite of rooms) is translated as "the Appartment, or Chambers of State." The addition of "or Chambers of State" explicitly elevates and specifies the nature of this "apartment" to be a grand, formal space, thereby enhancing the metaphor of the visiting comets as "Planetary Ambassadors" and making the implied grandeur explicit.

chunks.source_manual: <P101>J'entends, dit-elle. <NCP></NCP>. Nous ne les laissons pas entrer jusque dans le cœur de nostre Tourbillon, & avec nos Planetes, nous les recevons comme le Grand Seigneur reçoit les Ambassadeurs qu'on luy envoye. Il ne leur fait pas l'honneur de les loger à Constantinople, mais seulement dans un Fauxbourg de la Ville. <IIM>Nous avons encore cela de commun avec les Ottomans</IIM>, repris-je, qu'ils reçoivent des Ambassadeurs sans en renvoyer, & que nous ne renvoyons point de nos Planetes aux Mondes voisins.</P101> <P102>A en juger par toutes ces choses-là, repliqua-t-elle, <UP></UP>, nous sommes bien fiers. Cependant je ne sçais pas trop encore ce que j'en dois croire. Ces Planetes étrangeres ont un air bien menaçant avec leurs queües & leurs barbes, & peut-estre on nous les envoye pour nous insulter, au lieu que les nostres, qui ne sont pas faites de la mesme maniere, ne seroient pas si propres à se faire craindre, quand elles iroient dans les autres Mondes.</P102> <P103>Les queües & les barbes, répondis-je, ne sont que de pures apparences. <UP></UP>. Les Planetes étrangeres ne different en rien des nostres, mais en entrant dans nostre Tourbillon, elles prennent la queüe ou la barbe par une certaine sorte d'illumination qu'elles reçoivent du Soleil, & qui entre nous n'a pas encore esté trop bien expliquée; mais toûjours on est seur qu'il ne s'agit que d'une espece d'illumination <UP></UP>; on la devinera quand on pourra. Je voudrois donc bien, reprit-elle, que nostre Saturne allast prendre une queuë ou une barbe dans quelqu'autre Tourbillon, & y répandre l'effroy, & qu'en suite ayant mis bas cet <IIM>accompagnement</IIM> terrible, il revint se ranger icy avec les autres Planetes à ses fonctions ordinaires. Il vaut mieux pour luy, répondis-je, qu'il ne sorte point de nostre Tourbillon. Je vous ay dit le choc qui se fait à l'endroit où deux Tourbillons se poussent & se repoussent l'un l'autre; je croy que dans ce pas là une pauvre Planete est agitée assez rudement, & que ses habitans ne s'en portent pas mieux. Nous croyons nous autres estre bien malheureux quand il nous paroist une Comete; c'est la Comete elle-même qui est bien malheureuse. Je ne le crois point, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, elle nous apporte tous ses habitans en bonne santé. Rien n'est si divertissant que de changer ainsi de Tourbillon. Nous qui ne sortons jamais du nostre, nous menons une vie assez ennuyeuse. Si les habitans d'une Comete ont assez d'esprit pour prévoir le temps de leur passage dans nostre Monde, ceux qui ont déja fait le voyage, annoncent aux autres par avance ce qu'ils y verront. Vous découvrirez bien-tost une Planete qui a un grand Anneau autour d'elle, disent-ils peut-estre, en parlant de Saturne. Vous en verrez une autre qui en a quatre petites qui la suivent. Peut-estre mesme y a-t-il des gens destinés à observer le moment où ils entrent dans nostre Monde, & qui crient aussi-tost, Nouveau Soleil, Nouveau Soleil, comme ces Matelots qui crient, Terre, Terre. <UP></UP>.</P103> <P104>Il ne faut donc plus songer, luy dis-je, à vous donner de la pitié pour les habitans d'une Comète, mais j'espere du moins que vous plaindrez ceux qui vivent dans un Tourbillon dont le Soleil vient à s'éteindre, & <SC>qui demeurent dans une nuit éternelle</SC>. Quoi? s'écria-t-elle, des Soleils s'éteignent? Oüi, sans doute, répondis-je. Les Anciens ont vû dans le Ciel des Etoiles fixes que nous n'y voyons plus. Ces Soleils ont perdu leur lumiere; grande desolation assurément dans tout le Tourbillon; mortalité generale sur toutes les Planetes; car que faire sans Soleil? Cette idée est trop funeste, reprit-elle. N'y auroit-il pas moyen de me l'épargner? Je vous diray si vous voulez, répondis-je, ce que disent de fort habiles gens, que les Etoiles fixes qui ont disparu ne se sont pas pour cela éteintes, que ce sont des Soleils qui ne le sont qu'à demy, c'est à dire qui ont <IIM>une moitié obscure</IIM>, & l'autre lumineuse; que comme ils tournent sur eux-mesmes, tantost ils nous presentent la moitié lumineuse, & qu'alors nous ne les voyons, tantost la moitié obscure, & qu'alors nous ne les voyons plus. Je prendray bien pour vous obliger cette opinion là, qui est plus douce que l'autre, mais je ne puis la prendre qu'à l'égard de certaines Etoiles qui ont des temps reglez pour paroître & pour disparoistre, ainsi qu'on a commencé à s'en apercevoir, autrement les demy Soleils ne peuvent pas subsister. Mais que dirons-nous des Etoiles qui disparoissent & ne se remontrent pas aprés le temps pendant lequel elles auroient dû assurément achever de tourner sur elles-mesmes? Vous estes trop équitable pour vouloir m'obliger à croire que ce soient des demy Soleils: cependant je feray encore un effort en vostre faveur. Ces Soleils ne se seront pas éteints, ils se seront seulement enfoncez dans la profondeur immense du Ciel, & nous ne pourrons plus les voir. En ce cas le Tourbillon aura suivy son Soleil, & tout s'y portera bien. Il est vray que la plus grande partie des Etoiles fixes n'ont pas ce mouvement par lequel elles s'éloignent de nous, car en d'autres temps elles devroient s'en rapprocher, & nous les verrions tantost plus grandes, tantost plus petites, ce qui n'arrive pas. Mais nous supposerons qu'il n'y a que quelques petits Tourbillons plus legers & plus agiles qui se glissent entre les autres, & font de certains tours, au bout desquels ils reviennent, tandis que le gros des Tourbillons demeure immobile; mais voicy un étrange malheur, il y a des Etoiles fixes qui viennent se montrer à nous, qui passent beaucoup de temps à ne faire que paroistre & disparoistre, & enfin disparoissent entierement, des demi Soleils reparoîtroient dans des temps reglez. Des Soleils qui s'enfonceroient dans le Ciel ne disparoistroient qu'une fois pour ne reparoistre de longtemps. Prenez vostre resolution, Madame, avec courage; il faut que ces Etoiles soient des Soleils qui s'obscurcissent assez pour cesser d'estre visibles à nos yeux, & en suite se rallument, & à la fin s'éteignent tout à fait. Comment un Soleil peut-il s'obscurcir & s'éteindre, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, luy qui est en luy-mesme une source de lumiere? Le plus aisément du Monde, selon Descartes, répondis-je, nostre Soleil a des tâches. Que ce soient ou des écumes, des broüillards, ou tout ce qu'il vous plaira, ces taches peuvent s'épaissir, se mettre plusieurs ensemble, s'accrocher les unes aux autres, en suite elles iront jusqu'à former autour du Soleil une croûte qui s'augmentera toujours, & adieu le Soleil <UP></UP>. Nous l'avons déja même échepée belle, dit-on. Le Soleil a esté tres-pasle pendant des années entieres, pendant celle, par exemple, qui suivit la mort de Cesar. C'estoit la croûte qui commençoit à se faire, la force du Soleil la rompit & la dissipa; mais si elle eust continué, nous estions perdus. Vous me faites trembler, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>. Presentement que je sçay les consequences de la pâleur du Soleil, je crois qu'au lieu d'aller voir les matins à mon miroir si je ne suis point pasle, j'iray voir au Ciel si le Soleil ne l'est point luy même. Ah! Madame, répondis-je, rassurez-vous, il faut du temps pour ruiner un Monde. Mais enfin, dit-elle, il ne faut que du temps? Je vous l'avouë, repris-je: Toute cette masse immense de matiere qui compose l'Univers est dans un mouvement perpétuel, dont aucune de ses parties n'est entierement exempte; & dés qu'il y a du mouvement quelque part, ne vous y fiez point, il faut qu'il arrive des changemens: soit lents, soit prompts, mais toujours dans des temps proportionnez à l'effet. Les Anciens estoient <IIM>plaisans</IIM> de s'imaginer que les Corps celestes étoient de nature à ne changer jamais, parce qu'ils ne les avoyent pas encore vû changer. <IIM>Avoyent-ils eu le loisir de s'en assurer par l'experience?</IIM> Les Anciens étoient jeunes auprés de nous. Si les Roses qui ne durent qu'un jour faisoient des Histoires, & se laissoient des Memoires les unes aux autres, les premieres auroient fait le portrait de leur Jardinier d'une certaine façon, & de plus de quinze mille áges de Rose, les autres qui l'auroient encore laissé à celles qui les devoyent suivre, n'y auroient rien changé. Sur cela elles diroient, nous avons toûjours vû le mesme Jardinier <UP></UP>, de memoire de Rose on n'a vû que luy, il a toûjours esté fait comme il est, assurément il ne meurt point comme nous, il ne change seulement pas. Le raisonnement des Roses seroit-il bon? Il auroit pourtant plus de fondement que celuy que faisoient les Anciens sur les Corps celestes; & quand même il ne seroit arrivé aucun changement dans les Cieux jusqu'à aujourd'huy, quand ils paroistroient marquer qu'ils seroient faits pour durer toûjours sans aucune alteration, je ne les en croirois pas encore, j'attendrois une plus longue experience. Devons-nous établir nostre durée, qui n'est que d'un instant, pour la mesure de quelque-autre? Seroit-ce à dire que ce qui auroit duré cent mille fois plus que nous, dût toûjours durer? On n'est pas si aisément éternel. Il faudroit qu'une chose eût passé bien des âges d'homme mis à bout pour commencer à donner quelque signe d'immortalité. Vrayment, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, je voy les Mondes bien éloignez d'y pouvoir pretendre. Je ne leur ferois seulement pas l'honneur de les comparer à ce Jardinier qui dure tant à l'égard des Roses; ils ne sont que comme les Roses mêmes qui naissent & qui meurent dans un Jardin les unes aprés les autres; car je m'attens bien que s'il disparoist des Etoiles anciennes, il en paroist de nouvelles, il faut que l'espece se repare. Il n'est pas à craindre qu'elle perisse, répondis-je. Les uns vous diront que ce ne sont que des Soleils qui se rapprochent de nous aprés avoir esté long- temps perdus pour nous dans la profondeur du Ciel. D'autres vous diront que ce sont des Soleils qui se sont démeslez de cette croûte obscure qui commençoit à les environner. Je croy aisément que tout cela peut estre, mais je croy aussi que l'Univers peut avoir esté fait de sorte qu'il s'y formera de temps en temps des Soleils nouveaux. Pourquoy la matiere propre à faire un Soleil ne pourra-t'elle pas, aprés avoir esté dispersée en plusieurs endroits différens, se ramasser à la longue en un certain lieu, & y jetter les fondemens d'un nouveau Monde? J'ay d'autant plus d'inclination à croire ces nouvelles productions, qu'elles répondent mieux à la haute idée que j'ay des ouvrages de la Nature. N'auroit-elle le secret que de faire naistre & mourir des herbes ou des plantes par une revolution continuelle? Je suis persuadé, & vous l'estes déja aussi, qu'elle pratique ce même secret sur les Mondes, & qu'il ne luy en coûte pas davantage. De bonne foy, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, je trouve à present les Mondes, les Cieux, & les Corps celestes si sujets au changement, que m'en voila tout à fait revenuë. Revenons encore mieux, si vous m'en croyez, repliquay-je, n'en parlons plus, aussi bien vous voila arrivée à la derniere voûte des Cieux; & pour vous dire s'il y a encore des Etoiles au delà, il faudroit estre plus habile que je ne suis. Mettez-y encore des Mondes, n'y en mettez pas, cela dépend de vous. C'est proprement l'Empire des Philosophes que ces grands païs invisibles qui peuvent estre ou n'estre pas si on veut, ou estre tels que l'on veut, il me suffit d'avoir mené vôtre esprit aussi loin que vont vos yeux.</P104>
chunks.target_manual: <P074>I understand you, said she, <UP>and am pleas'd with your Chamber of State </UP>; for we do not permit 'em to come directly in the middle of our Tourbillion, but receive 'em as the Grand Seignior does his <IIM>Foreign Ministers </IIM>; he does 'em not the Honour to lodge 'em in Constantinople, but sends 'em to the Suburbs. Madam, reply'd I, we agree with the Turks also in one thing more; that is (as they) so we receive Ambassadors, but send none; for none of our Planets ever go to visit other Worlds. At this rate, said the Marquiese, we are very proud, yet I know not what to think of the matter; these Stranger- Planets, with their long Tails and Beards, have usually but a scurvy threatning Look, and it may be they are sent to terrifie us; whereas ours, not being made of that terrible Form, wou'd not be so proper to frighten People, were they sent into another World. These Tails and Beards, said I, are not real, but only Appearance, and these Stranger-Planets differ in nothing from ours; but entring into our Tourbillion, they take a Tail, or a Beard from a certain kind of Illumination which they receive from the Sun; which, as yet, is not fully explain'd amongst us. But let this be found out when it can, we now are sure it is nothing but a kind of Illumination, or <UP>false </UP> Light. I wish then, said the Marquiese, that our Saturn wou'd take a Tail, or a Beard, and go into some other Tourbillion, to frighten its Inhabitants; and that afterwards, laying aside this terrible Equipage, he wou'd return, with the rest of our Planets, to his own place. 'Twill be better for him, said I, not to go out of our Tourbillion: I have told you already of the Encounter between two Tourbillions pushing against one another; and I believe, upon that occasion, a poor Planet is strangely shaken, and that his Inhabitants are not the better for it. We believe our selves very miserable when we see a Comet appear, but it is the Comet it self that is most unhappy. I do not believe that, said the Marquiese, for it brings its Inhabitants to us in good health; and you know, nothing is wholsomer than Change of Air: As for us that never go out of our own, Life languishes but dully on. If the Inhabitants of a Comet had but the Skill to fore-see their Passage into our World, those who have already made that Voyage will tell these new Adventures what they will see in their way: A Planet, say they, which has a great Ring round him, meaning Saturn; and then you will see another that has four little ones following him, and it may be that amongst them there are People set a-part, on purpose for observing the very Minute when they shou'd enter into our World, and who are instantly to cry out, A new Sun! A new Sun! as our Mariners do, Land! Land! <UP>after a long Sea-Voyage </UP>. I hope you will no longer pity the Inhabitants of a Comet; but, no doubt, you will commiserate those who live in a Tourbillion where the Sun comes to be extinct, and leaves them in Eternal Night. What! cry'd out Madam the Marquiese, Can Suns be extinguish'd? Yes, said I, without dispute. The Ancients have seen fixed Stars in the Firmament, which we see no more; these Suns have lost their Light: A great Desolation certainly for that Tourbillion, and a great Mortality for all the Inhabitants of its Planets; for there is no living without a Sun. That Idea, said she, is too mournful; Is there no way to pass it by? If you please, said I, Madam, I'll tell you what very learned Men say; that the fixed Stars which have disappeared are not however extinguished, but that they are Half-Suns; that is to say, they have one side obscure, and the other englightned; and as they turn upon their own Axis, sometimes they present their enlightned half, and then we see 'em; and sometimes their obscure half, and then we lose 'em. To oblige you, Madam, I shall follow this Opinion, because 'tis more favourable than the other; but it must only be for certain Stars, who have regular Seasons of appearing and disappearing, as hath been discover'd; otherwise these Half-Suns cannot subsist. But what shall we say of Stars that disappear, and do not shew themselves again after the time in which they ought certainly to have perform'd the Revolution upon their own Axis? You are too just, Madam, to oblige me to believe that these Stars are Half-Suns: However, for your Satisfaction, I will endeavour to solve this Objection another way: Those Suns shall not be extinguish'd then, but shall only be sunk into the depth of the vast Heavens, which removes 'em from our sight; and in that Case, these Suns are follow'd by their Tourbillions, and all is well. 'Tis true, that the greatest part of the fixed Stars have no such Motion as carry them from us; if they had, they might as well approach more near us, and we shou'd see 'em sometimes bigger, sometimes less; which can never fall out: Let us therefore suppose that there are some little Tourbillions of less Light and Activity, which slide in among the others, and make certain Turnings; after which, they come back again, whilst in the mean time the great Tourbillions remain where they did before; and 'tis a strange Misfortune that there shou'd be certain fixed Stars which appear to us, and after a great deal of time of appearing and dis-appearing, entirely vanish, and are lost. In that time the Half- Suns, I spoke of, wou'd appear again, and Suns that were sunk into the Heavens wou'd dis-appear once, and not to appear again for a long time. Resolve well what to think, Madam, and take Courage; there is a necessity that these Stars must be Suns, which grown obscure enough to be invisible to our sight, are afterwards enlightned, and in the end must lie extinguished. How! said the Marquiese; Can a Sun be obscur'd, or entirely extinguish'd, who is himself the Fountain of Light? The most easily in the World, said I, Madam: According to the Opinion of Des Cartes, our Sun has Spots; let 'em be Scum or Vapours, or what else you will, these Spots may condense, and many of 'em may come together, and form a kind of Crust, which may afterwards augment, and then farewell the Sun <UP>and all its Light </UP>. 'Tis said, we escap'd once very hardly, for the Sun was grown extreamly pale for several Years together; and particularly the Year after the Death of Iulius Caesar, it was that Crust that began to gather, and the Face of the Sun brake and dissipated it; but had it continu'd, we had been all undone. You make me tremble, said the Marquiese; and now that I understand the Consequences of the paleness of the Sun, I shall henceforth every Morning, instead of going to my Looking-Glass to consult my own Face, go and look up to the Heavens to consider that of the Sun. Madam, said I, be assur'd there goes a great deal of time to ruin a World. Then, said she, there is nothing requisite but Time. I acknowledge it, Madam, said I; all this vast Mass of Matter which composes the Universe, is in perpetual Motion, from which no part of it is entirely exempt; and therefore Changes must come sooner or later, but always in Time proportional to the Effect. The Ancients were <IIM>foolish </IIM> to imagine, that the Celestial Bodies were of an unchangeable Nature, because they never saw any Change in 'em; <UP>but they had neither Leisure nor Life long enough to undeceive themselves by Experience </UP>; but the Ancients were young in respect of us. Suppose now, Madam, that the Roses, which last but for a Day, shou'd write Histories, and leave Memorials from one to another; the first wou'd have described the Picture of their Gardener of a certain manner; and after fifteen thousand Ages of Roses, the others that had follow'd 'em wou'd have alter'd nothing in that Description of the Gardener, but wou'd have said, We have always seen the same Gardener, since the Memory of Roses we have seen but him, he has always been as he is, he dies not as we do; nay, he changes not, and certainly will never be other than what he is: Wou'd this way of arguing of the Roses be good? Yet it wou'd be better grounded than that of the Ancients, concerning Celestial Bodies; and tho' there had never happen'd any Change in the Heavens to this Day, and tho' they shou'd seem to last for ever, yet I wou'd not believe it, but wou'd wait for a longer Experience; nor ought we to measure the Duration of any thing by that of our own scanty Life. Suppose a thing had a Being a hundred thousand times longer than ours, shou'd we therefore conclude it shou'd last for ever? Eternity is not so easy a matter; and some things must have pass'd many Ages of Men, one after another, before any sign of Decay had appeared in 'em. I am not so unreasonable, said the Marquiese, as to consider the Worlds as things eternal, nor will I do them the honour to compare 'em to your Gardener, who liv'd so many Ages longer than the Roses: They are themselves but as a Rose, which are produc'd but in a Garden, that bud one Day, and fall the next; and as those Roses die, new ones succeed; so for some ancient Stars that dis- appear, other new ones are born in their places, and that Defect in Nature must be so repair'd, and no Species can totally perish. Some will tell you, they are Suns, which draw near to us after having been long lost in the depth of Heaven: Others will say, they are Suns that have cast off the Crust which began to cover them. If I cou'd easily believe all this, yet I shou'd believe also that the Universe was made in such a manner, that new Suns have been, and may be form'd in it from time to time; and what shou'd hinder the Substance proper to make Suns from gathering together, and producing new Worlds? And I am the more inclin'd to believe these new Productions, since they are more correspondent to the great Idea I have of the glorious Works of Nature: And why shou'd not she who knows the Secret to bring forth and destroy Herbs, Plants and Flowers, in a continu'd Succession, practise also the same Secret on the Worlds, since one costs her no more Pains and Expence than the other. Indeed, says the Marquiese, I find the Worlds, the Heavens and the Celestial Bodies so subject to change, that I am altogether returned to my self. Let us return yet more, said I, and if you please, make this subject no longer, that of our Discourse; besides you are arriv'd at the utmost bounds of Heaven; and to tell you, that there are any Stars beyond that, were to make my self a wiser Man than I am, place Worlds there, or place none there, it depends upon your Will. These vast invisible Regions, are properly the Empires of Philosophers, which it may be are or are not, as they themselves shall fansie. 'Tis sufficient for me to have carried your Understanding as far as your sight can penetrate.</P074>
