explanations: The French 'J'entends' (I understand) is expanded with 'and am pleas'd with your Chamber of State'. This addition makes explicit a positive reaction from the Marquise and offers a concrete interpretation ('Chamber of State') of the philosopher's analogy about comets being received like ambassadors in the 'suburbs' of a tourbillon, clarifying an implied sentiment and metaphor.

The French implies a comparison through parallel structure ('qu'ils... & que nous...'). The English addition of '(as they)' explicitly spells out this comparative link between the Ottomans' practice of receiving ambassadors and the solar system's reception of comets, clarifying the relationship for the reader.

The translator adds 'usually,' making explicit a frequentative aspect of the comets' appearance that was implied by the general description in French. Additionally, 'scurvy' elaborates on 'menaçant' (threatening), explicitly adding a specific negative quality (contemptible, vile) to their look.

The French 'ne sont que de pures apparences' (are only pure appearances) implies that they are not real. The English translation makes this consequence explicit by adding 'are not real,' directly stating what 'pure appearances' means in terms of reality.

The translator adds 'or false Light' to clarify 'une espece d'illumination' (a kind of illumination). This addition makes explicit the implied nature of the cometary tails' illumination as an optical effect or non-genuine light, enhancing comprehension for a general audience.

The French 'Rien n'est si divertissant que de changer ainsi de Tourbillon' (Nothing is so entertaining as to change Tourbillon like this) is replaced by 'and you know, nothing is wholsomer than Change of Air:'. The translator makes an implicit analogy between 'changing tourbillon' and 'change of air' explicit, and adds a then-common cultural belief about the health benefits ('wholsomer') of such change, shifting the focus from entertainment to well-being.

The French 'aux autres' (to the others) is rendered as 'these new Adventures.' This addition explicitly characterizes the other inhabitants of the comet who haven't made the voyage yet, adding a descriptive layer that was implicit or absent in the source and framing them as explorers.

The French narrator adds 'en parlant de Saturne' (speaking of Saturn) as his own comment after the imagined speech. The English translation incorporates 'meaning Saturn' as an immediate gloss within or directly following the imagined speech about 'A Planet...which has a great Ring round him', making the identification of Saturn more direct and explicit for the reader at that point.

The translator adds 'after a long Sea-Voyage' to explain the context in which sailors cry 'Land! Land!'. While this context is strongly implied by 'Matelots' (sailors) and their cry, the addition makes this circumstantial information explicit for the reader.

The French 'mortalité generale sur toutes les Planetes' (general mortality on all the Planets) implies that it is the living beings on the planets who suffer mortality. The English translation makes this explicit by adding 'for all the Inhabitants of,' clarifying who is affected.

The French 'disparoissent entierement' (disappear entirely) is translated as 'entirely vanish, and are lost.' The addition 'and are lost' explicitly states a consequence or synonymous description of 'vanishing entirely,' reinforcing the idea of their complete disappearance.

The French simply refers to 'des demi Soleils' (half-Suns). The English translation adds the clause 'I spoke of,' which explicitly creates a cohesive link to the philosopher's previous explanation of half-suns, aiding the reader's recall.

The French 'adieu le Soleil' (farewell the Sun) implies the loss of its essential properties, primarily its light. The English translation makes this crucial consequence explicit by adding 'and all its Light,' specifying what is lost with the Sun's demise.

The French Marquise says she will check 'si je ne suis point pasle' (if I am not pale). The English 'to consult my own Face' broadens this specific check to the general act of looking in the mirror and examining one's face, making the overall, implied action explicit.

The French question 'Avoyent-ils eu le loisir de s'en assurer par l'experience?' asks if the Ancients had the 'leisir' (leisure/time) for experiential verification. The English translation expands this by adding 'nor Life long enough,' explicitly stating another crucial limiting factor (insufficient lifespan for long-term observation) which was implied by the context of astronomical change but not mentioned in the original question.

The French 'il ne change seulement pas' (he simply does not change) is a concise statement about the gardener. The English translation expands this significantly to 'nay, he changes not, and certainly will never be other than what he is:', making the implication of his enduring, unchanging nature an explicit and stronger assertion about his perceived eternal sameness from the roses' perspective.

The French 'nostre durée, qui n'est que d'un instant' (our duration, which is but an instant) describes human lifespan. The English 'our own scanty Life' makes the implied negative quality (i.e., insufficiency for observing long-term phenomena) of this short duration explicit with the adjective 'scanty' (meager, insufficient).

The French 'mis à bout' (literally 'put end to end') describes how the 'âges d'homme' (ages of man) are to be considered for judging immortality. The English 'one after another' explicitly clarifies this implied sequential arrangement of lifespans, making the image more direct for the reader.

The French 'd'y pouvoir pretendre' (to be able to claim *it*) uses a pronoun 'y' whose antecedent (immortality/eternity) is implied from the preceding discussion on long-lasting entities. The English translation makes this antecedent explicit by rephrasing the idea as considering 'the Worlds as things eternal.'

The French 'qui naissent & qui meurent dans un Jardin les unes aprés les autres' (which are born and die in a Garden one after the other) describes the roses' lifecycle. The English 'that bud one Day, and fall the next' expands on this by providing a more concrete and evocative image of their ephemerality, making the short, distinct phases of their existence ('bud,' 'fall') explicit.

The French 'il faut que l'espece se repare' (the species must be repaired/repair itself) is a general statement about new stars replacing old ones. The English 'and that Defect in Nature must be so repair'd' specifies that it is a 'Defect in Nature' (the disappearance of stars) that is being repaired, making the implied problem and the overarching system of cosmic balance explicit. The 'so' also links the repair mechanism explicitly to the appearance of new stars.

The French lists 'des herbes ou des plantes' (herbs or plants). The English translation expands this to 'Herbs, Plants and Flowers,' adding 'Flowers' as a specific and common example of 'plantes,' thereby making the category more concrete and explicit through exemplification.

The French 'qu'il ne luy en coûte pas davantage' (that it doesn't cost her more) uses the general term 'coûte' (costs) in reference to Nature's creation of worlds versus plants. The English translation makes explicit what is implied by 'costs' in this context by specifying 'no more Pains and Expence,' clarifying the nature of the 'cost' involved.

The French Marquise states 'm'en voila tout à fait revenuë,' meaning she has completely changed her mind or gotten over a previous notion (about the unchanging nature of worlds). The English 'that I am altogether returned to my self' interprets this change of mind as a return to her 'true' or more sensible self, making a psychological state explicit that was implied by 'revenuë' (having recovered from a misconception).

The French 'n'en parlons plus' (let's not talk about it anymore) is a concise suggestion to change the topic. The English translation expands this into the more formal and explicit 'make this subject no longer, that of our Discourse,' spelling out what 'it' refers to ('this subject') and its relation to their conversation ('that of our Discourse').

The French 'cela dépend de vous' (that depends on you) is general, referring to the Marquise's choice to imagine worlds beyond sight. The English 'it depends upon your Will' specifies the aspect of 'vous' (you) that is relevant – the Marquise's choice, volition, or desire – making explicit the faculty involved in this imaginative act.

The French 'si on veut, ou estre tels que l'on veut' (if one wants, or be such as one wants) describes philosophers' power over invisible regions. The English 'as they themselves shall fansie' makes explicit the mental process of 'wanting' in this speculative context as 'fancying' or imagining, clarifying the nature of the philosophers' creative agency.

The French 'aussi loin que vont vos yeux' (as far as your eyes go) is a common expression for the limit of vision. The English 'as far as your sight can penetrate' uses 'penetrate,' which explicitly adds a sense of active effort or overcoming visual limits, implying a deeper or more thorough seeing than the more passive 'go,' thus clarifying the extent of the mind's journey guided by the philosopher.

chunks.source_manual: <P105>Quoi, s'écria-t-elle, j'ay dans la teste tout le systeme de l'Univers! Je suis sçavante! Oüy, repliquay-je, vous l'estes assez raisonnablement, & vous l'estes avec la commodité de pouvoir ne rien croire de tout ce que je vous ay dit dés que l'envie vous en prendra. Je vous demande seulement pour recompense de mes peines de ne voir jamais le Soleil, ny le Ciel, ny les Etoiles, sans songer à moy.</P105>
chunks.target_manual: <P075>What, cry'd out the Marquiese, have I the Systemes of all the Universe in my Head, am I become so learned? Yes, Madam, you know enough; and with this Advantage, that you may believe all or nothing of what I have said, as you please. I only beg this as a Recompence for my pains, that you will never look on the Heavens, Sun, Moon or Stars, without thinking of me.</P075>
source_segments: ne rien croire de tout ce que je vous ay dit
le Soleil, ny le Ciel, ny les Etoiles
target_segments: the Systemes of all the Universe
believe all or nothing of what I have said
the Heavens, Sun, Moon or Stars
explanations: The French 'tout le systeme de l'Univers' (all the system of the Universe) uses a singular 'systeme'. The translation 'the Systemes of all the Universe' pluralizes 'systeme' to 'Systemes'. This explicitation likely aims to clarify that the Marquise has grasped not just one overarching cosmological model, but also the multiple interconnected components and planetary arrangements (e.g., other planets as worlds, stars as other suns with their own systems) discussed throughout their conversations, making the plurality inherent in Fontenelle's popularization of the new cosmic order explicit.

The French 'ne rien croire de tout ce que je vous ay dit' (to believe nothing of all that I have told you) grants the Marquise the freedom to disbelieve the presented scientific ideas. The translation 'believe all or nothing of what I have said' expands this into a symmetrical binary choice. This explicitation rewrites the specific permission by adding the option 'to believe all', thereby making explicit the full spectrum of intellectual autonomy implied for the reader, allowing for either complete acceptance or complete rejection of the novel concepts.

The French list of celestial objects is 'le Soleil, ny le Ciel, ny les Etoiles' (the Sun, nor the Sky/Heavens, nor the Stars). The translation expands this list to 'the Heavens, Sun, Moon or Stars'. The addition of 'Moon' is an explicitation. Given that the Moon (its nature, potential inhabitants, and status as another world) is a prominent and extensively discussed topic throughout 'Entretiens sur la pluralité des mondes', the translator makes explicit an element that is highly relevant and implicitly central to the context of their dialogues and the memories they should evoke.
